section.p: Dedicated to the incomparable Raymond Chandler
And to his peerless private eye, Philip Marlowe

I guess it was dinnertime because the smell of hot grease was floating up from the kitchen of the Maxwell House Hotel across the alley. I wasn’t working, just resting my ankles on the corner of my desk and wondering why I’d ever bought a pair of purple Argyles with lemon-yellow clocks; but the intellectual challenge was too much for me. I yawned and the buzzer sounded from the spare office I call my reception room. That told me somebody had opened the hall door. I finished off the yawn and was thinking about getting my feet off the desk and the alert, confident look of an efficient private investigator on my face when suddenly somebody was standing in the connecting doorway. His body was broad enough to almost fill it, which made him look shorter than he was, until you noticed he had to duck a little coming through. His face was broad and scarred, with the faded tan of an ex-outdoor man; he had short gray hair that lay flat on a round, hard-looking skull. His shoulders looked like the abutments for Boulder Dam. Anyway, he had wide shoulders. He looked like a circus strong man in town to visit his grandchildren.

His little, pale blue eyes roamed around the room, came back to rest on me. He came on into the room, hooked the guest chair around and sat in it carefully, as if he’d had a chair break under him once and wasn’t risking a repeat. All this made about as much noise as a bare foot on a bath mat.
“I’m Lou Anglich,” he said, in a rumble that came from down around his shoes. He said it as if it was information I’d been waiting for, and would be glad to get. “You’re Shaw, huh?”
I nodded. “You move pretty well, Mr. Anglich,” I said. “But why waste it on me?”

“You don’t get me, Shaw. A fellow named Lacey in the sheriff’s office sent me. I maybe got a job for you.” He looked around the room again, carefully, frowning at the near-walnut chairs, the rust-red carpet, the old calendar with Rembrandt on it, the back of my name on the glass door.

“You must have dough, the front you put up,” he said. He was wearing the kind of sport coat a lumberjack would go to the state fair in. He put a big hand inside it and lifted out a well-fed wallet. He tore it open and grabbed money from it, jammed the wallet back in a side pocket, poked through the bills and picked out the ones he liked. They were hundreds. I liked them too. He reached across and shoved a few of them under the pen set on the desk.
He leaned back and flashed some gold crowns at me.
“Dough is no problem,” he said. “Maybe you know me better now, huh?”
I put my hands back of my head and looked at the water stains on the ceiling.

“Anglich, Lou or Louis,” I said. “Former Tampa stevedore, deck hand, union enforcer. You operated a rum and guns service in and out of Cuba for a while, until the Coast Guard closed it down. You switched to bolita, ran up a tidy stake, came West. Bought real estate in the right places, made money. Hungarian ancestry, no family. No police record since Tampa.”
“Geeze,” he said. “I pretty near forgot about the bolita myself.”
“You said Lacey sent you. What did he think we might have in common?”
His little eyes pinched down, looked speculative. “I kind of expected a bigger layout. If you’re so good, why you operate out of this mousetrap?”
“I’ve wondered about that myself. I think Lacey gave you a bum steer.”
“Maybe a cheapie is what I want, at that.” He shifted in the chair. The chair creaked. “A cheapie that can keep his yap buttoned.”
“There’s another thing,” I said. “I have a somewhat restricted clientele.”
“Huh?” He creaked the chair again. “I can pay my way, you seen that.”
“You’ve got your own kind of connections, Mr. Anglich. I’m not sure we’d get along.”
His forehead narrowed down to an inch wide; he opened his mouth to scare me and then changed his tack. He shifted around in the chair and grinned an almost shy grin.
“Look, guy, I been out of the rackets twenty years. That dough’s as clean as church bingo.”
“Maybe cleaner. I still don’t think I’m the man to earn it.”

Anglich nodded as if I was finally seeing it his way. “Swell,” he said. “You got principles. Nice, if you can afford ‘em. Me, I come up the hard way. Maybe I cut a few corners on the way. But you think Lacey would of steered me to you if I was still working that side of the street?”
“I hope not.”
“I get it. The widows’ and orphans’ pal. But a guy which maybe he ain’t had all the breaks―toss him out on his can. Even if he’s a father.”
It was a pretty funny line coming from who it came from, but he wasn’t smiling. Something hunted peeped out of the little pale eyes just for a moment, and went away again.
“I guess I slipped on that one,” I said.

He got out the wallet again and rummaged, came up with a small photo of the kind itinerant fruit pickers have in their passport, passed it across. It was the face of a child barely old enough to sit up, with big round eyes, a solemn mouth, hair cut short and tied with a messy bow.

“That’s Little Anya,” he said. “My kid, see? I don’t see her in maybe twenty-five years now, but I never forget. I had to give her up, yeah; but I don’t forget. I get a stake, I come out here and make good. Now I want to find her, make it up to her. You can help me, huh?”
I got a pipe out of the drawer and poked at it with a burned matchstick.

“Listen,” he said. “Lacey says you’re a all right guy. I tell you a secret. Anya ain’t really my kid at all. I picked her up on the street in Ybor City, just a poor little throwed-away baby. I don’t know who her real folks was. Maybe I didn’t have no right―but what the hell―a little kid like that . . . .”
“Stole her, huh?”

“You don’t know how it was in them days. Or maybe you do. It wasn’t like now. No big welfare handouts. Nobody give a damn. I put her in a home―a nice place, trees and flowers, other kids to play with. I got to go away, business, you know? Then I come back; she’s gone. They give her away. Give her to some stranger; they say I signed papers that let them do that―the lousy punks. My Anya!”
I stared out the window, watching a high, fleecy cloud that looked like a unicorn’s head shred itself out into nothing.

“I ask questions, but they wouldn’t tell me nothing,” Anglich went on. “So I wait, two, three years, until I got some of the stuff that talks the language all them guys can understand. Then I try again.”

I looked at the photo on the desk and squared it up with a finger. Anglich hitched his chair closer. “There was a mug at the agency I got next. Cost me five cees but he told me Anya was took from the home by a couple name of Conroy, six months after I left her. They come West to work in a war plant. That’s the reason I come out here.”
“You’ve been here six years. How does it happen you’re just now looking for her?”

He leaned back and gave me an important frown. “I looked some the first year. But dough was tight; I got noplace. Now it’s different. I got something to offer Anya, now.” He took out a handkerchief that was less than a yard square and wiped under his chin and behind the ears with it.
“Any lead on these Conroys?”
“I figure maybe they changed their name.”
“Uh-huh,” I said. “You don’t want a detective, Mr. Anglich, you want Adalian the Psychic. Now if you’re through wasting my time I’d like to catch up on my foot-dangling.”
He thrust out his lower lip.
“You telling me you won’t find Anya for me?”
“You don’t really want me to, Mr. Anglich. You’re not really trying.”
His head jumped back as if he’d been slapped with a fish. His jaw dropped. He reached up a big, square hand and felt tenderly of his chin. He grinned.

“Hey,” he said. “Maybe you’re OK at that.” The grin dropped; he leaned forward and got an elbow on the desk. “Monday night I get a phone call. I don’t recognize the voice. The guy says, ‘Hey, maybe you’d like to see your daughter, Anya, huh?’ Just like that. After all these years.
“I say ‘Yeah, sure, who’s this?’
“ ‘Never mind that,’ the guy says. ‘Five grand is the price.’

“I say, ‘You nuts or something?’ Stalling, see? He says, ‘You heard me, brother. Five grand. Just take off your sock and count the toes. No more, no less. Think it over. We’ll call you later.’ And he hangs up on me.”
“And?”

“Nothing. I pretty near go nuts waiting. I don’t get no call. And all the time I wonder: Who is this mug? What’s Anya to him? Maybe he’s got her someplace, maybe he’s hurting her! The dough don’t mean nothing―but if he hurts her, I break his neck with my hands.”
I looked at him carefully; then I grinned a little. “Nuts, you’re just playing games.”
He sat bolt upright and looked ominous; then he relaxed and put his big hands on the desk and looked at them.
“Yeah, I’m still holding out. I dunno why.” He dipped into the inside pocket and fished out a small envelope, opened it and slipped out a second photograph, laid it in front of me.
“This is supposed to be the guy, Conroy. It’s a old shot, made back when they taken Anya away.”

I swiveled to get more light on the picture. It was a blurry snapshot of a turkey-thin fellow in a wide-cut white suit holding a shapeless Panama at his side, standing in front of a board fence. He had a bony, long-chinned face, thinning black hair, deep-set eyes that showed no light or warmth, a mouth like a carp that had been hooked plenty of times but never boated.
“Better,” I said. “Not good, but better. Who have you showed this to? Lately, I mean.”

Anglich shifted his seat in the chair. “I tried a couple local adoption agencies. My contact down South says these kind of outfits work together. According to him, they got to like inspect the foster home and that. But I draw a blank. They never seen Anya, they heard of no Conroy.”
“This contact down South: would he have a name?”

“Pate. A. J. Pate. But he’s out of the picture, years ago. Croaked, maybe. Too bad. I would of liked to of did the job myself. A rat like that. Selling a father info on his own kid, and holding out at that.”
“Holding out what?”
“That pic you’re looking at. I was tipped he had it. I had to twist the sucker plenty before he come acrost.”

“Let’s get this straight,” I said. “You’ve got a couple of twenty-five-year-old snaps and a name, and you want me to tie it to a woman who would be about twenty-six or-seven years old, probably married with three kids, and wouldn’t know you from Noah’s pet mongoose.”
He frowned and rubbed his chin, watching me. I got a bottle of rye out of the deep drawer and poured a couple of ponies. He picked his up and threw it at his tonsils as if he was mad at them.
“It don’t sound like much the way you put it,” he said. “But I got to find her, Shaw―and fast.” His voice implored me, as if all he had to do was convince me.
I sampled my drink. It was as good as warm whisky usually is. “Why not tell me what’s really bothering you, Mr. Anglich? Then maybe I can tell you if there’s anything in all this.”
He put his hands flat on the desk and stared down at the square, manicured nails.

“I’m being tailed,” he said in a dead voice. “I spotted the guy two, three times already. Or maybe there’s two of ‘em. In a gray VW with a crease in the left front fender. They been on me for two days now.”
“Any idea who’d be that interested?”

“Yeah. You could say I left some unfinished business back in Tampa. At least there’s guys might see it that way.” He shook his head. “I thought I was clean, after six years. But I guess once you get that kind of dirt on you, it don’t never come off.” His eyes were on me again, scared eyes. “That’s why I got to find Anya now, fast. Before it’s too late.”
“Talking that way doesn’t get you anywhere,” I said, and poured him another shot. “Mob rub-outs have gone out of style.”
“OK, so maybe I’m nuts. But what if I ain’t? Lacey said you were a all right guy, Shaw. Help me find little Anya.”
I reached across and slid the bills out from under the pen stand, flaked off one, handed the others back to him. A slow grin lit his battered old face like sunshine on rock.
“I knew you were a all right guy, Shaw,” he said.
“Sure, I’m a good guy,” I said. “But don’t get up a testimonial dinner just yet. I’ll see what I can do. That may turn out to be nothing. It has before, plenty of times.”
“Just so you try, Shaw. That’s all I’m asking.”
“I’ll want the address of the orphanage, the places you’ve tried here, anything you’ve got on these Conroys, where they worked and so on.”
“Yeah, sure, I remember all I can.” He remembered out loud for a while, and I wrote it down. It wasn’t much. He wiped his nose with the back of his hand and watched me frown at my notes.
“Don’t expect too much,” I said. “After this long you know chances aren’t good. And if I turn up anything it might cost you some money.”
“Don’t worry. I got plenty scratch.” He stood and jammed the leftover bills in a pocket.
“Where can I reach you?” I asked. “If I get anything.”
“I ain’t settled. I’ll call in.” He turned to the door, turned back.
“One other thing,” he said. “When Anya was just a little baby, she always loved dogs.”
“Sure,” I said. “I’ll remember that.”
He rolled on out, as silent as a shadow for all his tonnage. I hardly heard the outer door click.

I put his hundred in my shirt pocket, mixed myself a long drink, and sat down in the chair that was still warm from him. I played with the drink for a while and watched the light get yellower and the shadows creep across the office.
I rinsed the glass out at the wash bowl and looked at my face in the mirror. It looked back at me. The years had left a lot of tracks on it. I yawned, giving myself a good view of my fillings.
“You’re lucky, Shaw,” I said. “You’ve got your own teeth to have fillings in.”
I put on my coat and went down to the street.

Morry Blumenthal was a lean, grizzle-haired sourpuss. He was also city editor of the Independent. He was sitting back of a desk that had probably been new once―about the time Henry Ford raised wages to five dollars a day. His eyes were closed. When I was six feet away he opened them and yawned. “Hello, Joe. You still on the outside?”
“Don’t let me bother you if you’re working,” I said. I got out the picture Anglich said was a man named Conroy, held it out to him.
“I’ll bet you can’t put a name to the face.”
He rolled an eye at it, closed both eyes. “You win.”
“Try again. There’s ten bucks riding on it.”
He stretched out an arm that was not as long as a deck crane and took the photo, frowned at it, frowned at me.
“Well―I could be wrong. This is an old picture, late thirties I’d say by the cut of the suit. And faces change. But it could be . . . “
“Sure. Could be who?”
“Remember old man Prendergast?”
“Me too,” I said. “Let’s go browse the clip files.”
“What’s it about?”
“It’s too early to say―as they say in the papers.”

A cute little blond typist looked up grinning and winked at me as he unfolded himself and led the way down an aisle of desks into a room full of filing cabinets. It was a minute or two before he grunted and tossed a folder on the table.
“Have fun, pal. Even an old buzzard as publicity-shy as Prendergast gets mentioned a few times in twenty years.”

I leafed through it: Mr. Harvey Wade Prendergast, noted industrialist, attends NAM conference, returns from tour of European business centers, lays cornerstone, plans merger, dies suddenly. There were a few half tone cuts of the narrow bloodless face, the hair slicked sideways across the skull, looking much as it did in the photo Anglich had given me―if the photo was really Prendergast. There was no mention of any family.
“Prendergast have any children?” I asked.
“A daughter or two, as I recall. And of course, a wife.”
“How old? The daughters, I mean.”
“Old enough. Late twenties, I guess. Why?”
“The obit says he died of acute food poisoning after a family picnic. Botulism. Kind of an old-fashioned way to go.”
“He was an old-fashioned guy. Hell, he still wore wing collars with his dinner suit.”
“I don’t suppose there was any question about the diagnosis?”
Morry looked at me sideways. “After two years, I’d say the question is academic.”
“Yeah. Just my instinct for the nasty thought. By the way, was either of the daughters adopted?”
Morry pulled at a long lower lip. “Not that I ever heard. You could go out and ask them―but don’t say I sent you.”
“The family still at the same address?”
“I haven’t heard of five acres in Mayfair Heights going on the market.”
I thanked him, promised him a drink at an unspecified date, and went on out.
The blond girl was still typing, but now she looked sad and disappointed, as if the funny man had turned out to be a villain after all.
It was too late in the day for social calls. I had a sandwich and three or four drinks, sat through most of a movie that had been photographed during a power failure, and went home to bed.

The Harvey Wade Prendergast house was on one of those wide, curving streets that was laid out before they started platting real estate by the square inch. A Korean gardener who was manicuring a pansy bed spared me a sneer as I turned in at the gate. The house was big, but not more than twenty rooms, with a Spanish tile roof and lots of wrought iron in the right places, some nice imported trees, plenty of magnolias and bougainvillaea, and a circular parking space at the top of the drive with two cars parked in it. One was a little silvery-gray Jaguar and the other a big yellow El Dorado. Farther back I could see a four-car garage and grounds stretching across to some stately old trees that seemed to stand a little aloof from the rest of the composition, as if they’d been there before the house and would be there after it was gone.

I pulled in beyond the Jaguar and set the brake and got out and sniffed some expensive morning air of the kind that’s only found behind trimmed hedges, above clipped lawns. It was nice air, filtered and scented; the breeze blew with a pleasant restraint; it knew better than to get tough around here.

I went along the flagstones to the front door, which was built up out of rough oak planks and hung on iron straps and looked strong enough to withstand a siege. Before I had time to poke the bell, the door opened and a smooth-looking old bird in a fawn-colored jacket and an ascot tie and a nice head of wavy gray hair stepped out. He looked a little surprised to see me.
He said, “Oh―was there something?” and stood with his hand on the doorknob, not exactly blocking my entrance, but not exactly ushering me in, either.
“Shaw is the name,” I said. “Mrs. Prendergast at home?”
“I’m afraid Mrs. Prendergast isn’t seeing anyone just now. She’s not well, you know. Possibly I could help, Mr. . . . .. ah . . . Shaw.”
“I was hoping to talk to a member of the family.”
“I’m Frank Prendergast, Mrs. Prendergast’s brother-in-law.”
“Then maybe you could help me, Mr. Prendergast.” I got out my snapshot―not the one of Anya―and flashed it. Uncle Frank gave it a sharp look, lifted his pale eyebrows at me.
“Where did you get this?” He took the picture in bony, manicured fingers and studied it, frowning a little in a well-bred way.
“Can you identify it, Mr. Prendergast?”
He pushed his lips in and out, tapped the picture against his palm. “Just who are you, Mr. Shaw?”
“I just drove over from the Independent in the hope of checking out a few things, Mr. Prendergast.”
“What sort of things, may I ask?”
“This photo, for a start.”

“What possible connection might there be between my family―my brother’s family, I should say―and anything that would be of interest to a―a person in your position?” He asked this in a mildly puzzled way, as if the whole thing was a bit daffy.
“That’s what I’m trying to find out, Mr. Prendergast.”

“We seem to be asking each other questions, Mr. Shaw,” he said. “Very well, I see no reason to be reticent. This is Harvey Prendergast, my brother. Taken many years ago, of course.” He handed the photo back to me.
“Would that be before the birth of his daughters?”
His smile stiffened. “Perhaps you’d better tell me just what this is all about, sir.” He glanced at his wristwatch. I took it he didn’t want any long explanations.
I nodded judiciously. “As you say, there’s nothing to be cagey about. No reason the newspapers shouldn’t have it.”
A hard little smile twitched at the corners of his mouth.
“You’re not playing fair, sir. I answered your question. I think you have an obligation to answer mine, eh?”
“Right here on the doorstep?”

“Suppose you step inside, Mr. Shaw.” He stepped back and we grinned slyly at each other, two smart cookies fencing delicately with poisoned foils. I went in past him into a hallway lined with pictures of somebody’s ancestors, along that to a pair of glass-paneled doors which opened into a sunroom that had lots of big rattan chairs with plum-colored cushions, lots of low glass-topped tables to go with the chairs, a big fiber rug that would be hell on bare feet, and a view on two sides of lawn and flowers and a swimming pool. Except for the cool whisper of the air conditioning the whole house was perfectly silent.

He waved me to a chair and sat down, carefully pulling his trousers up to save the crease. He was wearing brown silk socks with white clocks, and tan-and-white shoes just out of the box, still shiny on the bottom. Above the socks his legs were as thin and white as rolled newspapers.
“Drink, Mr. Shaw? I seldom indulge, especially on such a beautiful morning, so you’ll excuse me if I don’t join you.”
“No, thanks.”
He nodded brightly. “Now, then,” he said comfortably. “What’s this about newspapers?” We understood each other now; now we’d get down to cases.
“That was just a gag,” I said. “Where was Mr. Prendergast living at the time the picture was taken?”
Uncle Frank looked at me sharply. “You were going to tell me how you came by that photograph, Mr. Shaw.”
“I’m not at liberty to say, Mr. Prendergast. Would there be any way of tying it down, as to time and place?”
“None whatever. Look here, sir―”
“I understand the Prendergast daughters are in their late twenties. From the style of the suit, I’d say the picture was about the same age.”
“Kindly tell me just what it is you’re after, sir.”

“I don’t really know, Mr. Prendergast. I drove out here to ask about the picture. I expected to be told it was made at the family picnic in ‘forty-four, or was it ‘forty-five, and what about it. Either that, or to be given the fast gate. Instead, here we are, all settled down ready for you to pump me. For a man in my position, that’s enough to make me curious, if I wasn’t before.”
“Well, you’re candid enough.” For a moment his eyes measured me; then he relaxed and gave a light laugh. He lifted a liver-spotted hand and let it fall back.

“Very well, Mr. Shaw, I seem to have handled this encounter badly. I confess to being a nosy old man. There’s not a great deal in my life any more to interest me. When a large, competent-looking chap such as yourself appears on my doorstep waving a photograph of my brother, naturally I’m intrigued. And naturally I’m not in the habit of giving out information of a semi-personal nature to any stranger who happens to inquire.”
“You said ‘my doorstep.’” I cocked an eyebrow at him.
“The house is my sister-in-law’s, of course. But I’ve made my home here for the past two years. Mrs. Prendergast has never recovered fully from the shock of my brother’s death, poor lady.”
“What did he die of?”
“Food poisoning. A tragic thing. But even in this day and age―”
“What kind of food?”
“Lobster salad, as I recall. But―”
“Anyone else get sick?”
“As a matter of fact, I was quite ill myself; but lobster was a great favorite of Harvey’s. He ate the bulk of the contaminated salad.”
“You were visiting at the time?”
“Actually, I had moved West a year or two before. But look here, Mr. Shaw―what has all this to do with your inquiry―whatever it is?”
“How did Harvey Prendergast make his money?”
“I think I’ve talked enough for this morning.” He put his hands on his knees as if about to push himself up out of his chair.
“All these things are a matter of public record, Mr. Prendergast,” I said. “I could dig the information out of the newspaper files.”
“Then why ask me?”
“Why not answer me?”
“Perhaps I have other uses for my time.”
“What do you do for a living, Mr. Prendergast?”
“I’m retired.” This with a delivery like a mousetrap.
“From what?”
“From business. My business, Mr. Shaw.”
“Uh-huh. Harvey Prendergast was in the shipping line, wasn’t he?”
“He owned controlling interests in a number of steamship companies, among other enterprises, yes.”
“You weren’t connected with his companies?”
“Harvey and I were never close.” This time he stood. “And now I think you’d better go, Mr. Shaw.”
“You mean before I tell you where I got the picture of Harvey?”
“Very well―where did you get it?”
“Why do you want to know?”
He got a little white around the lips. For just a moment I got the feeling that in his younger days Uncle Frank might have been a bad man to play games with.
“Out,” he said. “Before you force me to forget I’m a gentleman.”

I stood. “Mr. Prendergast, I’m a private detective. It’s my business to ask questions, not answer them. My having the picture bothers you. You being bothered bothers me. The fact that you didn’t throw me out on my ear a lot sooner bothers me even more. When I get bothered my instinct is to dig harder.”
“You’re reading too much into an old man’s curiosity, Mr. Shaw.”
“When and where were Harvey’s daughters born, Mr. Prendergast?”
“Early in the war. On the East Coast. I’m a little vague about it.” He made a vague gesture, showing me how vague he was about it.
“Maybe I’d better talk to one of the Misses Prendergast personally,” I said. He opened his mouth to be rude and changed his mind.

“Perhaps that would be best.” He looked at his strap watch again. “I’m quite late for an appointment. If you’ll wait, I’ll see if either of my nieces is able to see you.” He went out, banging the door a little on the way.

I lit up a cigarette and looked out of the wide windows across the end of the room. Out back the gardener was dumping a wheelbarrow full of something into an outdoor fireplace, and sneering at that. A bird hopped across the terrace, busy on bird business. Sunlight sparkled like rhinestones on the pool. A few minutes went past, as minutes will.

A door opened across the room―not the one we had come in by―and a man came into the room. He was tall, broad, thick-bodied, dressed in a plain dark suit that somehow had a look of uniform about it. He halted and did a clumsy double-take, expressing surprise.
“Beg pardon, sir,” he said, and slitted his eyes at me. Maybe he was smiling. “I was just seeing to the ash trays.”
“Don’t mind me,” I said. “Just tell me when to lift my feet.”
He gave me a quick frisk with his eyes. If he saw anything that pleased him he did a good job of concealing it.
“I’m waiting for Miss Prendergast,” I told him before he asked.
“The name . . . sir?”
“Joe Shaw. I didn’t call ahead. I guess I should have gone around to the back door.”
“What was it concerning, Mr. Shaw?”
“Private.”
“I don’t think Miss Mianne has time for you today, Mr. Shaw.” This with a flat delivery.
“I’ll risk it.” I grinned and winked at him. “If it’s OK with you.”
His face went wooden. He turned to the door.
“You forgot the ash trays,” I said. He looked back, lifted his lip.
“I’ll see if the lady wants you thrown out on your ear.” He eased out, leaving the door half open.

I sat in the chair and felt thirsty. Around to the side of the house the gardener was slashing savagely at the lugustrum hedge with a big pair of shears now, still sneering. Or maybe his face was just built that way. There was a solid mass of tea-rose begonias under the window and a round carpet of purple and yellow pansies under an acacia tree. Pinks lined the walk that wandered across the lawn. Maybe it wasn’t a sneer at all; maybe it was a smile of quiet satisfaction at a job well done. And well paid.

There was a sliding glass door in the center of the bank of windows. I got up and went over to it, opened it, stepped out on the terrace. There was a heavy, sweet odor of gardenias in the air. I took two steps toward the edge of the terrace and a big black and tan shepherd dog wearing a broad horsehide collar came around the corner. His eyes were yellowish, with a wolfish slant. He came quickly toward me on his big rough paws, ears alert, stopped ten feet away. His ears flattened. His hackles bristled; he growled deep in his throat, a sound like a diesel idling.

I stood where I was, without moving a muscle. I thought the dog would want it just that way; I knew that if I took a step, even to retreat, he’d attack. I remembered reading somewhere that dogs can smell fear. I tried hard to smell brave.

Then a girl came around the path and called to the dog. His ears pricked up and he stopped growling, but he didn’t move. The girl came up quickly and hooked her fingers in his collar. She patted the side of his neck and rumpled his ears, and said, “Good old Robbie, good old boy.” She glanced at me.

“That can be dangerous, walking around the grounds unescorted.” She was a nice, quiet-looking little girl with soft, curly brown hair and a tender, vulnerable mouth that didn’t seem to have done enough smiling in its time. She was wearing a light green gardening smock with enough smudges on it to suggest she wasn’t just wearing it for effect.
“Sorry,” I said. “I didn’t see the sign.”
“I didn’t mean to be rude. But Robbie’s trained to guard the house.” She let him forward far enough to sniff my knee.
“Looks like a fine animal,” I said. “You train him yourself?”
“The Army trained him at the Special Forces School at Benning. But he broke a tooth and they flunked him. And he’s not really mine. He belongs to Mianne.”
“But you’re the one he’s got a crush on.”
She smiled quickly. “It’s mutual.”
She patted his shoulder absently and started off along the path. I dropped into step beside her.
“Mianne is your sister?”
“Of course. I’m Ellen Prendergast.” We were near the parking area. She glanced across at my car, didn’t see anything painted on the side of it. “May I ask your business here?”
“Shaw is the name. I was waiting to talk to Miss Mianne.”
“You have an appointment?” She sounded a little worried, as if she ought to have known about it if I had an appointment.
“No, but your uncle Frank said he’d see.”
“You know Uncle Frank?”
“Not well.”
She glanced at an upstairs window with closed drapes. “Mianne isn’t up yet.”
“What about Mrs. Prendergast?”
“Mother doesn’t see callers, Mr. Shaw.”
“I see. About Miss Mianne: will she be getting up for lunch?”
“You mustn’t be impertinent. Just what was it you wanted to see her about, Mr. Shaw?”

Just then the closed drapes up above stirred and came open a foot or two. A tall, slim figure in a fluffy pink something was standing there working a hairbrush on a glossy mane of black hair. At that distance I couldn’t see much but the figure, but there was plenty of that.

“She seems to be up now,” the little girl I was talking to said in a tone with a nice snap to it, calling me to heel. J let my gaze linger up above long enough to let Miss Mianne catch me looking at her. If it bothered her, she didn’t show it. She turned away lazily, still brushing.
“Well, you made quite a hit,” the nice little girl said.
“She doesn’t smile at just anyone this early in the day.”
“Tsk,” I said. “Is that any way to talk about Miss Mianne?”
She looked at me primly for a second and then let a smile show, just for a moment, like a shy woodland creature.
“Please come in, Mr. Shaw,” she said. “I’ll tell her she has a caller.”

She leaned to pat the dog and whisper in his ear; he strolled off and she led me in a side door under a trellis full of scarlet climbing roses and along a rather narrow tiled passage into a big parquet-floored entry hall. Across that, and we were back in the sunroom.
“Please sit down. It may be a few minutes. If you’ll excuse me . . . “
“Why not stay and talk awhile, Miss Prendergast.”

She looked at me coolly. “I can’t imagine what we’d talk about, Mr. Shaw.” She went out and closed the door silently behind her. The Prendergasts were great ones for letting the old family detective commune with himself in the sunroom.

I went back and sat in my chair and wished I’d taken that drink after all. Uncle Frank had told Miss Mianne I was here. She’d been watching me through the drapes when I went outside. But he hadn’t told Miss Ellen. I wondered if that meant anything, other than that Mianne had been in her bedroom and Ellen out in the potting shed. Uncle Frank had also sent the hard boy in the dark suit in to look me over. That was all right too. A family of women and one elderly man had a perfect right to hire a bodyguard if they wanted to.

It was a good quarter hour before the door the butler had used swung in and a tall, black-haired beauty came halfway across the room and smiled. She wore a white knitted something that showed lots of smooth, tanned shoulder and a nice pair of knees. There were hints of color in the dark eyes, of latent warmth in the curve of her lips. Her cheek line and jaw showed the kind of bone structure that separates the stars from the extras.
“I’m Mianne Prendergast,” she said in a voice that made it sound like a secret joke between us. I got up out of my chair.

“Shaw,” I said. “It’s good of you to see me, Miss Prendergast.” I took the hand she offered me. It was a nice hand, well shaped, strong, smooth, and not too much paint on the nails. She let me hold it while she looked into my face.
“Do I know you, Mr. Shaw?”
“I’m afraid not. Actually, it was Mrs. Prendergast I wanted to see.”
“Mother?” She took her hand back and strolled over to the windows. “Mother doesn’t often have an attractive male caller. Could you tell me what it’s about?” She turned and smiled encouragingly.
“Miss Prendergast, did you ever know a family named Conroy?”
She pursed her lips a little, shook her head. “I don’t think so.”
I got out my snapshot of the man with the Panama hat and showed it to her. She glanced at it.
“It’s Daddy, isn’t it?” she sounded a little surprised. “Taken a long time ago. He looks so young.” She took the picture and looked at it sadly. “It’s hard to believe he was ever young.”
“How old was your father at the time of his death?”
“Oh―all of seventy, I imagine. He was very secretive about his age. He was much older than Mother, of course.”
“You don’t happen to know when or where the picture was taken?”
“I haven’t an idea. Probably before I was born, judging by the funny old suit Daddy’s wearing.” She handed the picture back.
“You don’t happen to have a baby picture of yourself, Miss Prendergast?”

“My parents weren’t camera bugs, Mr. Shaw. As a matter of fact, my father hated to have his picture taken. I suppose we all absorbed his attitude.” She gave me the conspiratorial smile again. “But you still haven’t said why you’re asking all these questions.”
I was smiling back at her. “That’s right, I haven’t,” I agreed.
“But then, I haven’t given you many answers, have I? I’m afraid I haven’t been of much help. Maybe it would be better if you did talk to Mother.”
“I understood she wasn’t seeing anyone.”
“Nonsense, Mother loves visitors. Where did you get an idea like that?”

“Just an impression I picked up, maybe.” I followed her out into the hall and up a sweeping staircase with blue carpet and a white-painted oak handrail of the kind that nobody’s known how to make for a generation.

Miss Prendergast was a nice, friendly girl, glad to interrupt her shopping trip to help out a fellow with a problem. Uncle Frank had met me first; then Miss Ellen. Miss Mianne had had her look. Now it was Mrs. Prendergast’s turn. It was a nice, smooth routine, almost as if it had been planned that way. As if they had been expecting me.

She was propped up in a big bed like a Parisian doll on display in a show window. There was lace on the pillows and on the curtains at the window beside her; the bed jacket she wore was a mass of frills and tiny embroidered rosebuds. Her hair was that shade of gray that blonde hair turns to, and it looked as if it had been fussed over for a couple of hours by Andre of the Ritz. The face under the coiffure was thin, lined, almost without color; but traces of what it had been once still lingered there, like a hint of perfume in a room where a princess has slept.
“Mother, this is Mr. Shaw to see you,” Miss Mianne said softly. She drew a chair with a brocaded seat around for me beside the bed and retired silently into the background.
Mrs. Prendergast looked at me with her big faded violet eyes. Her hands lay on the coverlet like plucked sparrows.
“I don’t believe I know you, Mr. Shaw,” she said in a whispery voice, a voice murmuring in a deserted ballroom.

“I’m a private detective, Mrs. Prendergast. I appreciate your seeing me. What I have to say won’t take very long.” I patted a couple of pockets and frowned. I hitched around in my chair and grinned foolishly at Miss Mianne.

“Some sleuth,” I said. “I must have dropped the picture on the way up.” Before I could go through the motions of rising she said, “Don’t get up,” and slipped through the door. I turned back to the invalid.

“I’ll be brief, Mrs. Prendergast,” I said quickly. “I’m trying to trace a child who was adopted from an East Coast orphanage in 1942. A little girl with dark hair. It seems her father has come into money. Not a lot of money, but enough that he’d like to see his daughter get it. There’d be no strings, of course. Just an anonymous donor.” As I talked, her face tightened, became stark and bloodless. Her eyes were like eyes peering out between the bars of a cell.
“My God,” she said. “Who sent you here?”

“Just following up a lead, Mrs. Prendergast. Lots of leads lead nowhere. Maybe this is one of those. But it might save time all around if you could tell me if you recognize this picture.” I took out the photo of little Anya and held it for her to look at. She barely glanced at it.
“What do you want from me? I’m a dying woman.”
“I hoped you’d tell me whether this is your daughter.”
She stared at me as though I’d just said something astounding. Then she swore.

She knew all the words. She used them with skill and imagination, covering my ancestry, present habits, and future offspring. I listened until she finished and lay back panting, her mouth sagging open like a picked pocket.
“There must have been something in the picture I missed,” I said. I tucked it away and got out the other. “Care to try this one?”
She spat on it.
“Thanks for your valuable assistance, ma’am,” I said. “That rounds things out nicely.”
“Get out, you filthy, creeping, sneaking . . . “
“Sure, right away. By the way, which girl is the adopted one?”
She made a noise like a chicken strangling. Suddenly she was crying, big wet tears spilling out of the big pale eyes, cutting tracks across the powdered cheeks.
“I hated him,” she pushed out the words in choked gasps. “God, how I hated him―”
The door behind me banged open. Miss Ellen came through it with a prairie fire in each eye.
“Get out!” She bit the words off like an infantryman pulling a grenade pin with his teeth. “Who let you up here? What have you been saying to Mother?” She brushed past me, making distressed sounds.
I went out in the hall. Mianne Prendergast was there, looking contrite.
“I’m sorry,” she said. “I thought it would be all right.”
“Yeah,” I said, a little savagely. “You must have read the signals wrong.”
“Oh, dear. I hope Mother wasn’t rude?”
“I wouldn’t call it that.”
“I’d like to make it up to you. Perhaps if we talked again? I could meet you in town―tomorrow, say?”
“My office is in the Banshire Building.”
She shook her head. “You know the Penguin Lounge?”
“A long time ago I did―if it’s the same place. On Cigale, near Sixth?”
“At two o’clock?” She offered her hand, gave mine a quick squeeze.
“Don’t be late,” I said, “or I’ll have a snootful.”

The butler came up then; he managed to conduct me down to the door without socking me. I made it around to my car without meeting Robbie. Maybe the old Shaw luck was still in. I’d paid a call on the upper crust and gotten away with nothing that a good hot bath and a couple of stiff shots of rye wouldn’t cure.
When I got back to the office the phone was ringing.

It went on ringing as I crossed the outer office, unlocked the inner door, parked myself behind the desk and got out the office bottle. It rang while I poured and while I capped the bottle and put it away. I listened to it ring while I rolled the stuff on my tongue, made a face, and swallowed it. It tasted like what they keep pathology specimens in.
“Joe Shaw, Investigator, licensed by the city of Los Angeles, at your service with a smile on the lip right along with the knuckle bruises,” I said, and lifted the receiver.
“Shaw?” a tight, furtive voice said. “This is Albert P. Jaster calling. There’s a matter we ought to talk over.”
“What’s it about, Mr. Jaster?”
“I’m not free to discuss it over the telephone.”
“Could you tell me who you are, Mr. Jaster? Over the telephone, I mean.”
“I’m an attorney.” There was a little snap in the voice now.
“Well, that’s fine, Mr. Jaster. Would it be a breech of security to tell me where you got my name?”
“Maybe you don’t get me, Shaw. What I have is hot. Very hot.”
I leaned over and lifted the city directory off the shelf, opened it to the J’s, and went down the list. I found two J asters, but no Albert P.
“Are you still there, Shaw?”
“Still here, Mr. Jaster.” I put the directory back and tried the yellow pages, ran a finger down the columns of lawyers. No Jaster listed.
“Well―what about it?” he said.
“What about what?”
He made an annoyed sound. “Get wise, Shaw. This is a serious business proposition. You’d better get over here right away.”
“Where would that be, Mr. Jaster?”
“I have offices in the Russon Building. Room 619.”

“Look, Mr. Jaster, I don’t want to give the impression I don’t want your business, but I’d have to have more than the temperature of this matter of yours before I expose myself to the direct rays of the afternoon sun.”
I listened to some hoarse breathing into the mouthpiece that suggested halitosis. He cleared his throat.
“Anya,” he said.
“Go on.”
“That’s all you get―over the phone.”
“Well, you’ve intrigued me after all, Mr. Jaster,” I said. “Maybe I will drive over there, say in an hour?”
“I’m leaving in thirty minutes.” There was a clack and I was listening to a dial tone.
“You played that one just right, Shaw,” I said. “Smooth, snappy, and you didn’t give away more than ten pounds and a horseshoe.”
I tried the bottle again just to confirm my first impression, locked up the office, and rode the elevator down to the parking lot.

The Russon Building was on Serrano, a chalky stucco front with the date 1928 in green tiles above the entrance. A menu board inside listed a dozen or two names with an air of tired defeat about them. From the amount of dust in sight I had a feeling that a lot of the names had moved on long ago. Jaster’s wasn’t there. Probably his idea of playing it cagey.

I rode one of the original Otis elevators up to the sixth floor and prowled along the corridor. Number 619 was locked. I gave it the old bootlegger’s knuckle, light and confidential. Something squeaked inside. The knob rattled. The black varnished door opened on a pale, wary face with a soft round chin, suety cheeks, an oily complexion, and an undernourished black mustache that drooped at the corners of delicately shaped lips pink enough to be rouged.

He backed out of my way, looked along the hall before he closed the door behind me. “Nice to see you, Shaw,” he said. His hair was thin, combed forward; it looked like a toupee, except for the bald spot and the dandruff flakes. His dark suit needed cleaning. “Have a seat.” He bustled around behind the desk.

It was a bare carpetless room paved in scuffed brown linoleum, with metal desks and filing cabinets in shades of gray that didn’t match. There were a couple of hard-looking chairs of different patterns, a built-in closet with a dark curtain, an open door into another room. I went over and looked in. It was a small windowless anteroom with chairs, magazines, a worn rug.

“Sit down, sit down.” Jaster made an expansive gesture and settled into his swivel chair. It squeaked again. I got out a cigarette and blew smoke across at him. He picked up a chewed pencil and poked in his ear with it, looked at the point and frowned.
“How do you figure it?” he asked suddenly. He seemed nervous, like a fellow who’s gotten the girl up to his apartment and doesn’t know what to do next.
“Figure what?”
He made marks on his desk calendar, looking casual. “How maybe we could do a little business together.”
“What business would that be?”
“Maybe about a client of yours,” he said quickly.
“Have I got a client?”
“You’re eating.” He looked at me now, a knowing look, like a dirty picture salesman back for a repeat order. “You could be eating better,” he said.
“Like you.”

His hand jerked and the pencil point broke. I grinned at him. He tossed the pencil on the blotter; it rolled across the desk and fell on the floor with a too-loud clatter. “Let’s not mouse around,” he said sternly. “What do you want?”
I stood up. “Excuse it, please. I must have the wrong place. I understood somebody here wanted to see me.”
“All right, all right―take it easy. Sit down, Shaw.”
“What for―so you can try out another bunch of gag lines on me?” But I sat.
“Don’t get too flip, Shaw. I’m wise. I saw the Hunky go to your office. Later I saw you pay a call on what the papers call a prominent local family.”
My cigarette didn’t taste good. Maybe it was the atmosphere I was burning it in. I leaned across the desk and mashed it out in a bleary glass ash tray with a photo of Atlantic City on the bottom.
“The Prendergasts,” I said. “You can say the name. It’s all right. Nice folks, the Prendergasts. Ever met Mrs. Prendergast?”
His eyes jumped.
“Oh, did I let something slip?” I leaned back and grinned at him.
“We’re just kidding each other,” Jaster said. “Let’s get down on the rug.”
“All right,” I said. “Let’s talk about Anya. Does that make it any easier?”

He tensed, but kept his voice casual: “I happened to see the big guy on the street. I knew him, knew the kind of friends he had back East. I did a little checking, found out he was in the silk these days. I kept an eye on him, got wise he was making the rounds of adoption agencies. I know people in places. They gave me the name: Anya.”
“So you phoned him.”
“Maybe. Just sounding out the guy’s meat, you know.” He grinned a nasty grin. “He ain’t so tough.”
“Let’s get on to the business we were going to do together.”
He licked his red lips. He was tasting something he liked now. “I don’t know what routine he gave you, Shaw. You give it to me just the way he gave it to you, and I pick out what we need.”
“What we need for what?”

“To parlay the play into the big money. I know Anglich; I know plenty on the guy. But he don’t know me. Maybe he did once, but I changed a lot. Him, hardly at all. Now, I could handle it alone. But hell, there’s plenty in it for both of us―if we slice it right. Why be greedy? So I’m cutting you in.”
“Nuts―you don’t know anything you can use, Jaster. You got me up here to tease something out of me. I had the same idea, maybe―but I can see I’m wasting my time.” I made a move as if to get up.

“Hold it, Shaw,” he said sharply, and there was a little glitter of victory in his eyes. “I’m holding plenty cards, guy, don’t ever doubt it. Maybe I haven’t got it all in the can yet. Maybe there’s ways to play it I don’t see yet. But what I got is the goods. You put a guy like Anglich and a family like the Prendergasts together, and milk gotta flow.”
“Why let me in on it? A smart fellow like you could handle it alone, given a little patience.”

He leered across the stained blotter. “I got my feet dirty a few times in this town. I couldn’t get within a block of Mayfair Heights without being curbed by a carload of law. You’ve got the front I need to work in the open.”
“Uh-huh. That’s what I’ve got. What’ve you got?”
“Nix,” he said sharply. “You spill first. Then we take it from there.”
I looked thoughtful. “We sell him a dutch, is that the idea? Or do you like the blackmail angle better?”
He hitched himself around in his chair, his eyes on me, furtive as mice. “Depends,” he said. “How does it look from where you stand?”
I grinned at him. “Like bluff, Mr. Jaster. You just want on for the ride.”
He stared at me, gave a barking laugh. “You poor sap. I’m on the rail; you’re back in the pack. What’s to bluff?”
I yawned. “If you’ve got anything solid to show me, better dig it out.”
“Ah, hell,” he said, but he sounded contented. “I’m wasting my time with a guy like you.”
I pushed back my chair and went across to the door; when my hand was on the knob he said, “Hey.” I looked back at him.
“What about a straight cash deal?” he said, and grinned, watching me.
“Straight how?”
“Five grand for a line into the Hunky. Turn over what you’ve got and deal yourself out. How’s it sound?”
I scratched the side of my jaw with a forefinger, which reminded me I needed a shave.
“Suppose I top that,” I said. “Ten grand for information leading to a positive ID on the girl.”
He grinned wider. “Take the air, Shaw. Come back when you’re ready to talk real money.”
I nodded. “By the way, you drive a gray VW?”
He looked blank. “They lifted my license.”
“Let me know if you change your mind,” I said.

I bought myself lunch in one of those all-plastic eateries with matching cuisine and thought over the morning’s work, looking for the deep inner meanings. There didn’t seem to be any. Back at the office I made a few calls to acquaintances at the courthouse. There were no records covering the birth of the Prendergast girls. They were already part of the family when the family moved into Los Angeles County. I phoned the agencies Anglich had mentioned and got the swift chill-off. That seemed to be that for the day.

I drove on home to the Cheshire. My chess problem was still laid out on the coffee table where I’d left it; nobody had solved it in my absence. I went out to the kitchenette and bought myself a quick shot from the guest Scotch bottle, stood under a hot shower long enough to steam the smell of Albert P. Jaster’s operation out of my pores, and stretched out on the sofa for a short siesta.
It was twilight when the phone woke me. I yawned, and fumbled it to my ear. A thick, heavy voice, like the voice of a drowned man: “Shaw.”
I gripped the phone tighter. “Go ahead, I know you.”
“You better come quick. I got plenty trouble.”
“Where are you?”
“Hobart Apartments, 112 Bell Street, Room 211. One flight up, at the front.”
“I’ve got it. What kind of trouble?” But I was talking to myself. He’d hung up on me.
I got dressed and started for the door, then went back and got my Smith and Wesson short-nose and buckled it under my arm. It looked like it might be one of those trips.

I kicked the little Olds I was driving that year to life, not without some persuasion. An early evening fog had drifted in from the beach, bringing along the usual quota of industrial waste. I drove east on Wilshire, riding bumpers, rushing the lights, then north on Alvarado. No more neon here. A vapor lamp on a pole showed me a sign that read Bell Street. I did two blocks up a slight incline, parked in front of a boarded-up red brick building that had been a funeral parlor in happier times.

One-twelve was a three-story frame apartment house that somebody had tried to prop up with a layer of asbestos siding. It had a heavy green-painted door with thick cut-glass panels behind which faint light showed. I stepped inside, stood on warped linoleum with holes through which dark oak flooring showed, and listened to a lot of silence. Dim doors with metal numbers nailed to them lined the hall. Halfway back a staircase went up. Dull brass stair rods held down an eighteen-inch rubber runner that had given up fighting back a long time ago.

At the top I prowled back toward the front. Two-eleven was at the end. I tapped lightly with a fingernail. There might have been a sound from inside. Behind another door across the hall somebody sneezed and went on sneezing. I tried the knob; it turned.

The only light came from the pole lamp on the street, filtered through a torn roller shade. There was a patch of dark rug a chair, a brass double bed with a snarl of bedding hanging down over the foot.

Lou Anglich was lying on the bed, propped up against a couple of pillows with striped ticks. His eyes were swollen almost shut. There was blood on his mouth, on his upper lip, on his chin. Bruises showed between the bloody places. There was a knot in front of his ear that made his face lopsided, misshapen. The broken mouth moved, said painfully:
“You make good time, Shaw.”
I went over and looked down at him. The gaudy jacket was scuffed and torn. His thick hands lay curled in his lap, the big knuckles raw.
“What happened to you?”

“I need a drink.” His head twitched in the direction of the chipped bureau against the wall. I got the bottle and uncapped it and held it to his split lips. He took a couple of swallows and breathed out harshly.
“Three guys,” he said. “They jump me in a parking lot.”
“You know who they were?”
“Never see ‘em before. But I got a idea, OK.”
“You ought to be in the hospital. Some of those cuts look bad.”
“No hospital. After a while I feel better, I fix myself up then.”
“You need a doctor to sew you up.”
He started to sit up. “No doctor―and no cops.”
I pushed him back. “Take it easy.” I got out my weeds and lit one, looking at him, feeling a thought coming to life.
“Why no cops?”
“I think maybe I croaked one of them punks.”
I waited.

“They hit me from behind, drag me inside a shed. They bounce me around pretty good then, but one of ‘em makes a mistake. He gets too close. I got strong hands. That makes it even. I wipe the other two mugs and I come here.”
“Where did this happen?”
“Back of a joint called Terry’s, over on Alamitos. A poolroom. I go in there sometimes to nibble a few. I ain’t comfortable in them downtown joints.”
“Anybody see this fight?”
“Hell, it ain’t no fight―not after I get warmed up. Anyways, it’s dark back there, no people around.”
“What makes you think you killed this fellow?”
Anglich looked down at his hands lying curled and bloody against his thighs. “I was holding his neck. I think I feel something break in there.”
“So you walked off and left three men lying around for the cop on the beat to trip over.”
“They’re inside. I close the door―I think.”
“What makes you think you can’t be traced here?”

“I ain’t followed. I move pretty good. I don’t leave no trail. Nobody sees me come in.” The broken mouth twitched. His eyes were glints between puffed slits. “I own this building. Wise guys, they jump me four blocks from my own property. But to hell with that, Shaw. That ain’t why I called you. They make a mistake only sending three guys with no iron. Next time they do it right. Yeah, they find me; not right away, but sometime. Those are the babies that never forget. OK, I don’t run away. I wait right here. But there’s one thing they don’t get. I been saving it a long time. It’s for Anya. You find her, Shaw. You give it to her.” He fumbled at his watch pocket with his thick fingers, brought out a flat brass key.
“In a locker at the train station. A suitcase, real pigskin. Inside a hundred and fifty grand in tens and twenties. Little Anya’s inheritance from her old man. If they get me―see she gets it.”

I looked at the key, turned it over and looked at the other side. It was a plain profile with a number stamped on the bow. Any enterprising young fellow with an hour to kill could make one like it out of a standard blank with a nail file.
“You looked at this money lately?”
“It’s there. Don’t worry. I got a guy keeping a eye on it. He thinks I got a out-of-town girl friend and this is my weekend duffel.”
“What if I don’t find her?”
“Then you keep the dough for yourself. What the hell, better you than them―or the cops.”
I put the key away. “I’d better go down and take a look at your work. Maybe he’s not dead after all.”
“Don’t put no dough on it.”

I left him lying there and let myself back into the hall. It was still empty. I went down the stairs, looked at the mailboxes, went back along the lower hall to a door with a crack of bluish light under it. Behind it a TV blared, applauding its own jokes. I rapped. A heavy voice yelled something. A refrigerator door slammed. Feet clumped. The door flew open and a big man holding a beer can in one fist looked out at me with an expression that was all ready to get belligerent, if it worked out that way. He took a long swallow of the beer, watching me over the rim, and said, “Yeah?”
He had a broad face, a wide expanse of forehead that didn’t suggest a high IQ, going back to meet thin, no-colored hair. A none too clean undershirt partly covered the pelt on his chest.
I said, “Manager?”
“I ain’t his sister.” He took the other half of his beer, crumpled the can in one hand and tossed it behind him. “What’s the graft, chum? You’re interrupting my dinner.”
“How well do you know your tenants, Mr. Shamey?”
“As good as I got to. Why?”
“Apartment 211; occupied?”
He hooked a thumb in his undershirt strap and leaned against the doorjamb. “Maybe yes―maybe no. Who’s asking?”
“Shaw. I’m a private cop.”

“One of them guys.” He turned and walked into the kitchen. I followed him. He kicked the door shut behind me. damping down the blare of the TV. He wrenched the top off a new beer Can, squeezed the contents down his throat.
“The tenant’s a friend,” I said. “He’s there now. He’s not feeling well. He wouldn’t like to be bothered.”
Shamey grunted. His little eyes watched me take Anglich’s hundred-dollar bill out of my pocket and unfold it, put it on the linoleum countertop and put an empty beer can on it.
“He’s willing to pay a reasonable amount for his privacy.”
He nodded thoughtfully, shrewdly. “A hot boy, huh?”
“He was in an accident. He got a few bruises. He’s just resting up.”
“Slug in him?” Shamey stiffened suddenly; his hand made a sudden movement toward his hip, changed its mind, scratched his ribs instead.
“Maybe you and me better go up,” he said in a flat monotone.
“Call him on the phone,” I said. “He’ll confirm it.”
His little blue eyes dug into my face. “I have a tenant croak on me once in a while,” he said softly. “Phone him, you said?”
He studied my face a little longer, then shrugged. His hand went out and twitched the bill from under the can, whisked it out of sight.
“I don’t know the guy, never seen him. So he wants to cool off upstairs, that bothers me like a knit doily. But if cops show, it’s their party. Me, I just watch.”
“I’ll be around to see him from time to time, Mr. Shamey. There might be more money later―if he decides to stay on.”
Shamey smiled with his lower lip. “Don’t worry about a thing, pal. I ain’t a guy to put a tenant in the grease.”
He drank the rest of his beer and watched me watching him flatten the can.
“As long as the pot’s right,” he added.
“Fine,” I said. “I knew I could count on you.” He followed me out as far as the TV set.

In the car, I dug a franked post office envelope out of the glove compartment and addressed it to myself. I put the key in it and dropped it in a mailbox at the first corner―one of those big blue and white ones that are placed just right so that you can reach across to them with no more inconvenience than a dislocated elbow.
Then I headed for Alamitos.

Alamitos Street, between Seventh and Eighth, was a neon-lit block of cheap clothing stores, pawnshops, mean hotels and suspect drugstores, one-flight-up dance halls and shopworn girly joints that leaked thin, brittle music across the sidewalk. Terry’s Billiard Parlor was a made-over store, a half-frontage on the ground floor of an old three-story walk-up. A sign in a dark window above said rooms to let. It was a nice part of town. I felt right at home there. It was where a man named Anglich had to come to do his drinking in comfort.

I drove past, went around the block, pulled into the space in front of a curb market that had given up the battle. A wan street light showed me a narrow airspace running back between buildings. I locked the car and walked back through the three-foot-wide passage over a carpet of cans and bottles, came out in a bricked alley. Weeds grew up between the bricks and around corroded garbage cans the city collector had dropped from the route. Off to the right the back of a big signboard occupied a space between buildings. A pair of old-model sedans slumped in the lot beyond it, like abandoned getaway cars.

Beyond the sign was a wall of dull corrugated steel. A green-enameled reflector with a dead bulb stuck out over a small door. The lights from the other side of the parking lot made a pool of black shadow there.

I unshipped my fountain-pen flash, played it across knee-high Jimson weeds at the base of the signboard. Some of the tall stems were broken, beaten down flat. They made a trail across toward the door. I switched off the light and stood flat-footed, listening.

Somewhere a radio twittered, far off a car engine raced, backfiring. A cicada chirred. I didn’t hear any shoe-leather creaking, but that didn’t mean there weren’t six plainclothesmen within twenty feet, waiting for me to get my neck all the way in. I felt the butt of my revolver with my elbow and went forward.
The door was closed. It opened on a big dark space full of the smell of silence. I eased inside and closed it behind me, listened to my own breathing for a few seconds, then switched on my light.

The floor was concrete, rough-finished, stained with oil and spilled cargo, littered, dusty. There were a few dark spots against the dust, bright red in the dime-sized spot. I saw foot-prints, drag marks, a small puddle of blood. I flashed the light a little further and found what I was looking for.

He lay on his side, his knees bent, his hands beside his face. Sallow-skinned, hollow-cheeked, acne-scarred, the thin black hair oiled across his narrow skull slightly mussed, after the biggest adventure of them all. Age, forty-five to fifty. He wore a dark blue suit, white shirt, shiny yellow-brown shoes, badly scuffed across the pointed toes. A red tie was flung gaily over his shoulder. His half-shut eyes glittered with a look of pleased expectancy. like a man on the way to the track with the inside facts. His lower jaw sagged a little, showing the edges of stained yellow teeth.
I tried to find the artery at the side of his thin, corded neck. His skin was already as chill and clammy as a toad’s.
Except for a few crates, the rest of the place was empty.

There was a lot of paper in his pockets: an airline schedule folded open to the New York flights, a receipted, two-day-old bill from the Hotel Tremaine, a sheet from a desk calendar, today’s date, with scribbling on it, the racing section from yesterday’s Tribune, much folded and marked, a movie ticket stub, a pair of Greyhound baggage checks. His wallet contained the usual credit cards, driver’s license, insurance card, all in the name of Arnaldo J. M. Carlotti, of Tampa, Florida.
I didn’t build too much on that. A lot of people were from Tampa, Florida.

I got out my wallet and slipped out the thick plastic window I kept for opening spring locks, wiped it clean, and took a set of prints from his right hand. I put his papers back, all but the scribbled one, straightened out his coat the way I’d found it, and backed out of there.

Back in the car, I used the flash to look over the calendar page. It was a common style; the fact that I’d seen one like it minus today’s page back in Jaster’s office didn’t necessarily tell me anything. The words: Terry’s Bar―Alamitos were written on the back. The scribbling was just scribbling, not even doodling. I held it close to the light, and could see what might have been words written under the scribbling. Or maybe not. I put the paper away and got the traveling bottle out of the glove compartment and took some of my medicine and subjected the data to the searching Shaw scrutiny. Five minutes of that lowered the level in the bottle by an inch. I put the cap back on, patted the bottle and tucked it away, started up and drove back around the block.

There was a red neon sign―beer―in the window of Terry’s. That and a ten-year accumulation of dust masked the front window. I made the corner and parked, transferred the pistol to my waistband before I got out.

I had the sidewalk to myself. The light at the corner was a white puff-ball through the mist. I pushed open the door to Terry’s and went in. A stocky man in a dark suit, with a big ring on his right hand, leaned on the bar, which was a plain wooden counter with a green formica top. Behind it, colored lights shone through bottles of cheap blended whisky. Printed cards were tacked on the wall: mail-order jokes about credit and hangovers, and some oversized breasts and hips in photographs. In the back of the room were covered tables, racked cues. It didn’t look like a place that was showing anybody a big profit.
The barkeep watched me take a stool. The other man looked straight ahead, past me. I ordered beer.
The barman drew it slowly, turning the glass, cut off the suds with an old table knife, pushed it across.
I tasted it. It tasted like what somebody had washed the cat in.
“Arnie around?” I asked.
“Arnie who?”
“Arnie Carlotti.”
“Carlotti, huh? A Spic name. I see lots of Spies. I don’t ask what their names is.”
“This Carlotti is about forty-five, sallow skin, losing his hair, snappy dresser.”
“Never seen the bum.” He turned away.
“Be nice, Shack,” the customer said. “Maybe Shiner could help the gent.”
I looked at him and smiled. He smiled back. He had thick lips, eyes that were set in deep hollows.
“Who’s Shiner?” I said.
“A guy that comes around. They call him Shiner on account of his scalp shines. He got no hair. He knows a lot of answers.” He was still smiling.
“He around?”

“I’ll go see.” He straightened, and behind me a glass broke. That was supposed to take my eyes. Instead I slid away from the bar and snapped the .38 out into sight, held it pointed at the floor near the feet of the smiling man.
“What the hell―” the barkeep blustered. “What is this―a heist? You’re outa luck, pal. The register’s flat.”
I backed a step to keep both boys in sight and leaned an elbow on the bar. “Polish another glass,” I said. I nodded to the customer, “Let’s be sociable. Come over and take a stool.”
He didn’t move. I grinned at him.
“Hell, he won’t shoot,” he said quickly. “Take him, Shack.”
“Take him yourself,” the barkeep said. His eyes seemed to bulge in his head a little, watching my hand with the gun in it.
“You got a sawed-off under the bar―” Smiler started, and his hand moved. I snapped the pistol up, hammer back. He stopped with his hand half out from under his arm.
“What are you waiting for?” the barkeep said. “Now’s your chance, smart guy.”
The Smiler straightened. “Hell, the guy’s a cop, Shack.”
“Better throw it down on the floor, Smiler,” I said. He laughed and lifted the gun clear, leaned over and put it on the floor.
“Now kick it in the corner.”
He said something that reminded me of Mrs. Prendergast and kicked it away.
“Now let’s talk about Arnie,” I said. “How long has he been around?”
“Ask Shiner,” the barman snarled.
“Fine,” I said. “Where is he?”

“Clam up, Shack,” the Smiler said. “He’s got nothing―” He stopped talking; in the silence I heard the faint howl of a siren, rising and falling, getting closer. Getting much closer. Rubber squealed from the corner. The siren growled down the scale. A red spot hit the front window, pushed red shadows across the dusty glass, along the wall.
“Like that, eh?” I said. I poked the gun at the Smiler; he slid aside. I went sideways to the back, to the door I had seen beyond the shrouded tables.
“Well, tell Arnie I was asking for him,” I said. I let myself out into the alley. Nobody tried to stop me.

I walked fast along the alley to my car, drove ten blocks, and pulled to the curb in front of a drugstore with big bottles of colored water in the window flanking the camera and sunglass display. Inside, an old rooster with red garters on his sleeves gnashed his plates at me and filled my order for gauze, iodine, adhesive tape, and aspirin. He rang up my money and looked at my left ear.
“All set?” The words seemed to come from his direction but his lips didn’t move.
I thought that over. “All set how?”
He shifted his piercing look to the back of the cash register. “Man oughtn’t to try to do too much doctoring hisself.”
“I leaned a hip on the counter and folded my arms, gave the place the casual once-over, leaned toward him a little.
“How do you mean, Dad?”
He gave the place a once-over of his own, in case I’d missed anything. “Know just the man. Handles a needle real nice. Top man on gunshot wounds. Got a little careless once, was all.”
“He know how to saw off a leg?”
The old boy’s head jerked. “How’s that?”
“Amputations. You know.”
The druggist’s color didn’t look good. “How bad is this feller hurt, for Gawd’s sake?”
“Who said he’s hurt? I just don’t like the guy.” He staggered back.
“Sure, ride me,” he said. “Everybody rides Walt.”
“Just a routine check, Walt,” I said. “You’ll be hearing from us.”
I looked back from the sidewalk. He was staring at me over the green bottle like an angry trout.

Shamey stuck his head out and leered as I went past. Upstairs, Anglich was still lying in the same position on the bed. His face was puffed up like a beach ball now, but he seemed a little more alive. He grunted and laid a small automatic pistol on the table beside the rye bottle.
I lit up a weed and looked at him.
“His name was Arnaldo Carlotti,” I said. “Never saw him before, eh?”
“I never see any of the bums before.”
“Carlotti was from Tampa. That’s your old stamping ground.”
“You think I know every gun-punk in the state?”
“It ties in with your idea that your old friends are still interested.”
“Yah. I already tell you that.”
“Ever heard of a man named Shiner?”
“Naw. Who’s he?”
“He hired the boys who worked you over.”
Anglich snorted. “Forget about them slobs. You find Anya for me. That’s what I hire you for.”
“That―and finding the bodies you leave laying around.”
“Yeah,” he said slowly. “That puts you in bad with the cops if they find out you don’t phone it in. Or―” He tensed up.
“No, I didn’t report it,” I snarled. “I guess three to one is fair enough odds. That doesn’t mean they won’t find you on their own. They do that occasionally, you know.”
“Geez, you’re a all right guy, Shaw. Don’t worry, if they catch me I don’t say nothing about you.”
“Sure,” I said. “Just try to keep your hands to yourself a little more after this. The necks you get hold of nowadays break so easily. You know a man named Jaster?”
“No.”

I spent a quarter of an hour with the tape and bandages. When I finished his face looked like a mummy that had come through the mails badly. I told him I’d see him tomorrow and left him nursing his rye bottle.

There were still a few lights on in the Russon Building. I parked across the street and made another try to read the words that might or might not be under the scribbling on the paper from Carlotti’s pocket. I still couldn’t. I went across and rode the car up. The sixth floor was dark and silent. Jaster’s door was locked; there was no light behind it. I tried my stuff with the celluloid: no go. The next door was more cooperative. I stepped inside and looked at the chairs and the dead magazines on the table. A buzzer had sounded when I opened the outer door. I closed it and the buzzing stopped. A little gray light came from the half-open inner door. I flat-footed over and looked through.

Papers were scattered on the floor and on the desk. Also on the desk was a hand, motionless, palm up, the fingers curled, a color that no live hand ever was. I eased into the room; the face that went with the hand rested with one gray cheek against the blotter. The tip of the tongue showed between lips that were no longer pink. The half-shut eyes glittered at me knowingly.

I went back and set the latch on the anteroom door, then came back in and put on the small hooded desk light. It made his bald spot look greenish, his fat neck the color of river-bottom clay. There was a soggy hole in the front of his shirt. Between his feet on the linoleum there was a black pool like drained oil.

The drawers were pulled out, empty. I poked around in the debris, looked under the blotter, in the filing cabinet. No clues jumped out at me. I went over and kicked the safe; the door swung open. Inside was a brown paper bag with Jaster’s lunch in it―that and some dust. I didn’t look inside the sandwich to see if there was a message tucked under the Bologna.

Jaster had had something that he thought put him in a bargaining position. But the bargain had gone sour, as such bargains will. Maybe I should have played my interview a little differently, talked a little longer. At the time I had had the feeling Jaster would soften up if he was left alone with his thoughts for a while. He looked like a man who would have that kind of thoughts.
Whatever he had had, he hadn’t left it lying around for me to find.

I started to leave and veered over to the desk and looked at the calendar pad. There was nothing on the top sheet except some of the Jaster scribbling. I leafed back a few days. All the sheets were scribbled. Several of them were missing. I took another minute to check the pudgy man’s pockets. They were clean. I almost missed the scrap of paper on the floor. Just a corner showed under his shoe. I slid it out. It was Sunday’s page from the calendar, folded twice. An address was written on it: 2056 Orlando Way, just legible under the black marks.
I put the light off, wiped the doorknobs, let myself out into the hall and left the door locked behind me.

Orlando Way was on the shabbier side of Sunset, a street full of those cereal-box prefabs they sold just after the war. It hadn’t looked good when it was new, and nobody that had lived there had ever gone to any trouble to try to ritz the neighbors. Twenty fifty-six had a small front porch that probably wasn’t part of the original package; the ends of real two-by-fours showed under warped decking above concrete block foundations. A broken front walk led up between squares of hard brown turf full of sickly dandelions. I drove on half a block and parked the Olds under a durable-looking palm tree and walked back.

The porch was empty. I rapped on a rusted-out screen door that rattled when I touched it. The roller shade on the window to my left twitched, then dropped back. The door creaked open and a small, pinch-faced woman in a dowdy housecoat peered out at me through the black screen. Behind her I could see new mail order furniture and bargain carpeting, a kerosene floor furnace in a narrow hall.
I said, “Good evening, ma’am. I’d like to talk to you for a few minutes on a business matter.”
She made a vague sound and whined, “We ain’t buying nothing, mister.” But she didn’t move.
“It’s a matter Mr. Jaster may have spoken to you about,” I said. Her eyes jumped; her face sagged sideways.
“We don’t know nobody like that,” she said in a breathless rush.
“Is your husband at home?”
Her eyes jumped again. I moved toward her and she gave ground. Behind her a voice said tiredly, “Ah, hell, let him in, Mae.”

The room was hot, small, untidy. A heavy-bodied round-shouldered man in a flannel shirt that was a size too big and too heavy for the season was sitting on a brown plush divan with worn patches on the arms that didn’t match the rest of the room. A ten-gauge shotgun lay across his lap; it wasn’t aimed at me, but it could be in a hurry. His finger was curled carelessly close to the trigger. There was a greasy patch on the flowered wallpaper above the back of the divan behind his head. The house stank of cabbage and careless housekeeping.
“What was this about a―Mr. Jester, did you say?” he squinted his eyes at me as if he was used to talking through cigarette smoke. There was sweat on his upper hp.
“If you don’t know him, what does it matter?” I said.
“You ain’t drove all the way out here to Brentwood just to talk smart,” he said. “Sit down―over there.”
“Fred’s just . . . cleaning his gun,” the woman said in a ratchety voice.
“That’s right,” Fred said. “I’m cleaning my gun. And I’ll clean it right into your vest if you get fancy, mister. Sit down―like I said.”
I sat. A broken spring poked me in the haunch. I watched the gun and wondered how far into my draw I could get before he got the muzzle around in line with my navel. Not far enough, I decided.
“I asked you, what’s this about Jaster?” He knew his name now.
“He couldn’t make it. I came instead.”
He thought that over while I listened to the woman making snuffling sounds from her end of the room.
“If I knew what you was talking about―and I ain’t saying I do―why ain’t he here hisself?”
“He had to stick around the office.”
“And who are you?”
“Shaw. We haven’t met.”

“Yeah? Maybe you better stand up at that, mister.” He shifted the gun a little more in my direction. I stood and he came to his feet. Standing, he didn’t look as big; his legs were short and bowed in baggy khaki pants.
“Mae, check him over. Let’s see who he is.”

The woman made a thin sound, like a chicken bone in the throat, strangling, and skittered down the hall into the back room and slammed the door. The man paid no attention to this at all. He moved in, shifted the gun to his right hand, and said, “Get them hands up high.” I followed instructions. He reached for me, maybe with the idea of patting me down the sides the way it’s done in the movies. I grabbed his wrist and yanked hard and kicked the shotgun out of his hand. He swore and tried to use his heel on my shins, and I hit him beside the ear. His eyes went glassy. I stepped back and let him go down on his face. All this made hardly any noise at all. I got his wallet and sat in the chair and rested my gun on my knee and mopped my face off with a handkerchief before I opened the wallet. There was a driver’s license, some expired credit cards, a union card, other junk, all made out in the name of Frederik A. Conroy.

While I was doing this Conroy was stirring around and groaning in a halfhearted way. He rolled over and sat up, looked around and stared at my knees. He grunted, made heavy work of getting to his feet and over to his divan. He kicked the shotgun away and rubbed a pale, spotty hand over his jaw.
“Brother, you sock,” he said blurrily. “What’s it about?”
“Anya,” I said.
He nodded and tried his jaw to see if it still worked. “I been through all that with A.P. I got nothing to add.”
“Go over it again―in case A.P. left something out.”
He narrowed his eyes down. “Where you know A.P.?”
“Where do you think?”
“I ain’t thinking.”
“We’re wasting time, Conroy,” I said. “Where’s the girl?”

That was the wrong question. His face changed, got tight and crafty and scared. “Wait a minute, mister,” he said. “What you pushing at me? I don’t know what you’re talking about. What you doing in my house, anyway?”
“You brought her out here in ‘forty-two or ‘forty-three,” I said. “I guess it was a legal adoption. How long did she stay with you?”
“You got the wrong party, mister.”
“She’d be in her late twenties now. How long since you saw her last?”
His eyes brooded on me. “You ain’t no friend of A.P. Where you get my name?”
“The point is I got it. Do you want to talk to me or would you rather do your talking down at Headquarters?”
He sat up and said, “Huh?” It was a nice covering action.
