I heard the sound behind me―too late. The woman was standing in the hall holding a .44 hogleg with both hands, aimed at my head. She came forward quickly, her back curved, her eyes flicking from me to Conroy.
“Get his gun, Fred,” she whispered.

“Aw, for cripe’s sake, Mae,” he said, and didn’t move. I got up and she put the gun in my face and strained at the trigger. I took it out of her hands. The safety was on, rusted on. She wailed and put the back of her hand against her mouth.
Conroy was looking at me, almost grinning.

“Naw―you ain’t no cop. A cop would have put three slugs in her before he thought to check the safety.” He made a pushing away motion. “Hell, we got nothing to hide. Not after all this time. Me and Mae give up the kid right after we come West. Working them late shifts and overtime, sleeping days. And we was drinking some. No life for a kid. So . . . “ He threw out his hands and forgave himself with a smile. “We let her go.”
“Where?”
“Lessee―Mae called up the home and they come and got her. Ain’t that right, Mae?”
“Yeah,” Mae said in a dead voice. “Sure.”
I fished the picture of Prendergast out of my inside pocket and held it for Conroy to look at.
He tried to grin, frowned, then gave up and let his face fall apart like a bride’s piecrust. Mae wailed again and flopped down in a chair.
“Rings a bell, eh?” I said. “Tell me about it.”
Conroy shook his head. He looked like a sick man.
“We done nothing,” he croaked in a broken, old man’s voice. “God help us, we done nothing.”
“Threw a scare into you, eh? Why?”
“I don’t know nothing. I never seen him before.”
“You’re overplaying it, Conroy. He’s been dead two years. I want to know what your deal was.”
His mouth opened and shut. “Oh,” he said. “Yeah. Sure. I guess the guy got to me.” He faked a laugh, not successfully. “Must be getting old, nerves shot to hell.”
“You were telling me about Prendergast.”
“Aw, look, feller,” Conroy whined. “Why can’t you just go on away and leave us alone? I told you―we don’t know nothing about the girl no more.”
“Just a quiet, suburban couple enjoying a peaceful evening at home,” I said. “That the picture?”
“Right, mister. Now why don’t you just take your gun and your big smile right on out of here before I get mad and call in some law?” This in a tone of weak bluster even he didn’t believe in.
“You always greet visitors with a shotgun?”
“Like Mae told you―I was cleaning it.” Sullen now. Somehow he’d gotten his confidence back―or a part of it.
“Who were you expecting?”
The woman made one of her sounds. Conroy sneered. Maybe he thought it was a placating smile.

“Look, we don’t want a damn thing, Mae and me; only to be left alone, understand? We don’t want nothing, we don’t know nothing. We done nothing. We’re decent, retired people. We worked hard all our life.” He was working himself up into a little pale righteous rage. “Now you get out, mister!” He jerked a hand toward the door. “Go on―out!”
“What did you have to do for the furniture money, Fred?”
“Who told you about that?”
“He come here,” Mae said suddenly, in a dead voice. “He gave us the money. We didn’t have to do nothing.
Just keep quiet, was all.” She tittered in a drunken way. “And here we are, talking our fool heads off.”
“Who do you mean by ‘he,’ Mrs. Conroy?”
She shuddered and didn’t answer, didn’t look at me.
“She means Jaster―the lousy skunk,” Conroy said smoothly. “Tried to scare us. Sure, we taken the money. Why not? He said there’d be more later, maybe. But we done nothing wrong―”
“What was it you were supposed to keep quiet about?”
Conroy moved his shoulders. “The girl―what do you suppose?”
“Why?”

“Curiosity’s for rich folks, mister. Young folks, healthy folks. We could use the money, God knows. You think this place looks pretty plain, maybe. You should of seen it before.” He stopped talking suddenly and looked startled, as if he’d just remembered a cake in the oven.
“We ain’t never had nothing,” Mae said. “Only for a while there, in the war.” She started to cry silently for a change, into a wadded handkerchief.
“When did Jaster come around?”
“Year, year and a half ago,” Fred answered for her. “The first time.”
“When was the last time?”
“Not him,” Mae spoke up. “It was―”

“All right, Mae,” Fred said in a deadly tone he hadn’t used before.―She closed her mouth in mid-word and went back to her hanky. “A few days back,” he went on. “Like I said, he talked mean. Made threats. That’s how come the shotgun.”
“How did you happen to adopt the child in the first place, Conroy?”

He gave a short laugh that had all the hearty, spontaneous humor of a death rattle. “Guess you’re thinking we don’t look the type couple to be taking a kid. But we was young then. Hell, we ain’t old now―I’m fifty-five and Mae’s two years younger. You might not think it to look at her, but back then she was a pretty little piece.”
Mae sobbed.

“We hadn’t been doing too well, me and Mae. I’ll tell you, to us the war was a godsend. All of a sudden we was making money―good money. Life was good. We knew we’d been wasting it. Now we had a chance. We made up our minds to straighten up, amount to something. We went off the booze. We wanted to make a real home. We couldn’t have no kid. So we adopted one. Cute little rascal, big eyes, helpless; you know. Then we heard about better jobs on the Coast. Feller come around, signed us up right there in Tampa, paid our way out. We felt like life was opening up at last. Then one day this feller come along. Said there’d been a mix-up, we’d got his kid. He wanted her back. Said he knew he had no legal claim, but he’d pay.” Fred paused to wet his lips, his eyes shining at the golden memory. “Ten thousand, cold cash,” he whispered.
“That’s what we sold her for,” Mae said in a voice that wobbled like a flat wheel.

“Mae taken it bad,” Fred said. “Went to drinking, letting the house go.” His voice hardened. “Got to taking up with men, cheap spenders in liquor joints. I whipped her―God knows 1 whipped her. It was rough on me too. I went back on the booze. They fired me. Couldn’t hold a job. Got in trouble, got myself arrested.” He wagged his head. “I done six hard months up at Quentin. That cured me.”
“The man who took her―the one who said he was her father―”
“I never said he was the father,” Conroy said quickly. “He was the uncle. That’s what he said.”
“You believed him?”
“I believed him ten thousand dollars’ worth. Who’d pay that kind of money for a kid wasn’t nothing to them?”
“What name did he give?”
Fred looked at me squarely for the first time since he’d started talking. “I plumb forgot,” he said flatly. “And nothing’s going to make me remember any different.”
“Do you have a picture of her?”

“Oh, yes,” Mae said. “Right in the hall closet.” She scuttled around my chair and banged the door open, rummaged on the shelf, came back with a smiling studio shot of a weakly pretty woman of about thirty and a round-faced child of perhaps five. The woman could have been Mae, twenty-five years younger. The child was blonde, small featured, nothing like the picture Anglich had showed me. I put the photo in my pocket.
“And her name was Anya?”
“Anna,” Mrs. Conroy corrected. “We called her Annie.”

I stood, trying hard to remember if Jaster had said Anya, or if I had thought he had because that was what I had been expecting to hear. The gun in my hand seemed suddenly as out of place as a fire hose. I put it away.

“Well, thanks for the talk,” I said, and listened to the words fall into a silence like Bryce Canyon. I let myself out, feeling their eyes on me. My feet were loud on the walk. Somewhere the evening frogs were tuning up, a chorus of derision. I was a real nice fellow. I was proud of myself. I liked knowing me. The sleuth racket was such a lovely life. You got to meet such a nice class of people―and they got to meet you. Well, maybe we deserved each other.
I cranked up and started back to Hollywood. I got as far as Bundy before I noticed the car behind me.

It’s hard to be sure when you’re being tailed. At first I thought he was following me, then I didn’t, then I did again. I turned right onto Shetland, just above San Vicente, right again on Gretna Green. He did too. It was a small gray Volkswagen with a crumpled fender, but that didn’t necessarily mean anything. There were lots of Volkswagens, all of them small, lots of them gray, and a reasonable number with bent fenders. I speeded up and doused my lights and did a few lefts and rights and suddenly there were no more houses, just vacant lots full of sagebrush standing on their edges against a dark skyline. The sound of my engine racketed between the canyon walls. And not just my engine. The buzz of the VW got suddenly louder. Headlights went on in my rearview mirror, overhauling me fast. I put it to the floor and saw the Dead End sign in time to brake to a sliding stop with two wheels in among the manzanita and sage and tin cans. The nose of the VW was practically in my lap; its lights lit up the inside of the Olds like a night club act. They died and doors clacked and two men who were probably too small to be ex-Ram linebackers did a nice enveloping movement. Something black and deadly looking was poking in my open window: the snout of a submachine gun.

The face behind the gun had been used hard. It hadn’t been pretty to begin with, and the cut under the eye and the bruise that spread along the jaw line and the scabbed lip gave it an expendable look, as if nobody much cared anymore what happened to it. The skin was a sallow tan that hadn’t come from the sun; against it the teeth looked whiter than they were.
“Out,” a slick, tight voice said. “Vamanos, chum.” It was a Latin accent, but not Mexican. “This is a stick-up, like you hear about. Lift the feet.”
“You’re just kidding,” I said. “You wouldn’t shoot that thing around here.”

The muzzle jabbed my cheekbone and the salt sweet taste of blood spread along the edge of my tongue. The passenger side door jerked open and a gaunt face with a complexion like oatmeal and two strips of white tape across the jaw grinned at me over a big Colt revolver. I cut the engine and got out. The Cuban watched my eyes while he lifted my gun and threw it up the slope.

“In the bus,” he said. The other one came around the front of the Olds and got in the driver’s seat of the VW, closed the door on his side. I got in the back and the Cuban crowded in beside me while his partner held the Colt aimed at my head. When the stutter gun was nicely settled in my ribs the gaunt-faced man put the revolver on the seat beside him and started up, backed, gunned away. I reached up to touch the tender spot on my cheek and the gun jabbed at me.
“I thought you just wanted my gold elk’s tooth,” I said.
“You know better, gumshoe. But you might pass over the leather at that.”
“Nuts. If I reached for it you’d break a rib for me.”
“Now you’re getting smart. Ain’t the peeper getting smart, Sid?”

Sid grunted, hunched over the wheel. He did a left at the corner and covered three fast blocks past badly maintained bungalows and used cars parked in weed-grown driveways. The houses got bigger and farther apart. The road curved, rising and falling. We went fast, squealing tires, ripping through ribbons of fog in the hollows. Then we were in the foothills, climbing past fenced estates. There was a smell of the sea and of wild growth. Far away in the valley lights shone like strewn riches.
“Anywhere here is OK,” the Cuban said. It was the first time anybody had spoken in ten minutes.
“Not yet,” Sid said. He had a deep, broken voice, like trouble in the gear box. “Where they shot that picture Splendor Love something. That’s the spot.”
“Sid’s movie crazy,” the Cuban said. “He come out here to break into the acting game. Too bad they don’t make them kind of pictures no more.”
“I was in a couple pictures,” Sid said over his shoulder. “You ever see They Roll by Night?”
“I don’t think so.”
“I was what they call a extra person.”
“The peeper ain’t no movie fan,” the Cuban said. “He’s too busy poking his snoot in.”
“Errol Flynn used to live up around here,” Sid said. “Geeze, the broads that guy had.”
“Sid didn’t do so good with the broads either,” the Cuban said. “He’s only good at the one thing.”
Sid laughed. “A guy got to have a hobby,” he said.

More minutes went by. We reached the top of a rise. Sid slowed, pulled off on the shoulder under a high rock face, and cut the switch. He got out and stretched, then stood and looked in at me with no particular expression. The gun prodded me. I got out. It was a nice night. The stars shone down unconcernedly. A little breeze moved in the trees, as though it had nothing special to do.
Beyond a vertical drop on the other side of the road treetops pushed up from a canyon that looked as deep and black as a poisoned well.

The Cuban cradled the gun in his left arm, turned casually toward me, and rammed a punch at my stomach. It didn’t catch me completely asleep; I half turned fast enough to take some of the impact on my hipbone. He swore in Spanish, then laughed. While this was going on the other fellow had been easing around behind me. He grabbed me and tied up my arms in a grip like a banding machine. The Cuban, still chuckling, took aim and hit me far enough below the belt to make the sky turn bright. Even set for it, it felt like the recoil from a sixteen-inch gun. I spent a minute or two getting my spine uncurled.
“You’re a pretty tough boy,” I said, and tried not to wheeze. “What happened to your face?”
He laughed. He had a nice laugh, if you like them a little sinister.
“Maybe we don’t need to talk to you, shamus,” he said. “Maybe we’d settle for the Hunky.”
“Seems like we seen you and him together someplace,” the gaunt man said.
“Yeah, you hadn’t ought to hang out with them kind of guys,” the Cuban said thoughtfully. He put a thumb under my chin and pressed my head back. “Now, where was it we seen you together at?”
“Don’t you remember?” I said. “We starred in Andy Hardy Meets the Wolf Man.”
“A funny man,” the Cuban said, and rapped me across the face openhanded. “Skip it, peeper. We make the jokes.”
“We’re wasting time, Rosie,” Sid said. “Squeeze this monkey. Make him sing.”
“Maybe I did see that picture after all, Sid,” I said. “Frankenstein, wasn’t it? You played the left leg.”
Rosie snorted and slammed his fist into my ribs.
“Open up, peeper. Time’s getting short. We got things to do tonight.”
“Don’t let me keep you,” I said, and got the other side of the hand.

“What’s the big bimbo to you, small stuff?” the Cuban said, and slapped me half silly. “Where’s he holed up at?” He was warming up to the work now, getting the rhythm. I wasn’t hearing his words anymore, or feeling the blows. It was a big league game and I was the football. I was the track at Santa Anita, and they were running the Preakness on me. They bunched at the turn and there was a bad spill that seemed to go on for a long time and then I was lying on the ground on my back listening to a high humming sound. Somebody was kicking me in the side, just hard enough to make me grunt. I rolled away from that and got to all fours. Don’t ask me why. It just seemed like the thing to do.
“The peeper likes it,” the Cuban said. “He wants to talk about the Hunky now, on account of he likes it so good.”

I stood, with no more waste motion than three amputees pitching a tent in a high wind. The ground wanted to sway, but I held it firmly in place with my feet well spraddled. It would have been a good time to keep my mouth shut, but I said, “You must be losing your stuff. Young mothers hit harder than that when they burp the baby.”
He chewed some air and then stooped swiftly and put the Thompson gun down on a flat rock at the edge of the road.

“I show you some two-handed work,” he said. I started to slide sideways and the gaunt man made a grab for me. I stamp-kicked him below the knee and turned just in time to catch a haymaker on the side of the head that sent me spinning into orbit.

This time I was a lot longer swimming up out of it. At least it seemed a lot longer; I didn’t actually look at my watch. There was dirt and bits of grass in my mouth. I lay doggo and listened to them talking. The Cuban was in favor of breaking my arms and legs and rolling me over the side. Sid thought it would be better to take me back to town and squeeze me in private, at leisure. I opened one eye, saw pebbly ground, stiff weeds, the butt of the submachine gun six feet away. The Cuban was standing just beyond it, facing the gaunt man. I couldn’t see his eyes. He might have been watching me like a worm watching a robin―or maybe not. There are risks in any business. It was time for me to take one of mine.

I snapped my feet under me and lunged. The Cuban was quick. He spun like a cat in mid-air, reached the gun just as my outstretched hand touched it, sent it clattering off the rock. His own grab sent it over the edge. He yelled and threw himself after it. I came up in a groggy charge and bounced off the gaunt man’s knees and dived over the side. Foliage ripped at me. I skidded twenty feet, ricocheted off a tree trunk, did another three yards end over end, and fetched up hard against rock. I lay still―very still. I wasn’t thinking very clearly, but I was thinking clearly enough for that.
I listened to them snarl at each other while the Cuban beat the brush for his toy. After a while doors slammed and the car went away. I gave it another ten minutes, then started down.

I came out on a road fifty feet below. It was a twenty-minute hike back to Mulholland. I got a lift with a rabbit-faced fellow in a pickup truck that smelled of chicken manure. If he believed the story I gave him about missing a bus he didn’t say so.

He dropped me at a cab stand in Beverly Glen. My car was still parked where I’d seen it last. Nobody took a shot at me as I got in. I drove home and took some of my medicine and chewed a couple of aspirin and stuck tape over the cut on my cheek and turned in for one of those long, restful sleeps you read about.

There was nothing in the morning paper about Jaster, or about a stiff named Carlotti being found in an unused warehouse off Alamitos. I treated myself to an extra cup of coffee and a long hot shower to take some of the ache out of me.

It was a little after nine when I shook open the lock on the office door. I sorted the mail into the wastebasket. The envelope with the key was at the bottom of the stack. I put it in the safe along with my gilt-edged securities and opened the alley window to let in the bracing morning smog, firmly rejecting the idea of uncapping the office bottle at such an hour. Well, maybe just one. You deserve it, Shaw.

I made faces at myself in the mirror over the sink while I rinsed out the glass. The Cuban was a neat worker: no braises showed. The cut on the cheek was mostly on the inside. Under my belt it was a different story. I’d think of Rosie for a week, every time I tucked my shirttail in.

Back on station with a heel on the desk I dialed the number of police headquarters, told them where to look for a stutter gun, and hung up before the desk sergeant had a chance to get tough. That tired me out. I poured another dram of my cure-all and was just reaching for it when the phone rang.
“Mr. Shaw,” a cool, unhurried female voice said. “This is Ellen Prendergast. I wonder if I might see you this morning.”
“You might―if you’re in the right places.” I said.
“I’m sorry about the other morning,” she said sharply. “But you had no right to upset Mother, you know.”
“Sorry, Miss Prendergast, I had no reason to think what I was going to say to her would upset her.”
“Just what did you tell her, Mr. Shaw?”
“Maybe tell is the wrong word. It was more of a question.”
“What question?”
“Tell you what: come on down and I’ll ask you the same question.”
“I have no intention of being interrogated, Mr. Shaw,” she said firmly.
“What was it you wanted to see me about, Miss Prendergast?”
“Will you be in your office at one o’clock?”
“Better make it before lunch. I may feel like a nap.”
“If you’re trying to prove that you can be very rude, consider the point made. I’ll be there at ten. Good-by.”
I said good-by to a dial tone and went into a huddle with my bottle. The phone jangled again. It was Lacey, from the sheriff’s office.
“Hiya, kid,” he said. “How’s the private war on crime?”
“You sound too cheerful for a cop,” I told him. “You must not know all the facts.”
“Ain’t it the truth, boy?” he said, and yawned into the phone. “Say, you do any good for that Lou Anglich I sent around?”
“Not much. He’s counting clouds if he thinks I can pick up a trail twenty-five years old―if there’s any trail to pick up.”
“Yeah―well, I figured you could make an honest buck letting him down easy. By the way, where’s he staying?”
“He said he’d call me.”
Lacey sighed.
“Sure. Well, let me know if he rings in.”
“Check.”

“Well, keep the nose clean, boy. Oh―I almost forgot. The L.A. prowlies answered a squeal last night and got to poking around and turned up a stiff. An out-of-town hot rod name of Carlotti from Tampa, same as Anglich. Coincidence, huh?”
“It’s a big town.”
“Yeah, I should of thought of that.”

I hung up and started to pour and suddenly the smell of the stuff was gagging. I put it away and thought about ham and eggs, but that wasn’t what I wanted either. I dug an old brier out of the drawer and stuffed it and lit it. It tasted like shaved caribou antler. I knocked it out in the ash tray and the outer office buzzer sounded. There was the usual pause, then a sharp nose poked around the edge of the connecting door and a sharp face followed it. Sharp eyes probed the corners of the room, the ceiling, the wastebasket, came to rest on my feet, propped on the desk. He came on into the room, a birdlike little man on the arthritic side of fifty in a pinkish tan suit that was neat if not too clean. His yellowish shirt was bunched at the collar by a tie that hadn’t quite made up its mind to be purple. His shoes were a tawny ocher, a little curled but brightly polished. He held a brown woven-straw hat with a paisley band in both hands, as if he was getting ready to take a bite out of the brim.

I watched him come across the room. He slapped the hat on his knees and sat down without waiting to be asked, not forgetting to hoist the cuffs a bit to save the crease. He leaned forward and crossed his legs, laced his hands over a chest like a starved sparrow’s, and said, “Heard from Jaster lately?” He still hadn’t looked at me higher than the ankles.
“Who’s he?”
He nodded and smiled comfortably, flicked a look past my face, got interested in last year’s calendar on the wall behind me.

“We used to do a little business together,” he said in a reminiscent tone. “A.P. was a guy to know the angles―or thought he did.” He opened the corner of his mouth and wagged his head and made a sound like a ripe fruit hitting the pavement. I didn’t say anything. My caller gave me the benefit of another fast glance. He uncrossed his legs and crossed them the other way.

“There’s some loose ends,” he said. I waited. He uncrossed his legs and crossed them back the way they’d been in the first place. He looked down at the edge of the desk and let his look travel across and climb my shirt as far as my chin. He leaned forward and spoke to my chin:
“You know about the bump.”
“What was that name again?” I said. He didn’t act as if he heard me.
“Like I said, I’m winding up his affairs. As a favor to a former associate, like.”
“Wouldn’t he love that―if he knew.”
“There was a memo on the material you developed for him,” he said solemnly. “I’ll take it now.”
I said, “Yeah?” and picked up the letter opener and poked my thumb with it. It hurt. I tossed it back on the blotter.
“What was it?” he said. “Fifty bucks?” He made a tentative motion as if to reach for a wallet inside his coat, watching my ear attentively.
“What do I do for the fifty?”
“Turn over what you got,” he said quickly.
“On what?”
He thought that over; his eyes checked the corners of the room, came back to my chin. He looked a little hurt, like a drama coach listening to the star pupil fluff a line.
“You got wrong ideas,” he said. “I don’t mess around, Shaw. I got no time for the games.”
I fingered my ribs and ran my tongue along the gash on the inside of my cheek.
“You know a Cuban named Rosie?”
His head jerked and he almost looked at me. One of his eyes was slightly out of line, with a blurry pupil.
“He’s teamed with a worker named Sid,” I told him. “Nice fellows. You’d like them. What was your name again?”
He came out of the chair as if I’d just shunted a couple of hundred volts through it. His lips were curled back from his teeth.
“Wise guy,” he said, and had to stop to swallow. “I’m representing my client, see? Don’t try to make anything more of it.” He backed toward the door.
“Aren’t you going to leave a card?” I said. “Suppose I want to call you?”

“Forget it,” he said emphatically, and made a downward swipe with his hand. “To me it’s routine, I’m trynna clean up some loose ends for a pal. So you don’t want to cooperate, so OK. No hard feelings.” He started his fade around the edge of the door.
“You can leave the fifty bucks with the girl in the outer office,” I said.
“What fifty bucks?”
“That’s the wrong line. You should have said, ‘what girl?’ ”
He made a noise like skinning a snake and left at a trot. I picked up the dead pipe and poked it around in my jaw and wondered who he was and where he fitted into the picture, if there was a picture.

All the interview had told me was that Rosie and Sid hadn’t worked for Jaster―or if they did. the little man didn’t know it. But he knew them and was smart enough to be scared of them. Which left the question of who they did work for. Somehow I didn’t see them in business for themselves. Maybe I should have lifted him by the heels and shaken some facts out of him. Somehow the idea didn’t excite me. I felt filled with a vast inertia. I thought about Anglich parked in his hotel room, taped to the eyes. I thought about the elderly Mrs. Prendergast and her winning way with a hard-working snooper. I spared a couple of thoughts for a man named Jaster, scuffling for the next dirty buck on his way to the morgue. I thought these and other thoughts, none of them elevating. At ten sharp Ellen Prendergast walked in.

She looked cool, calm, and unhurried. She was wearing a plain suit in a rough dark blue material that was a remote and very elegant relative of what they bag potatoes in. There was a froth of white lace at her throat. Her hair was swept down in a smooth curve over her forehead and fixed with a little black bow in front. I climbed out of my chair while she pulled off a Navy blue kid glove and gave the office a quick sweep with her eyes that made me suddenly conscious of a certain amount of dust and a cobweb or two.
“It’s the cleaning lady’s year off,” I said. “Just a minute while I wipe off a chair.”
“Please don’t be offensive, Mr. Shaw,” she said in a soft voice, and sat down quickly on the edge of my guest chair. “I didn’t come here to fight with you.”
“Oh, I’ll bet you’d be willing to go a couple of rounds,” I said, and leered across the curled blotter at her. She stared steadily back at me.
“I don’t know why you’re putting on this ridiculous act, Mr. Shaw. Is it supposed to have some particular effect on me?”
“Doesn’t it?”
“I’ve apologized for being angry with you. Do you really dislike me so much?”

I looked at her and then past her out the window at the brick wall I used for a view. I sat up straight in my chair and said, “Let’s take it again from the top. My apologies, Miss Prendergast. In what way can I be of service?”
She gave me a carefully measured smile and took off the other glove. Maybe that meant she was staying.

“There’s really nothing. It’s just that . . . things are difficult at home now, for everyone. We’ve never really recovered from Daddy’s death. Mother is balanced on a very delicate equilibrium. Even Mianne . . . “ She frowned a little and nibbled her lip.
“What about Mianne?” I said it casually, the old family confidant inquiring after the problem sister.
“She gives the appearance―to a stranger―of being completely self-confident. But inside . . . she’s very sensitive. All this has upset her more than she shows.”
I wanted to ask her what she meant by “all this,” but instead I nodded and poked in my cold pipe with a paper clip.
“What I mean, Mr. Shaw, is that anything that interferes with our routine―anything at all―tends to upset the whole household out of all proportion.”
“So you thought you’d drop around and tell me to go do my sleuthing elsewhere.” I gave her a little twinkle along with the cheery smile.
“The other day you were showing pictures, asking questions. I don’t know what it is you expect to learn. And it really doesn’t matter. I realize that you have to earn a living―”
“But why couldn’t I have picked a cleaner racket―like pumping out septic tanks.”
“I thought we agreed not to be nasty.”
“Did your mother tell you what we talked about?”
She turned a little pink around the ears. “I heard a part of it.”
“Her part or mine?”

“I told you Mother isn’t well―not herself!” she snapped. “You can’t hold an invalid responsible for . . . for . . . “ She trailed off. She suddenly looked like a very tired and unhappy girl, trying hard to keep it a secret.
“Sure,” I said, “Let’s go back to where you were telling me to lay off the job.”
She looked at me coldly. “Someone is paying you, no doubt, to probe into our affairs.”
“Oh, you have affairs,” I said and looked sappy. I felt sappy. I was riding a girl I hardly knew, and most of what I knew of her I liked. All of a sudden the rye-glow was gone. I shook my head.
“You know something?” I said. “It’s not you I don’t like, Miss Prendergast.”

“Really? I’m gratified. I came here to tell you that I’m prepared to compensate you for whatever loss you may incur by sparing us your attentions.” She lifted a crisp little blue bag and snapped it open in a brisk, no-nonsense way. “Would five hundred dollars be about right?”
“Right for what?” I snarled. “You got a couple bodies you want buried? I get two fifty apiece for strangers. My friends will run you a little more money.”
She stared at me with her hand poised half in and half out of the purse. “Something’s bothering you,” she said.

“Who, me?” I yelped. “What would be bothering me? I lead a fine, full life. I get to go out and mingle with the uppercrust, not to mention the lower crust; people I hardly know invite me along on picnics in the foothills; my colleagues consult me regularly for the latest on everything from where to have a boil lanced to the best place to cool down after a murder or two. Cops call me to find out if I’ve hidden any bodies lately. Nickel grifters with terminal halitosis and beautiful mysterious spinsters alike clamor to press money on me. And afterwards I get to go home and stretch out among my first editions and my prize begonias and my Ming chamber pots and plan my next caper. It’s a million laughs, baby, don’t ever doubt it.”
She took her hand out of her purse and gave me a remote look, like a desk clerk listening to a complaint about slow room service.
“What do you mean―mysterious?”
I breathed out. I wouldn’t call it a sigh; I just breathed out. “Don’t count that one,” I said. “It just slipped out.”
“You needn’t speak to me as though I were one of your . . . your . . . “
“Go ahead,” I said. “I’m two insults up on you.”
“And I didn’t come here to insult you, either,” she said, as if finishing a sentence I’d interrupted.
“Why did you come, Miss Prendergast?”
“I’ve told you―”
“You fanned a lot of hot air about the delicate constitutions of the Prendergasts,” I said. “You left out Uncle Frank. How is Uncle Frank? Still keeping a tight rein on the Prendergast fortunes?”
“What in the world do you mean by that?” she said tightly.
“Do I mean something by that? Maybe I do, now that you mention it. To tell you the truth I got the feeling Uncle Frank didn’t fit into the scene too well, if you know what I mean.”
“I haven’t the remotest idea,” she said, with a frost like Scott’s last camp on the ice cap.
“You get along well with your uncle?”
“I can’t conceive that it’s even remotely any of your concern, Mr. Shaw.”
“Still, you’re listening. Maybe there’s something you came here to tell me that you haven’t gotten around to yet.”
She jumped up. Well, she didn’t really jump; but she stood up pretty fast.
“I should have known better than to expect you to have any understanding at all of . . . of what . . . “ She stood there frowning at me frowning at her and her unfinished sentence.

I took a deep breath. “I’d like to understand,” I said. “But I’m not getting a lot of help. I came out to the house and showed a couple of snapshots and asked a couple of nosy questions―and got razzed plenty for it. I haven’t been near the Prendergasts since. If hush was what you wanted you were getting all of it I had to give. Instead of letting it go at that, here you are over on my side of town mentioning a reasonably large sum of money for me to get lost. Tell me how I’m supposed to understand that, Miss Prendergast. I’ll do my best to cooperate.”
She sat down slowly, as if her knees wouldn’t hold her weight.

“Uncle Frank said . . . “ She paused and looked thoughtful. “He said you’d been . . . prying into matters. That you were obviously trying to . . . to dig up some dirt. He warned us not to tell you anything.”
“Did he say just what dirt it was I was digging up?”
“You speak as though there were actually something . . . discreditable to discover about us. Well, Mr. Shaw, I can assure you―”
“At the time of your father’s death, Miss Prendergast―where was Uncle Frank?”
“Why, he was staying with us.”
“Had he been with you long?”
“A week or two, I suppose.”
“Not a year?”
“Certainly not. He just arrived for a visit from the East. After Daddy’s funeral, he stayed on to help . . . “
“And stayed and stayed. But I guess his business back East knows how to run itself.”
“He has no business in the East―as far as I know,” she amended.
“What does he live on?”
“He’s quite well off; his funds are invested, of course. Recently he’s complained about the market being bad, and―but I have no intention of discussing my uncle’s financial affairs.”
“How much is he into you for? The family, I mean.”
She opened her mouth to be indignant but instead she closed it and gave me a level look. “You’re quite clever, Mr. Shaw. I underestimated you.”
“How much? Fifty grand? Not less, if I know my Uncle Frank.”
“I see he was right about your prying.”
“Just guessing. You see a lot of him as a kid?”
“He visited quite often, yes. After all, Father’s only brother . . . “
“Miss Prendergast―is there any doubt that he is your uncle?”
She looked startled, then smiled vaguely and shook her head. “Not the least in the world. If you’d known Daddy you’d know why. They were very much alike―physically, at least.”
I opened the desk drawer and got out the photograph of the man in the linen suit and passed it across. “When was this taken, would you say?”
She studied it, shook her head slowly. “Years ago, of course. During the war, perhaps. Why do you ask?” She handed it back.
“Do you have any baby pictures of yourself, Miss Prendergast?”
“No―none at all. Daddy hated cameras. I was sixteen before I had a portrait taken. I remember I was frightened to death.”
I put away the snap and got out the one of the blonde-haired child. “Then you wouldn’t recognize this?”
She pursed her lips at the picture and looked up sharply at me.
“Am I supposed to?”
“Does it ring a bell?”
“None whatever. Where did you get it?”
“I’m afraid that’s privileged information, Miss Prendergast. Could it be your sister?”
“I suppose it could be almost anyone. Do you mind telling me why you’re asking these questions?”
I took the picture back. “On behalf of a client. It seems he had a daughter, a long time ago. Now he wants to do something for her. There’s a little money in it. Of course there’d have to be proof.”
Ellen looked puzzled. “Proof―of what?”
“That the party in question was the one my client had in mind.”
“But―this is ridiculous. My parents―”
“You’ve heard of adoption, Miss Prendergast.”
Her face went stiff as a jammed lock. “Are you saying . . . that . . . “
“I’m not saying anything. I’m asking. I take it the answer is no.”
Some of her color was coming back. “I’ve never heard anything so fantastic,” she said in a rather faint voice.
“What about Mianne?”
“Nothing about Mianne! I’ll thank you to leave my sister―and myself―out of your grubby little investigations, Mr. Shaw.” She stood up and grabbed her bag off the desk and glared at me.
“Sure. Any time you want me to ignore you some more just drop around and remind me.”
She snorted in a refined way and turned to go. At the door she paused and looked back almost sadly. “I don’t really dislike you, Mr. Shaw. I think perhaps I should―but I don’t.”
She went on out. I listened to her heels clicking in the corridor until they died away.

I paid a buck eighty-five for a mild case of indigestion at the corner beanery and then drove over to Cigale. The Penguin Lounge was a black and white and glass block affair with the slightly seedy look even the best of bars have in broad daylight. The plastic penguin over the deep-set doors looked hot and tired, like I felt. There was a carved screen just inside to confuse the customers. I made it around that into the cool and the dark and groped my way back past a long bar with a padded edge to a table well off the aisle. There were a few early drinkers on hand, just getting settled down to the afternoon’s business. A waiter with a face that had seen everything and liked very little of it came over and took my order for a Bacardi cocktail. The clock over the bar said 2 p.m.

A plump man in a double-breasted suit with the coat unbuttoned and a hungry little blonde hanging on his arm went back to the jukebox and clacked quarters. The walls trembled and began oozing “Deep Purple.” I was on my third Bacardi when she arrived.

I watched her come back through the gloom, a big, healthy girl with hair as glossy as a mare’s mane, walking with a self-assured stride, thighs curving the gray skirt, head up, chest out under the fitted gray jacket. She grinned at me and slid into a chair and breathed, “Hi, I’m late.”

The heads that had turned to watch her turned reluctantly back to what they’d been doing. The waiter almost stepped on his own foot getting over to the table. She gave him the tail end of the smile and ordered a Gibson.
“I want to apologize again for the other day,” she said. “Mother’s so unpredictable. But she seemed so tranquil, I thought―well, that she’d enjoy a visitor.”
“I should have listened to Uncle Frank,” I said, “How is the old boy?”
“Oh, fine.” She seemed to be waiting for me to go on.
“He and your father must have been pretty close.”
She looked thoughtful. “Why do you say that, Mr. Shaw?”
“It’s not every brother who’d step in the way Uncle Frank has.”
“I suppose not.” She frowned a little. “Its odd―but I never even knew I had an uncle until he came West two years ago. Daddy never spoke of him.”
I nodded casually. “Did you ever meet a man named Jaster, Miss Prendergast?”
She shook her head. “No.”
“Any of your uncle’s old friends from back East ever come around?”
“Why―no, not that I know of.”
“What line of work was he in―before he retired, I mean?”
“I really don’t know. Some sort of investment business, I believe.”
“Any connection with your father’s shipping lines?”
“I don’t think so.”
“There’s a lot of shipping out of Tampa. Your father have any interests there?”

“I suppose so. He owned shares in many companies.” She smiled and wrinkled her forehead at me. “I don’t see just where all these questions are leading, Mr. Shaw. I agreed to talk to you―I felt I owed you that―but―”
“I’m just making conversation, Miss Prendergast.”
“Is there something . . . about Uncle Frank . . . that . . . “
“You mean did he run away with the buttons off the mayor’s vest? Not as far as I know, Miss Prendergast.”
She put her hand over mine. It was warm and soft and as provocative as a bare leg under the blanket. “Please―call me Mianne.”
“I’d better not,” I said. “It might get to be a habit. What would the servants say?”
She laughed and moved her hand. Mine felt cold and lonely with it gone; I used it to lift my glass for another swallow of my poison.
“You showed Mother a picture of a child,” she said in the same light tone as the laugh. “Who was it?”
“She didn’t say.”
She shook her head. “Mr. Shaw, you’re a tease. What made you show it to her?”
“I thought perhaps she could identify it.”
“And the other picture―the one of Daddy. Was there supposed to be some connection?”
“I don’t really know that either, Miss Prendergast. I’m just a fellow groping in the dark, as usual.”
“Groping for what, Mr. Shaw?”
“Have you ever been in Florida, Miss Prendergast?”

“Never. I prefer Mexico. I have a little house there, at San Miguel de Allende.” She was still smiling nicely, but her voice had taken on a touch of remoteness, like a credit manager hearing there’d be a slight delay in the next installment.
“Do you mind telling me why you’re prying, Mr. Shaw?”
“I have a client, Miss Prendergast. He came to me with a problem. A legitimate problem, it seemed to me. I’m trying to help him with it. So far I haven’t gotten much of anywhere.”
“But―what does this client’s problem have to do with the Prendergast family?”
“When I know that, maybe his problem will be solved.”
“That sounds rather ominous, somehow.”

“Why should it? The Prendergast family are all fine people, aren’t they? There’s the invalid mother and the two charming―and unmarried―daughters. And the hired man. And of course, there’s Uncle Frank.”
“Do I get the impression you don’t like Uncle Frank?”
“I don’t like him, I don’t dislike him, Miss Prendergast. I hardly know the man.”
“Surely you don’t think . . . ?” She crinkled her nose at me; the tone was light, but her eyes watched me over the rim of the glass.
“I don’t know anything that would send him to jail, Miss Prendergast. Should I?”
The smile faded just a trifle. “Don’t be offensive, please, Mr. Shaw. It’s not at all necessary.”

“How should I be, Miss Prendergast? Here I am, a hardened old gumshoe, scuffling to get a crop out of some pretty barren ground; and here you are, as luscious a peach as ever hung out of reach. I like sitting here looking at you, and I like having you pat my hand; but I’m not kidding myself there’s a big future in our relationship.”

She arched her eyebrows and did something to her eyes that seemed to make the pupils get big and dark. “Where did you ever get the idea that younger women didn’t like tall, tough men with cool gray eyes?” she said in a husky, low voice. “A man’s face is never really beautiful until it has some experience behind it.”
“Is that what you came out to tell me today?”
“Why shouldn’t it be―Joe? I’m over twenty-one―well over. I’m single, with no ties. Is there some reason I shouldn’t meet you―for personal reasons?”
“What about my wife and four kids in Azusa?”
She shook her head chidingly. “Not Azusa. Hollywood. The Cheshire, on Fountain. No wife, no children, no pets allowed. Are you a misanthropist, Joe Shaw?”
“You’ve been doing a little snooping on your own.”
“You have a patent on it, Mr. Shaw?” All this patter still with the intimate little smile, the smile that said the words didn’t matter, that what we had between us surmounted the barrier of language.
“Why haven’t you married, Mianne?”
A casual wave of that soft, deft hand. “Why buy a bull,” she murmured, “when beef’s so cheap?”
“Uh-uh,” I said. “Out of character. You should have said, ‘The right man hasn’t asked me.’”
“You’re blushing, Mr. Shaw. Do I shock you?”
“I’ve heard about the sexual revolution,” I said. “I still think chasing them down is half the fun.”
“And I preempted your masculine prerogative by making the first pass. Tsk.” She flicked a slim finger playfully at my chin. “It won’t happen again.”
“Seen Ellen lately?” I said. She paused, all over, like a stop-action film clip. Then her hand finished its wave. She sipped her drink, put it back, centering it carefully on the coaster.
“At breakfast. Why? Or is that an undiplomatic question?”
“Just wondering. Nice girl, Miss Ellen. Who’s the adopted one, you or her?”
She tilted her head, like a robin listening for a worm. “The . . . ?”
“Adopted. A-d-o-p-t-e-d.”
“What a curious idea. Is that why you were showing a picture of a child? You don’t think . . . that my father . . . that―”

“Go ahead, say it. You’re the emancipated girl of today, remember? That your old man fathered a bastard. No, Miss Prendergast. That wasn’t it. But it’s interesting to see the way your mind is running.”
She looked at me thoughtfully, not to say coldly. Cold was a way Miss Mianne could never be.
“You’re going out of your way to be unpleasant, Joe. Why? You’re really very nice. Is there something you’re hoping to surprise from me by making me angry with you?”
“What did you have in mind?”
She laughed. “I like to see a man who’s good at his work,” she said. “You’re very good. Nothing I’ve said has really affected you, has it?”

I didn’t answer that one. She didn’t wait for an answer. “Perhaps you think a woman with a healthy body and reasonable looks and youth and adequate money has everything,” she said softly. “You’d be wrong to think that, Joe. Such a woman has perhaps less chance than the average to find what a woman wants. The men I meet are spoiled darlings―or they’re someone else’s rejects, the veterans of half a dozen marital disasters―or they’re jackals, hovering around the edges for the scraps from someone else’s table. Sometimes they’re openly after the money. That kind are almost a relief; at least their motives are uncomplicated. It isn’t often that one meets a man who’s none of these things―a man untarnished and unafraid. I saw that in you. Can you blame me for wanting to warm myself at your fire?” She stood, not hurriedly but with finality.
“Thank you for the drink, Mr. Shaw.” She moved off, gracefully, regally―giving me plenty of time to hurry after her and stumble over my apologies.

I didn’t pick up the option. I watched her go―along with the rest of the barflies. A sort of sigh passed over the room after she was gone. In the silence the laugh of the little blonde scraped like a fingernail on a blackboard.

It had been an interesting day with the Prendergast girls. Miss Ellen had come along to the office and asked me to go play on another corner. Miss Mianne had staged her play more artfully, with due attention to fighting and background music. But the messages had been the same: Lay off, Mr. Shaw. Get interested in something else.

I dug my picture gallery out of an inside pocket and lined them on the edge of the table: Little Anya, with her button nose and solemn black eyes. Little Annie, all blonde curls and innocence. And the young Harvey Prendergast, standing against the high board fence.
Something caught my eye. I blinked and it was still there. Or maybe not. Maybe it was just the light. Or my imagination.
I finished my rum and went out on the hot, bare sidewalk and took another look at the photo. It still said the same thing.
The afternoon seemed to be waiting for something to happen. I got in my car and headed for Mayfair Heights.

The gardener wasn’t on duty today. The Jag and the Caddie were out visiting somewhere. The house had that still look that houses get when nobody’s home. I parked in the same spot as last time and used the same flagstones to get to the front door. As I reached for the bell I saw that the door was standing open half an inch. I pressed the button anyway, and heard some chimes go off in the middle distance. I gave it half a minute and dinged the chimes again. Nobody came hurrying to give me the swift brush. I leaned on the door sort of accidentally and it swung open a foot or so. That gave me a view of the front hall with the paintings. Without much intention on my part I was sliding in past the edge of the door. Light filtered down from some stained-glass strips above dark wood paneling. To the right an open archway gave on a vista of pale blue and fawn oriental rug. A similar arch on the left showed me books on dark shelves. Sixty seconds of standing with my ear fine-tuned netted me a minute’s worth of silence. I looked along the hall and thought about backing quietly out the way I’d come in, but somehow my feet started along toward the back of the house.

Halfway back, the hall widened for the staircase that swept down from the right. The white handrail glowed in the dimness. At the foot of the steps a heap of chiffon lay like a discarded gown dropped by Cinderella on her way home from the ball. Except that this gown still had somebody in it. Somebody hardly big enough to disturb the graceful folds of the cloth. Somebody with a face like yesterday’s gardenias, the coiffure still unmussed. The pale violet eyes were half open, the bloodless mouth almost smiling, like someone hearing a faint song from long ago.

I let out a long breath and snaked the Luger out from under my arm and did some more of my listening. Upstairs a board creaked. Then more silence. I went around the body on the floor and put a foot on the blue runner and the step creaked under my foot. That made two creaks, one mine and one the other fellow’s. Or maybe not. Old frame houses creak a lot, even without murderers sneaking around in them. I went up gun first, leaning sideways to look up the stairs ahead of me. On the landing I rested and filtered some more dead air for nonexistent noises. Down below, Mrs. Prendergast lay, looking no bigger than a dropped handkerchief. I tried hard to remember whether anyone had said she was bedridden. Maybe I’d just assumed it. Maybe she’d started down the stairs for a stroll in the garden and fallen all by herself. But I couldn’t see her being by herself. There hadn’t been enough vitality left in that fragile frame to light a flashlight. She’d have had a nurse to hold her arm and help her over the rough spots: careful, Mrs. P., take it easy, Mrs. P., now let’s just sit here in the sun awhile and rest, shall we, Mrs. P.?

But there was nobody with her now. She’d taken that last trip all alone―or had she? Maybe the nurse had just stepped out for an afternoon paper or a fresh carton of weeds, and would be back any minute to get hysterical and scream for the police and swear she’d seen me climbing the trellis on her way out and had thought nothing of it at the time.

Nuts. It didn’t make sense. Ambulatory or otherwise, the lady wouldn’t have been alone in the house. Ergo, the hypothetical companion had lost his or her head and run from the scene of the accident―or it hadn’t been an accident.

You’re doing great, Shaw. The situation is yielding to the incisive Shaw analysis. Either she was alone or with somebody. We’ve established that much. Anything more you’d like to know before you shove off for the office?
Upstairs a board creaked. I got a good grip on my back teeth and went up.

Nobody shot at me. I went along a wide corridor carpeted in blue to match the stairs. The tables at each side of the hall had fresh gladiolus in tall pale blue pots. The doors on either side of the tables were closed. The second door on the right was Mrs. Prendergast’s room. For some reason, that seemed to be the place to look. I soft-footed along to it, put an ear against it, heard my pulse whispering back at me. I tried the big polished brass knob; it turned; I threw the door back and came through in a rush. Still no shot. Two balls, no strikes. So far just the one hit in the ball game―over the fence and out of the park.
The big bed was a little mussed, the coverlet turned back, a slight depression in the big pillows. I went over and touched them. Not warm, not cold. Nothing in that for you, Shaw.

Nothing in the room seemed to be disarranged. There were plenty of drawers and closets for an enterprising detective to poke through, if he had a few hours to kill. I settled for opening the closet doors. Nobody jumped out at me from among the frilled negligees and robes. I saw no dresses, no coats, no street shoes. To an acute thinker like me that might mean Mrs. P. didn’t get out much. She’d get out even less, now.

That wasn’t a nice thought. I didn’t like having it but it was too late now. I got out a handkerchief and wiped my upper lip and the doorknob and went back out in the hall and wiped that knob. Nothing like watching the details. If somebody walked in now there’d be nothing to prove I’d been there except me and my shy smile. I listened for any more creaks that might be getting ready to happen, then went back down the stairs. Mrs. P. was still there. She hadn’t moved.
Somewhere at the back of the house there was a sharp thump, as if someone had kicked a chair. I felt my lips getting tight over my teeth.

There was a choice of two routes, left, through the dining room, or straight ahead to a swinging door. I took the direct way, hit the door with my shoulder, crossed six feet of polished tiles, and slammed against a stainless steel counter that ran down the center of the long kitchen. My head bonged a hanging pot. Behind me, somebody moved; I threw myself sideways and something that felt like a barrel stave with a nail in it glanced off my skull and almost tore my ear off. I was down on the tiles trying to loop the loop with my eyes full of pain tears and a fire raging out of control on the side of my head. A low, bouncing grounder into foul territory, Shaw. Feet clattered; or something clattered. I rolled, fetched up against a counter, swam up, and saw a blurry figure outlined against the back door. I blinked hard and the door banged. The counter was between me and it. By the time I made the run around right end and could see a little there was nothing to see except some empty lawn. An engine started up somewhere, maybe next door, backed swiftly with a snarl, gunned off and away. I felt my ear. It was still there, which surprised me. There was quite a bit of blood. It hurt bad enough to make me regret my lunch all over again.

It took me five minutes to find the cooking sherry on a back shelf. I took a few ounces from the neck and then used some paper towels to make a cold compress for my ear. Some of the fire began to go out of it. There was a little blood on my coat, not much.
I used the white telephone on the wall beside the swinging door to call the police.

They came through the front door and ten feet inside before they stopped and gave the walls, the floor, me, and a hatstand the clammy eye. They weren’t Homicide dicks, just a couple of plainclothes boys from the local substation. One of them was a moose-faced fellow named Pincus whom I’d met once or twice before on similar occasions. He’d bought himself a new hat since then, a little black affair with a one-inch brim that made him look like a lobotomy case. He took it off, exposing a lot of freckled bald dome and slapped it on his leg.

“You the guy called in?” he said, and shouldered past me. His voice was one that had blown the foam off a lot of beers in its time. He was checking the ceiling now. His partner went on along the hall and said, “Ha! Here’s the stiff, Ed.”
Pincus put his hat back on and settled it front and rear.
“You got to excuse Gunwal,” he said, and grinned. “He’s still kind of new on the job. Let’s go back.”
We walked back to where Gunwal was staring down at the body. That made three of us staring down at the body.
“You know her?” Pincus said.
“Mrs. Prendergast. The widow of―”
“Skip the bio. I checked the address before we came out. You found her how?”
“The front door was open. There she was.”
Gunwal looked back along the hall. “Wait a minute,” he said. “This spot is invisible from the front door.”

I didn’t say anything. Pincus smiled. It made him look like a sliced pie. “He didn’t say he seen it from the front door, Hal.” He crinkled the smile at me. “You know the Prendergasts pretty good, do you, bub?”
“I’ve met them.”
“Yeah. And you come out here today, why?”
“On a business matter, not a social call―if that’s what you’re getting at.”

“You surprise me, shamus. Yeah, I know you. I seen you around before with your nose in where it would of been better off out. So you don’t drop around socially to split a pot of tea with the Prendergast family. What business, could a guy ask?”
“I wanted to see Frank Prendergast.”
“Hal―you ever heard of any Frank Prendergast?”

Gunwal twitched his mouth. He had a thin, solemn face and lips that almost met over some neglected teeth. “I think the guy is ribbing us, Ed. Harvey, the old guy was. Or Henry. And there’s a couple daughters. Who’s this Frank?”
“The brother,” I said. “Of Harvey, not the girls. He was staying here.”
“Oh, he was, huh? Hal, check that. Still got the ticket for the rod, shamus?”
I got out my wallet and showed him my permit. He didn’t look at it.
“OK, so you come out and the door is open and you come in for a little look-see while the folks are away. I’m guessing the folks were away―all but the lady of the house, that is. Right, bub?”
“That’s the way it looked.”
“Who’s been gnawing your ear, bub?”
“I didn’t get a good look.”
“Tell me about it, pal.”
“I thought I heard somebody upstairs. I went up, but I didn’t see anybody. When I came back down I heard sounds in the kitchen. I went back there and got beaned from behind.”
“Not good enough, bub. Not by a country mile. Try it again, and this time leave in all the parts you left out.”
“I told you what happened, Sergeant. I don’t like it much better than you do―maybe not as much.”
“Let’s have that description again, you,” Gunwal said roughly. “That’s what you guys are good at, ain’t it? How tall was the guy? What kind of suit? How old? Spit it out, mister. I want details!”

“OK―here goes. He was six-four in his sock feet, two hundred twenty pounds, red hair going bald, green eyes, a diagonal scar at the left corner of his mouth, and he’ll be fifty-one on his next birthday. And I almost forgot: he was smoking a brier pipe and leading a lobster on a leash―or was that Beaudelaire?”
Gunwal stared at me. “Hey―that sounds like Chief Walters―all but that crack about the lobster.”
“Sure, ham it up, cutie,” Pincus said. “Who’s this Beaudelaire?”
“Ed, I think this smart aleck needs a good punch in the joke box.”
Pincus gave him a bleak look. “Ain’t you got no respect for the dead lady over there?”
“You know what I think, Ed? I think Mr. Wiseguy here outsmarted himself.”
“Yeah?” Pincus looked bored.
“I heard of guys putting a knot on their own skull to beat a murder rap.”
Pincus sighed. “Sure―you heard of that. Maybe it even happened once. But did you look at that ear?”
Gunwal went around to the side and stared at my ear and winced.

“OK,” Pincus said, “so you come out here, you found the dead woman, tippy-toed upstairs and snooped around, and then poked your head in the back room and somebody tried to knock it off for you. It’s lousy enough to be true. Let’s go look at the place where it happened.”
I led them back to the kitchen. There were a few blood spots on the floor where I’d been rolling around. They went over and looked out the back door. Pincus sighed again.
“Yeah, he could of got away through the hedge, easy. By the way, where’s the rest of the family?”
“I don’t know.”
“Which one you working for, Shaw?”
“None of them.”
“Yeah? How come you had business with this Frank Prendergast?”
“Not really with him; it was peripheral to another matter.”
“Peripheral?” Gunwal repeated. “What does that mean?”
“It means it ain’t none of our business. Come on. Let’s frisk the joint.”

We traipsed upstairs and opened doors and looked into empty rooms. There seemed to be a lot of them. Back downstairs Pincus blew air through his lips and took his hat off and scratched his head and put the hat on again.

“Everything neat as a coffin,” he said. “Except just the one thing.” He went into the study and used the telephone, came back out and jerked a thumb at me. “OK, bub, you get to ride downtown and sign a statement. Hal, you stick around until the meat wagon gets here just so nobody comes home and trips going upstairs.”

We took my car. Pincus drove. We rode a few blocks in one of those pregnant silences. Pincus did a left turn against the light and sighed. “I’d like the accident angle real good,” he said sadly. “Except for that ear.”
“Mrs. Prendergast was an invalid,” I said. “She wouldn’t have been home alone.”
“She wasn’t―remember?” Pincus said sharply.
“You see where that leaves us.”
Pincus sighed again. He groped over the plastic gadgets on the steering wheel, sounded the horn at the car ahead, then cut out around it.
“How you like this bus?” he asked.
“The usual piece of junk. That on the level about you not knowing about Frank Prendergast?”
“I just made a down payment on one just like it,” Pincus said. “Don’t take Hal too serious. He likes to play ‘em under his chin.”
“Is that why you drove off and left him in charge?”
He grinned and wrenched the car around another left turn into a tree-shadowed street. “What’s next to the Prendergast place―behind the hedge?”
“Another hand-groomed acre with a French chateau on it.”
Pincus frowned; the tires whispered on the smooth pavement.

“You come along at a bad time―for the one who pushed the old lady. I figure they had unfinished business upstairs. Ordinarily, they’d figure on having maybe all afternoon before the folks come home. Plenty of time to get what they’re after and then rig the body next to the bed, say, like she fell getting up. They didn’t figure on some snoopy private dick waltzing in in the middle. They panic. But maybe they cool off. They take a stake-out down the block and they see us leave. Maybe they decide to chance it.” He showed me a smile like something carved on a pumpkin. “Like it?”
“The Homicide boys won’t.”

“Who cares what them hotshots like?” He did another left, which put us north of the Prendergast house, coming up on the street we’d started from. He slowed and pulled across to the left-hand curb, stopped in a pool of leaf-mottled shadow.
“Let’s go.”
We got out without slamming any doors, went along the sidewalk under a seven-foot hibiscus hedge. Pincus put his back to it and poked his nose around the corner. He pulled it back in.
“A green four-door, parked up the block,” he said. “Make it?”
“It was there when we left. Also when I arrived an hour ago.”

He grunted and straightened his hat and stepped around the corner. We walked along to the first break in the hedge. Big white wooden gates were latched open on a gravel drive that led up to a car yard in the shadow of three stories of tan limestone under a mansard roof. The hedge beside it was the one that bordered the Prendergast grounds.

“He could of parked up there for the getaway,” Pincus said. I had my mouth open to ask him if that wouldn’t make the neighbors curious when a car rounded the corner behind us. It was a black two-door Mercury with a man in a snap-brim hat behind the wheel. We watched it roll past and turn in at the Prendergast gate. Pincus’ hand went inside his coat and came out with a short-nosed Police Special. He licked his lips and started forward.
“Easy,” I said. “You don’t want to shoot him.”
He whirled on me; his eyes were a little wild.
“That’s Uncle Frank―the one I came to see, remember?”
“Aw, hell,” he said, and put the gun away. As we reached the gate a carload of Homicide men arrived.
“I been waiting for you guys,” Pincus said. “This here is the guy turned in the beef. Give ‘em your story, Shaw.”
I gave them my story. Then we drove downtown.

It was late when I got away from there. I stopped by a little place out on Sunset where they didn’t try to drown you in jukebox, to rinse the taste of cop out of my craw. There hadn’t been enough meat to my story to please them. They’d tried to make something out of it, but there wasn’t really enough to work with. A police nurse had even smeared some stuff on my ear and taped it for me. Maybe I was lucky at that. I’d done my duty as a citizen for a change and all it had cost me was an afternoon out of my young life. I ordered rye, drank it, and left.

I took the long way around to Bell in case anybody was tailing me, and parked up the block from 112. It was a nice late summer evening. Cicadas chirred in the amber twilight. I got out and idled along in front of the closed-down undertaking establishment and smoked a cigarette. No curtains twitched at the window of Lou Anglich’s room. By now he’d probably gotten tired of watching the street. I crossed and went in.

Shamey popped out of his room like an unshaven gopher out of its hole as soon as I came through the door. He leered at me and brought a cigarette out from behind the doorframe and blew smoke up his nose.

“In and out, huh?” he grunted. I grunted back and went on up the stairs. A door opened and a woman with a face like a clenched fist gave me a swift glance and disappeared again. Loud television behind her door got louder.

Anglich didn’t answer my knock. I turned the knob and nudged the door open with my toe. Silence came out of the room. I went in and closed it behind me. The big, rumpled bed was there, and the chair and the rug and the dresser. But no Anglich. Five minutes of poking in empty drawers didn’t change that. A light alligator coat with a tear in one sleeve was hanging on a bent hanger in the closet. The empty rye bottle was on the floor beside the wastebasket, along with some sandwich wrappings. Other than that, the room was bare as a foreclosed bargain basement.

I stood at the window and looked out at the vapor lamp and the high frame houses across the way and my car up the street, looking small and dusty in the gloaming. Then I went downstairs and rapped on Shamey’s door. It popped open so fast I almost rapped Shamey’s forehead.
“All right, what’s the beef this time?” he whined, and looked past my ear.
“When did he go out?”
“Who?”
“Try to guess.”
He made a throwing-away motion. “You think I got time to wet-nurse the tenants, Jack, you get a free think on the house.”
“I already had it. A hundred bucks’ worth.”

“Go on―get off my back.” He started to unwind from the doorframe and slide inside; I slammed a foot down on his instep. He made a choked noise and started a swing that got tied up in the close quarters. I stepped in close and hit him hard at the base of the sternum, twice, pushed him back and slid inside and closed the door behind me. He leaned on the back of a big platform rocker and made sounds like a bagpipe undergoing repairs.

“What was that crack you made as I went up?” I asked him. He helped himself around the chair and sat down and grabbed his beer can off the table and swallowed what was in it and dropped it on the floor without squeezing it.
“Geeze, fella, you busted something in there,” he said hoarsely. “Get me a beer outa the kitchen.”
I went around him and leaned on the wall by the kitchen door, facing him, and folded my arms with my hand near the butt of the Luger.
“In and out, you said. I should have listened closer. Start earning that hundred.”
He turned a hurt look up at me. “I figured it was you,” he said. “That’s how come I’m surprised to see you back so quick.”
“Start a little farther back, Shamey. I’m not getting my money’s worth.”

“A couple hours ago, say four p.m., I hear somebody on the stairs. I’m a little slow getting my head out, I don’t see nobody. I listen. It’s two-eleven; I hear the big guy’s voice. They go inside. I figure it’s you, like I said. Maybe I doze a little after that. The TV is kind of loud. I don’t hear nothing, but I get a kind of feeling. I go up. Nobody home. How about that beer, guy?”
“Did you check out front? No car?”
“The street’s empty. If there was a car I would of said. I ain’t holding out nothing. Why would I?”
“I don’t know. Maybe you’d figure to make a few smart bucks playing two hands. Anything in it?”
“Naw.” He sounded indignant. “Would I do you like that?”
“What was the other voice like?”
“All I heard was the big guy. Hell, you can feel him through the floor.”
“How long was this visitor up there?”
“Maybe fifteen, twenty minutes. The same show is on when I check the second time.”
“You think they left together?”

“I could of slept through one sneak-out. Not two. And you can take my word for it they wasn’t making no noise worth a damn. You spend as long as me keeping a eye on rent-skippers and you develop a ear for the soft-shoe work.”
“And a nose for the soft buck. How much did they pay you?”

He rolled an eye up at me. He humped himself out of his chair and went across to a pair of pants hanging across the back of a chair. I watched him root in the pocket. He came across toward me, holding out wadded bills.

“Here’s what’s left of your C-note,” he said, and dropped it on the floor. “Nobody else paid me nothing. It happened just like I said.” He went into the kitchen and banged the door. I stooped and picked up the money. There was eighty-four dollars. I put sixty in my pocket and tossed the rest on the table and left. Maybe he was lying, but it was a little too late in the day for me to work up a sweat trying to make him tell it any other way. And maybe I reminded myself a little too much of the boys down at Headquarters.

I went up the stairs and rapped at the door the woman had peeked out of. She’d gotten shy since. I kept on rapping. Then I started kicking, not loud, just a nice, polite kicking, but steady. The bottled-up TV got louder. So did I. The door opened in the middle of a commercial for a canine funeral parlor. The fist-like face glared and some crooked teeth snarled, “Beat it, you.” I got a foot in the door before it could slam.
“Cops, lady,” I said. “Hear anything from next door this afternoon?”
“Let’s see the buzzer, flatfoot.’”
I showed her a sad smile instead. “We don’t carry them anymore, ma’am. They got to causing too many riots. About your neighbor―”
“I got no neighbor.”
“The man who was in two-eleven for a few days. He’s gone now. Left about four p.m. I’m asking if you heard any unusual sounds; any conversation, disturbance of any kind.”
“I don’t stick my nose in. Get your foot outa my door before I ram a broom handle through it.”
“A shot?” I said, and smiled my crafty smile―the one Pincus taught me.
Her mouth opened and I got a flash of pink gums. “Shot, huh?” she said vaguely. “Hell, why’nt you say so? Shot, huh? Who done it?”
“You did hear a shot?”
“Maybe I did and maybe I didn’t. I’d have to think. Who did you say you was?”
“A friend of the family. About the shot―’
“Hell, you ain’t no cop. Beat it, mister, before 1 call my husband.”
“Where’s he―out in the back yard gnawing an old shoe?”
“Scram!” she yelled. “I keep my TV turned up loud. 1 wouldn’t hear dynamite if it went off in the hall!”
I got my foot out just in time for her heel to chip the linoleum where it had been. The slam of the door shook loose dust that had settled from the Thanksgiving parade of 1939.

Shamey didn’t stick his head out as I left. Maybe the door banging had deadened his keen ear. Or maybe he’d just had enough of Joe Shaw, Private Investigator, for one day. I didn’t blame him. So had I.
Halfway back to town I thought I saw a gray VW with a crumpled fender three cars back. I did a few lefts and rights and shaded an amber light, and didn’t see it any more.
I went on home and cops were waiting.

There were two of them, Pincus and a small, gray man with a face that looked as if all the juice had been sucked out of it by one of those spiders that sting their prey and take them back to the nest alive for the larvae to feed on. They watched me close the door and switch on a table lamp and turn off the bare ceiling light they’d been sitting under.
“I’m glad you boys didn’t feel shy about making yourselves comfy,” I said. “Take your shoes off. Have a drink. Act nice and I’ll let you run barefoot through my Persian rugs.”
“This here is Lieutenant Dreyfus out of Central Homicide,” Pincus said in an important voice. “Him and me come around to ask you a few questions.”

“No kidding. I thought you just wanted to bask in the sunshine of my personality.” I went past them into the kitchenette and mixed a drink. Then I sneered at myself in the window over the sink and mixed two more. I put them on the lid of a box some misguided admirer had sent me a fruitcake in once―probably a department store that got my name mixed up with a customer―and took them in.
Pincus started to reach and then frowned and glanced at Dreyfus.
“Don’t drink it,” I said. “It’s a bribe.”
Dreyfus twitched a lean jowl and picked up the glass and took a careful sip and put it back.
“Maybe you’d like to tell me what it was that brought you out to Mayfair Heights this afternoon, Mr. Shaw,” he said, in a voice as light and dry as old wine.
I sat down and sighed―I was sighing a lot lately―and sampled my drink. It was strong but I could have stood it stronger.
“It’s just as I stated in my deposition, Lieutenant,” I said. “I had a matter I wanted to discuss with Mr. Frank Prendergast. I went out on the chance I’d catch him at home.”
“What made you pick that particular time?”
“It was just a sudden impulse, I guess you’d call it. I could have gone earlier or later.”
He nodded gravely. “And you’ve said that you were not at that time employed by Mr. Prendergast.”
“Not at that time or any time.”
“Nor by any member of the Prendergast family.”
“That’s correct.”
“However, you were acting on behalf of a client?”
“I have a client. In my bumbling way I was working on his problem. But the client has no connection that I know of with Frank Prendergast.”
“And you decline to give the client’s name.”

“Lieutenant, I went out there and I found Mrs. Prendergast dead. The milkman might have done the same. Strictly speaking, I should have rung the bell and gone away. I didn’t. I heard sounds. I suspected foul play. Even a private cop is still a citizen. I did what I conceived any responsible citizen ought to do: I tried to apprehend a person I suspected might be the one who helped Mrs. Prendergast downstairs. For my trouble I have a knot on my skull and a ragged ear to remind me a smart cooky would have turned quickly and walked away from there―body or no body.”

“I don’t suppose it occurred to you to telephone the police and stand by, keeping an eye on the house. That way you might at least have been able to give us a description of the man you say attacked you.” Dreyfus said this mildly, without rancor.

“The thought never entered my mind. Things happened too fast, maybe. And maybe if it had entered my mind I still would have done what I did. Which side of the house would I watch, Lieutenant? My instinct was to nail the man before he did a fast fade out some side door I didn’t know about.”
He let that ride and watched the toe of his shoe. Then he said:
“This client of yours, Mr. Shaw―has he any connection with the Prendergast girls?”
I took a swallow of my drink, keeping the famous Shaw poker face in position, and thought that over. Nothing in particular occurred to me.
“May I ask why you ask?” I said carefully. I don’t know why I said it carefully; it just seemed like a good time to start being careful, even in small, unimportant ways.
“I’d prefer you just answer the question.”
“No connection―as far as I know.”
“Any connection you suspect?”
“I don’t think this is a matter I should make guesses about.”

Dreyfus looked at his thumb. “A woman’s been killed, Mr. Shaw. At this point we’re all guessing―about a number of things. How a woman in her position happened to be alone in the house; why your assailant was busy upstairs when you arrived; why a private investigator happened along at just that moment. Things like that. Your guesses might help.”
“What does Uncle Frank say?”
“Ha,” Pincus said. “That pickled mackerel―” He closed his mouth and frowned and sampled his drink.

“Mr. Prendergast wasn’t very helpful. He’d been gone less than half an hour. He’d left Mrs. Prendergast asleep. The day nurse had telephoned that she’d be a few minutes late. The daughters were out for the day.”
“So he left her alone.”
“She usually slept through until dinner. She hadn’t been out of bed―other than in a wheel chair―for over a year.”
“So somebody carried her to the stairs and pitched her down. Nice.”
Dreyfus shook his head. “Her neck was broken first. She was carried down and placed at the foot of the stairs. There were no bruises such as would have resulted from a fall like that.”
“I guess that takes care of the accident theory.”
He smiled a wan smile. “Was there one?”
“Who’d want to kill her?”

“We checked the will angle,” Pincus said heavily. “Nothing doing there. It’s all tied up in trust funds for the daughters.” He shifted his eyes sideways to me. “Unless you wanted to play with the idea maybe they wasn’t getting to spend it fast enough.”
“You say you had no other business with the Prender-gasts?” Dreyfus said offhandedly.
“I didn’t say that. I said none of them had retained me.”
“Seen any of them lately?”
“As a matter of fact Ellen Prendergast came by my office this morning,” I said. “Should I have mentioned that sooner?”
Dreyfus almost smiled at me. “Anything else you should have mentioned sooner?”
“I saw Mianne Prendergast this afternoon.”
Dreyfus held his lips like a dressmaker with a mouthful of pins.
“That would be what time?”
“At two.”
“And then?”
“We had a drink. Then I drove out to Mayfair Heights.”

“Now let’s see. You saw two members of the Prendergast family. Then you drove to the Prendergast home. But none of this had any necessary connection with whatever it was you were doing on behalf of the client whose name you don’t care to mention.”
“I didn’t say it had no connection. I said he had no necessary connection.”
“That’s getting to be a pretty fine distinction, wouldn’t you say, Mr. Shaw?”

“Look at it this way, Lieutenant. Let’s say you’re a client who comes to me with a problem: I scratch around and get some ideas. I start checking them out. Along the way I fall over a corpse. So I tell the cops to bring you down to the station house and see what they can grill out of you. Like it?”

He scratched his head delicately with his little finger. Pincus was almost, but not quite holding his breath. He was getting to watch an expert work. It was worth watching. In his quiet way Dreyfus was wrapping me up like a shilling’s worth of fish and chips.

“You have a right to protect your client―up to a point,” he said reasonably. “The question is, just how far does that obligation carry you?” He gave me a look as flat and hard and colorless as a sidewalk. “I wouldn’t say you were implicated in a murder, Mr. Shaw. I would say your role is still a little unclear to me.”
“It’s unclear to me too, Lieutenant.”

He leaned toward me and tapped himself on the knee. “You’re not getting the picture, Mr. Shaw. I don’t have you downtown under the lights. I’m not working you over with the plastic hose and the knuckle-punch to the kidney. I’m not keeping you up all night with the boys throwing the questions at you in relays. I’m asking you―almost politely. The name of the client, Mr. Shaw.”
I swirled the drink in my glass and drank the rest of it. He waited.

“You could do all that,” I said. “And other things. I know some of the other things. I’ve had them done to me on occasion. They don’t affect me much. They’re part of the business. If I wanted to hold out on you I wouldn’t have waited around after I phoned in. Maybe I wouldn’t even have phoned in. But I did. Chalk that one up for me. As you said, I have an obligation to my client. That includes not throwing him over the side for the wolves to worry while I make a getaway in the troika. If you’ll give me your word you won’t make any more out of it than there is in it, I’ll tell you his name.”
