“I’m a police officer, Shaw. I’ll do what my best judgment tells me.”

“Then you can go dig up his name for yourself, Lieutenant. I know you police officers. Sometimes your judgment is just dandy. Other times it’s hard to tell from any other headline-hungry bureaucrat with a yen to get his knuckles in where they’ll draw juice. Try it on me. See what it buys you.”
“You’re out of line, Shaw,” Pincus barked, and faded a hand back toward his hip. “About a mile and a half out of line.”
“Go ahead, Porky. Make that snappy hip draw. Show me the braided leather sap with the number-ten shot inside. Maybe you’ll wind up eating it.”
“How about it, Lieutenant?” Pincus poised on the edge of the chair with a fixed smile on his face.

“Just a minute,” Dreyfus rapped sharply, and waved Pincus back. “This is getting a little out of hand. I came up here to ask you a question, Shaw. I’m still asking it. You want my assurance your client won’t be unduly hassled. Very well―you have it.”
“Your word, Lieutenant. The fact that you’re a little reluctant to give it might mean it still means something to you.”
He flushed a little―or maybe not. “All right―my word on it. I’m not out to persecute innocent citizens.”
“His name is Louis Anglich.” I spelled it.
“Address?”
“I don’t know.”
His look jelled over like setting solder.
“Until this afternoon he was staying in a rooming house out on Bell Street,” I said. “He checked out. I don’t know where he went.”
Dreyfus stared at me. Pincus teased his upper lip with the tip of his tongue. Dreyfus nodded abruptly and stood. Pincus looked disappointed and heaved himself out of his chair.
“Naturally, you’ll let me know as soon as you’ve heard from him,” Dreyfus said tonelessly.
“Naturally.”
“Good.” They turned to go; Dreyfus paused with a hand on the doorknob.
“By the way―I don’t suppose you know where Miss Prendergast was headed after she left your office this morning?”
“No idea, Lieutenant.”
“And since she’s not a client you’d have no hesitation in telling me if you did.”
“I’d tell you if I knew.”

They left. I took Dreyfus’ drink in the kitchen and poured it down the drain and rinsed Pincus’ glass and mine. I mixed another, not overdoing the water, and took it over to the window and watched the unmarked cop car pull away from where it had parked half a block away. It had started to rain, a fine, wind-driven spatter like the spray on the promenade deck of a ship far from land.

Miss Ellen Prendergast hadn’t come home. Her mother was dead by misadventure, and the police were interested enough in her movements to dig out someone who’d seen her at the Banshire Building. I could see the way their minds were working.
“Nuts,” I said to the empty room. I had another drink and went to bed and after a while I slept.

Mayfair Heights looked fresh and crisp after the night’s rain. The big houses sparkled in the early sun. The black coupe was at home, looking in need of a wash. The tail end of the El Dorado showed through an open door of the garage. I parked in the drive and went across the grass to the front door and worked the bell. Yesterday I had wanted to talk to Frank Prendergast. I still did.

He opened the door himself. He was wearing a paisley dressing gown with a black satin collar, not as clean or as new as it might have been, and he hadn’t shaved. The stubble gave him a hint of the raffish look of an elderly panhandler making his first touch of the day. But his handsome head of silver hair looked as perfectly groomed as ever.
“Butler’s day off?” I said.
He said, “What?” and looked at me with blank hostility.
“Miss Ellen at home?”
“What is it you want―Shaw, isn’t it? I have no time for you today.” He started to close the door.
“I didn’t mention Thompson to the cops,” I said quickly. He went on closing the door, then opened it again.
“You said what?” His voice had gone as fiat as leftover beer.
I got out a cigarette and rolled it around between my fingers.
“If they’d asked me I would have. But they didn’t. They asked me other things. I didn’t have many answers. They weren’t too pleased with me. How’d you do?”
“Mr. Shaw, there’s been a death in this house. I’ll thank you to leave us to our grief―”
“Uh-huh. I was the one that found the body―or didn’t they tell you?”
“I asked you once what it is you want, Shaw.”
“But you didn’t wait for an answer. I was thinking we could have a little talk, Mr. Prendergast.”
“On what conceivable subject?”
“Yesterday.”
His eyes went to my bandaged ear. I said, “Why don’t we talk inside?”

He made an impatient sound and backed inside and I followed him into the library. He settled himself in a chair and motioned me to one. The leather made a soft whooshing sound; I sank down until I was looking out between my knees.
“All right―what is all this?” Uncle Frank said.
“I take it that’s Miss Mianne’s car in the garage?”
“What business is that of yours?”
“Ellen drives the little gray Jaguar. Still not home, eh?”
“My family’s activities are none of your concern!”
“The police seemed to think differently, Mr. Prendergast.”
“You keep mentioning the police. Is that supposed to secure some sort of reaction from me?”
“It does from most people. They had the idea I might know where she was.”
“What’s your interest in my niece, Shaw?”
“She came by my office yesterday. We had an interesting talk.”
“And?”
“And now she seems to have dropped out of sight. That worries me a little.”
“Haven’t you done enough snooping, Shaw? Yesterday, trespassing here―what do you think gives you the right to rummage in my dead sister-in-law’s room? I could have you arrested for that―”
“I thought they didn’t tell you I was here.”
“Well, you’re mistaken.”
I lit the cigarette I’d been playing with and dropped the match in a Swedish glass ash tray less massive than King Seti’s sarcophagus.
“Any idea where she is?”
“At the moment―no.”
“What are you doing about it?”
He squeezed the leather arms of the chair and sneered at me and didn’t answer.
“When she left the house, when did you expect her back?”
“As it happens, I didn’t see her go.”
“Did she often spend the night elsewhere without letting someone know?”
“What are you implying, Shaw?”
“She’s been gone almost twenty-four hours. Most families would be a bit worried by now.”
“Naturally, I’m concerned―”
“There was a small item in the paper this morning about Mrs. Prendergast’s death. Seems she had a fall. That’s the first Ellen would have known of it―unless she had another channel of information.”
“I haven’t spoken to her since evening before last.”
“You’d think she’d come home―or at least call―when she learned of the tragedy.”
“Perhaps she hasn’t seen the paper.”
“Maybe there’s something you know that I don’t, Mr. Prendergast.”
He stood up abruptly. “Possibly―and now perhaps you’ll be kind enough to go your way, sir. I’m expected at the mortuary in half an hour.”
“‘That must give you a funny feeling, Mr. Prendergast. How is Mianne taking this?”
“You’re insolent, sir! Get out of this house at once!”
I got to my feet. “Have you thought of calling the police, Mr. Prendergast―about Ellen’s disappearance, I mean?”
“Certainly not!”
“Mind telling me why?”
“I needn’t tell you anything!”
“You know they’re looking for her.”
Prendergast’s mouth worked as though there was a mouse inside trying to get out. He walked back to his chair and sat down.
“I’m . . . making every effort to find her,” he said.

He slashed his eyes at me, looked away. “Every family has its secrets, Mr. Shaw. This one is no exception. Ellen is . . . erratic. I don’t know what may have set her off. She always resented her mother, resented her illness, the necessity for the constant nursing, the constant attention. There have been incidents before―minor incidents, in the main. I shouldn’t have left her here alone with her, but in God’s name, who would have thought . . . ?” He gave me a sideways look to see how I was taking it.

“I had to go out―briefly―on a business matter,” he went on. “Marion was asleep. Ellen was in the garden, exercising the dog, running him through those ridiculous commando tricks―as if the beast weren’t savage enough by nature. There was no hint whatever of―” He stopped talking and shook his head, not looking at me.
“And as soon as you cleared the drive she went inside, dragged her mother out of bed, and threw her down the stairs. That the picture?”
He nodded once, jerkily. “The poor child isn’t responsible, of course. There are certain officials to whom the matter will have to be presented in the proper light . . . .”
“You’ll make the right payoff in the right quarter and the case will be dropped, that it?”

He looked at me now―like a jab between the eyes with a poker. “If you insist on putting it crudely―yes,” he snarled. “Now can you understand why you mustn’t interfere? This is a delicate situation, Shaw. If the authorities get their hands on her prematurely―or the newspapers―”
“How do you know I won’t go to the nearest telephone and give the whole story to the police? I could use a few points with them.”

His eyes gnawed at me. “I’m walking a knife-edge, Shaw,” he said hoarsely. “I know something of you; I’ve done some checking. You’re a man who probes―and probes. This situation can’t stand probing. Very well―perhaps I made an error in confiding in you. It will, of course, be your unsupported word against mine, if you choose to betray my confidence. I see little advantage to you in so doing. In the end, the result will be the same. Ellen will obviously have to be placed under restraint. It’s merely a question of reducing the tragic impact on others―her sister, for example.”
“You mentioned other incidents.”
“Small things, in the main: bursts of petulance, petty cruelties. Afterwards she was always contrite―”
“In the main, you said.”
“Damn you―haven’t you raked enough scandal for one morning?”
“The incident that wasn’t minor―how long ago would that have been, Mr. Prendergast?”
“It slips my mind,” he said coldly.
“About two years, say?”
“Damn you,” he repeated in a whisper.
This time I got up first. “Where are you looking for her?”
“I’m checking the hotels, out-of-town friends. A few places up the coast where the girls have spent weekends on occasion. Credit card usage, that sort of thing. Quietly, of course.”
“What makes you think you’ll find her before the cops?”
“I can only do my best!”
“If you find her, will you call me?”
“Why should I?”
“I’m a bit involved, Mr. Prendergast, like it or not. I’d like to have some idea just how far my neck is out. That way I might get a chance to get it in before the knife falls.”
“Very well. I’ll keep you advised.”
“How much of this does Mianne know?”

“Nothing. Nothing at all. She’s taking her mother’s death badly. For God’s sake leave her out of this.” He glared at me; then his expression got thoughtful. “Look here, Shaw. Perhaps you could find her. After all, you’re in that sort of business.”
“Perhaps. It would depend on how much help I got.”
“Damn it, man, I’ve told you all I know! I’d pay well, of course,” he added.
“How well?”
“Shall we say―a thousand dollars, if you locate her before the police, and put me in touch with her?”
I stood. He did too. “Well―do we have an understanding?”
“I’ll think it over.”
He trailed me to the door. Halfway through it I looked back.
“You know a man named Jaster?”
He shook his head, looking impatient, nothing more. “Please, Mr. Shaw. No more today.”
I left and drove back down to the office.

The elevator seemed to creak a little more than usual, as if it was already tired, with a long day ahead. Behind the door of the painless dentist down the hall a typewriter clattered with a brisk, cheery sound, as if it was typing up fat bills.
I knew there was someone waiting in my outer office before I opened the door; I opened it anyway.
Ellen Prendergast was sitting in the chair by the window.

She was wearing the same outfit I had seen her in the previous day. It didn’t look slept in. Her hair was brushed, smooth and neat, her lips touched up. She was sitting rather primly on the edge of the chair, looking every inch the moneyed client. Only her eyes said she hadn’t slept last night.

I went over and unlocked the inner office door and picked up the mail and dropped it in the wastebasket and dumped the ash tray after it. That took care of my housekeeping. I leaned in the connecting doorway and got out a cigarette and tapped it on my thumb and stuck it in my mouth. Miss Prendergast patiently watched me do all this.
“May I come in?” she said. I nodded and got out of her way. She sat in the chair by my desk. I went around behind it and parked myself in mine. That put us in business position.
“Shoot,” I said.
“Please―are you going to play that objectionable role again today?”
Looking at her, I couldn’t decide whether she’d heard the news or not.
“You forgot to light your cigarette,” she said.
I lit it. “Have you seen the paper?” I asked.
“Yes.” She looked at me, looked away, looked back. “My mother was killed, Mr. Shaw.”
“The paper said accident.”
“The paper lied.”
“Or made a mistake, maybe.”

“Lied. Last year one of their reporters came to the house wanting to do some sort of Sunday supplement article on us. Uncle Frank had Thompson eject him. He wrote the article anyway. He referred to Mother as an invalid dying in an upstairs room while we―Mianne and I―pursued a wild life of pleasure. They knew she couldn’t have gotten to the stairs alone, Mr. Shaw.”
“Anything in it? The wild life of pleasure, I mean.”
“I don’t know why you seem intent on baiting me, Mr. Shaw. I came here to consult you. You are a private detective, aren’t you?”
“In a small way of business.”
“Is there some reason I shouldn’t employ you?”
“Is there some reason you should?”
“I want to know who killed my mother.”
“Any ideas?”
“Yes.”
“Who?”
She shook her head. “I don’t want to prejudice you. I may be utterly wrong. I may be imagining things. I . . . hope I am. Perhaps you can tell me.”
“Where were you yesterday, Miss Prendergast―at the time of your mother’s fall?”

“I’m . . . not sure. After I saw you I didn’t feel like going home. I drove out to the beach. We have a cottage up past Cape Royal, I thought of going there. Then after I’d stopped for gas I just kept on going. I didn’t want to be alone. I stopped and had lunch at a place called Trajan’s.”
“That would be what time?”
“Noon, or a little after. I stayed there for a couple of hours, I suppose.”
“That would make it two p.m. at the latest. Mrs. Prendergast died at about three.”

“I left there and drove north, almost to Ventura. I went to a drive-in movie. Afterwards I ate dinner. I drove some more. I wasn’t going anywhere, just driving around. Have you ever not wanted to go home, Mr. Shaw?”
“I don’t suppose you just happened to stop to fill the tank at three p.m. And that the attendant would remember you.”
Her face changed a little; her eyes held on mine.
“The police are looking for you,” I said.
Her expression didn’t change much. Just stiffened up. I watched her handling the idea, getting the full implications.
“I . . . see. Of course.”
“Why didn’t you call home?”
“I don’t know.”
“Your uncle’s a little worried about you.”
She looked at me.
“He offered me a fat fee to find you and bring you home―to him, not the police.”
Her face went perfectly still. If there’d been any color in it, it was gone now.
“I didn’t take the job,” I said.

Her mouth twitched as if it was trying to smile and couldn’t quite make it. She leaned toward me―farther. Her eyes rolled up. I got a hand out just in time to keep her from banging the desk with her chin. I came around the end of the desk and got her out of the chair and laid her out on the old green leather settee I keep around for emergencies. Her eyelids looked as transparent as pale blue tissue paper. They fluttered and opened.

“Don’t yell,” I said. “You just took a short nap.” I got the office bottle out and poured her half an inch in one of my jelly glasses. She swallowed it and shuddered, but the vacant look went away from her eyes.
“I feel like a fool,” she said, and sat up.
“When did you see that paper, Ellen?”

“About midnight. I picked it up on a newsstand at Sherman Oaks. Some sort of early edition. It was strange: I wasn’t shocked or surprised. It was as if I’d been expecting it. As if it were what I’d been waiting for.”
“How well did you and your mother get on?”
“Very well, of course. I can’t say as much for her relations with Mianne, of course. She was so impatient with her, especially since she’s been sick . . . “ She let the rest of that trail off.
“Where did your parents meet?”
“In Florida. Mr. Shaw, does this have anything to do―”
“I don’t know yet, Miss Prendergast. But I’m working on it. Your father had business interests there, I understand.”
“I suppose so. But―”
“In Tampa,” I added.
“So I understand. Mr. Shaw, I really don’t think―”
“What did she do? Your mother. What kind of work?”
“I . . . don’t know that she . . . I think they met socially, at a party.”
“How much education did she have?”
“She was not a college graduate.”
“Or high school, either. What was she, Ellen? A waitress? Show business? Or something gamier?”

Her face had the chalky look again. She was having a rough morning. “You can really be quite horrible, can’t you, Mr. Shaw? In answer to your question―I don’t know. I made it my business never to inquire too closely. Does that satisfy you?”
“I’m not asking questions just to see you blush, Miss Prendergast,” I said. This time I poured one for myself too. We drank them off and looked at each other.
“Where did you spend the night?”
“At a motel. The Blue Pacific. Near Port Hueneme. A ghastly little room.”
“How did you get here?”
“I drove into town early, about daylight. I parked near the bus station and walked over. I . . . thought I came up here on impulse, but perhaps this was where I intended to come all along.”

I started to uncap the bottle again, but instead I jammed it back in the drawer and got out of my chair―maybe to get away from temptation. She watched me do a couple of lengths of the room. I went back and sat down and got the bottle out and poured and drank. It didn’t change anything. It so seldom does.
“I take it you don’t want to see your uncle,” I said.
“No.”
“Any particular reason?”
“None that I’d care to talk about.”
“What do you plan to do now?”
“That’s what I thought about all night.” She gave me a wan little smile. “Somehow, I thought you might advise me.”

“I could make some good friends downtown by picking up that phone,” I said, just to hear myself talk. “To say nothing of Uncle Frank’s offer.” She took that calmly, just looked at me, waiting. She was in my hands now. Whatever I thought was best. The old family detective, he’ll fix everything.

“I know a place where you could stay for a few days without finding it mentioned in the gossip columns,” I said. “The Dockweiler. Nothing fancy, but no cockroaches. The problem is getting you there. The building is probably watched. They’ll have spotted your car by now.” I got out of the chair and went and peered out the window.
“You’d better give me some money. A hundred dollars will do. I’ll give you a receipt that says you’re retaining me.”
She dug it out of her change purse and I typed out the receipt.
“I’m going down for a paper now,” I said. “If anybody knocks, or if the telephone rings, don’t answer it. Remember―you’re not here at all.”
“If the police come, I’ll tell them you convinced me to turn myself in.” She gave me the brave little smile. I gave her back a grimace and went down to the street.

There were no squad cars loaded with buttons double-parked at the curb. No large men sat in parked sedans reading newspapers. I didn’t see the glint of sunlight from binoculars on the surrounding roof tops. There could still have been a squad of plainclothesmen watching every move I made and I’d never have known it. I strolled along to the corner espresso joint and got an elbow in among the regulars and gave the high sign. A shopworn bunny who had outgrown her uniform pushed a cup across at me and brushed back her bangs with a forearm and gave me a tragic look and rushed away. A size forty-eight hip jostled me halfway off my perch. A newspaper flapped in my face. An elbow dug into my back. I turned.
“Nothing personal, pal,” a bald man in a brown plastic jacket said.

“The motto of our times,” I said. The coffee tasted like the stuff they dip brass in to take off the tarnish; that made it easy to leave after a couple of swallows. Back on the sidewalk, I did a slow ankle to the next corner. Old Shaw, taking his time, lingering over his morning coffee and having his morning stroll. No guilty conscience, nothing to hide. I came back along the block behind the Banshire Building, up the side, and back in at the front door. No cops. No visible cops, that is. Just the usual collection of faces, plus a few transients. No suspicious loiterers, except maybe me.
Back upstairs, Ellen Prendergast was sitting exactly where I’d left her. She stood as I came in.

“All right,” I said. “If there’s a stake-out I can’t see it. You’re going out alone. Take the side exit.” I told her where it was. “Don’t be in a hurry. You’re just out to do a little shopping. Walk east two blocks. There’s a storage garage. Walk through it. I’ll pick you up in back.”

She nodded a little stiffly and went out. I listened until the elevator had clashed its doors and the hum had faded. Down the hall the typewriter was still clattering. It sounded like a big month for the dentist.
“Come on, Shaw,” I said, “get your head all the way into the noose. There’s nothing worse than a sloppy hanging.”

I rode the elevator down, drove around to the garage and parked in the alley. In five minutes Ellen Prendergast arrived, looking a little scared but still in control. She even managed a small smile as she slid in beside me.
“Maybe the police aren’t as interested in me as you thought, Mr. Shaw.”
“They fumble one once in a while, too,” I said. We didn’t talk on the way to the hotel.
I watched the rearview. Nobody seemed to be following, but I took the long way anyway. Which didn’t mean I wasn’t followed.

Stan Fellows, the day clerk, was on duty. He checked Miss Smith into 507 without leering. I got her settled, then came back down to the desk. Stan was sorting letters into pigeonholes. He paused to read a postcard, shook his head sadly, filed it, dropped the rest of the mail on the switchboard desk, and said, “How long will Miss Smith be with us, Joe?”
“A day or two. Possibly longer. She’s not expecting any visitors, Stan.”
“Unless they show a badge. Check.”
I put a twenty on the counter. “She’ll be phoning out for a few necessities. Outside of that I don’t think she’ll be making any calls. She won’t be going out.”
“Sure. A home girl.”
“If she calls anybody―let me know. If she tries to leave―delay her and call me. Fast. Got it?”
He frowned and rubbed his forefinger on his lower lip. “Hell, Joe, I can’t keep her here―as long as she pays her bill.”
“Right. You get the idea. The twenty’s on top.”
“Do I?” He shook his head, but he took the twenty.
I sat in the car for a few minutes, thinking or―trying to―before I started up and drove back to the office.
Dreyfus telephoned me just after three.
“Heard anything from this client of yours―Anglich?”
I gripped the phone a little tighter. “No―have you?”
“No. I checked with Lacey. He gave you a clean bill―up to now.”
“Any line on Ellen Prendergast?” I asked.
“Nothing yet. I’m not too concerned about that. She’ll have to come out eventually.”
“Getting all the cooperation you need out of Frank Prendergast?”
“He’s told us what he could. It isn’t much. Naturally, the old man’s not enthusiastic about the situation.”
“He offer you a deal?”
“What kind of deal?”
“That little extra measure of candor―in return for the soft pedal.”
“He wouldn’t get anywhere with that.”
“How much did you tell him yesterday―about me being the one who found the body?”
“Just that. Why?”
“I just wanted to know if I had anything to be cagey about next time I see him.”
“You won’t be seeing him for a while. He’s out of town. He and the daughter―the one who didn’t fly the coop. They flew over to Vegas for a few days.”
It seemed like a long pause before I said, “Kind of in a hurry, wasn’t he? Didn’t even wait for the funeral.”
“You’re out of touch, Shaw. The funeral was at noon today. You can’t blame him for wanting to get out of the house for a while.” His voice sounded too casual.
“Can’t you? I thought you boys could blame anybody for anything―if it suited you.”
“Well, you chew that over, Shaw. Maybe there’s a lesson in it for you.” He hung up without waiting for the snappy comeback.

Some time went by while I sat and looked at a patch of not too clean wall, combing through the conversation I’d just had for the part between the lines. Cops didn’t call me up just to pass the time of day and pass along the latest gossip. Dreyfus had had a reason. And if I was any judge of oblique motives, he’d gotten what he wanted. Either I’d told him something without meaning to, or he’d planted an idea on me that was supposed to take root and grow into something he could use.
Nothing I’d said told him anything he didn’t already know. If he knew I’d seen Prendergast that morning he hadn’t let on. That left his big news―that Uncle Frank had left town.

Maybe that was supposed to panic me into some indiscreet behavior. I tried to think of some indiscreet behavior to be panicked into, but nothing presented itself. I found myself getting out the old reliable flask from the desk drawer without even being aware of it. The level had fallen to a perilous low. I wondered how much of it I’d drunk without knowing it. It had been a new bottle when Anglich was here. I’d done him a lot of good. He was a lucky man to have me looking out for him. I shook the bottle and put it away. I got out a couple of pencils and sharpened them. I picked a letter out of the in basket and read it. It was from a correspondence school that wanted to teach me how to become an astrologer. Detect Character Through Stellar Influence. Read Facts in the Stars. We all know that the tides due to the sun and moon affect crops, fishing, etc. Scientists concede relation of Sun-spot Cycle to human affairs. Why not apply this ancient knowledge to Twentieth-Century Crime Detection? Chance of a Lifetime. Send only $14.98. Signed, B’ahu Alah.

I threw the chance of a lifetime in the wastebasket―probably not for the first time. I wondered if Mr. B’ahu Alah had predicted that. Then I fished it back out and tucked the letter in the enclosed franked envelope and sealed it.

Down in the lobby I dropped it in the mailbox. That’s more like it, Shaw. Don’t ever get so busy you neglect your little jokes. Even if you have to do it cold turkey. Think of appearances. Read the future in the stars. Maybe it was as good a place as any.
I got in my jalopy and drove over to the Penguin Lounge.

The mid-afternoon lull was on. The noontime drinkers had mostly tottered off for a nap to get in shape for the evening’s elbow marathon, and the late shift hadn’t come on yet. I parked at the end of the bar and ordered a Bacardi cocktail. It was an old tradition with me to order a Bacardi at the Penguin, dating back to yesterday.

The bartender was a youngish fellow with curly brown hair whose boyish good looks were beginning to fade a little around the edges. He’d probably come out here ten years ago to make it big in the movies. At least he was working.
“You look kind of down, pal,” he said. “Anything I can do to brighten the picture?”
“You might try stocking a better grade of ant-killer,” I said.
“If it was any better they’d start complaining about the size of the drinks,” he said.
“And if the drinks were any smaller they’d complain about the prices.”
“And if the prices were any lower you wouldn’t be able to drink it.”
“Every profession has its problems.”

He wagged his head and refilled my glass without my asking. “You take women. I get all kinds in here. Old dames with junk jewelry halfway to the elbow, and elbows like turkey wings, and don’t think they don’t bend ‘em. According to them, they all tested the same day as Myrna Loy, only she flopped for the director and aced ‘em out of a big career. I get the middle-aged ones that are taking a little longer every day to get the face nailed back on, and spend the afternoon in here telling me the inside story on how Lana Turner lost her looks. And the young ones, the ones that were the queen of the ball back in Dry Creek, Oklahoma, or Spudville, Idaho, that figured all they had to do was shake it a couple of times and knock over Levine like they did the bag-boys back at the Piggly Wiggly store. And they all let slip they live up in the next block and have trouble sleeping nights. That’s supposed to take care of the bar tab. How much action they think a guy can handle, for chrissake? Besides, I have to pay for this stuff. You can’t kill ants for free, after all.”

He went down the bar to top off an elderly gent in rumpled white linen who looked like an escapee from one of those sweat and gin films that they don’t make nearly so well as they used to when Sydney Greenstreet and Peter Lorre were around. He polished his way back up to me and said, “Hey, didn’t 1 see you around before?”
“What a memory,” I said.
“Yeah―it was yesterday.” He worked hard on a stubborn spot in easy conversational―not to say confidential―distance.
“The lady you was with: some looker; no offense.”
“Don’t kid me,” I said. “You know her. She’s regular here.”
His grin was a little flustered, but not enough to build anything on.
“You know her pretty good?”
“I haven’t been up to see her etchings yet,” I said.
He wagged his head. “What is it with a dame like that?”
I took a swallow instead of answering.

“The first time I seen her―couple years back―she come in with a couple nances in pink and green silk suits. With perfume on, yet. Them, not her. A dame like that―with them two. Can you tie it?” He gave me an oblique look that I wasn’t supposed to notice.
“Maybe she was bored. A girl with all that money can still get bored, you know.”
“Greasers,” he said. “I seen her here a couple times with greasers. A dame like that. It makes you want to take a swing at something.”
“Did you?”
He stiffened a little; that broke the rhythm of his polishing. He tossed the cloth down under the bar and leaned on his left elbow.

“Sure,” he said, and gave me a flat look. “What guy wouldn’t?” His right hand was down under the bar, about where it would have to be hovering near whatever he kept there. He seemed to be a fellow who was expecting trouble. I nodded in a knowledgeable way and swallowed some more of the drink and got out a cigarette. He scratched a match and held it for me. We were still pals.
“I’ll give you a tip, chum,” he said. “Don’t make no long-range plans with that one. She’s strictly out for the kick of the moment, if you know what I mean.”
I blew out smoke and looked philosophical. Or maybe I just looked sad. It’s hard to tell the two expressions apart.
“Her old man kicked off just in time,” he said.
I held my expression in place and made it a point not to accidentally stick the cigarette in my eye.
“Meaning what,” I said.

“Hell, he’d of cut her out of the will if he’d lived another week. That was known.” He licked his lips and looked at me. He was a boy who was just aching to give out with the dirt. And I was the boy who would listen.
I yawned a little and looked at my watch. I said, “Yeah?”

“Damn right. Hell, the babe was out making the rounds every night, with every two-bit grifter that ever planted a cockroach in a Martini so he could squawk on the bill. She run around with guys like London, that ran the Chateau Club down at Playa del Rey. Hell, she was there the night they raided the joint and closed it down, only the old man kept it out of the papers.”
“That so?” I said.
“Damn right. Believe me, brother, I’d know.” The grin was that of a man who would know.
“Go on,” I said. “I’ll bet you never even got to warm up in the bull pen.”

He looked huffy and marched off to service a pair in the forty-going-on-sixty-five age group, all pancake makeup and mummified curls, with a sprinkling of crimson war paint. I went out and along to the corner and dropped a dime in a pale green telephone beside a plastic rocketship outside a drugstore. A pint-sized delinquent wearing an expression of wary suspicion was sitting in the saddle. We sneered at each other through the glass while I listened to the ring signal. A chipper female voice answered; I asked for Lacey.
“Well, howsa boy?” he said in the lazy sort of drawl they use as they slip on the brass knuckles. “Glad you phoned in.”
“Barely making expenses,” I said. “A guy named London: used to run a little flash gambling out of a place called the Chateau Club. What’s he doing now?”
“London, huh? It’s an angle, at that. What would he be doing?”
“All right―where’s he doing it.”
Lacey chuckled softly. “The sign says The Blue Dahlia―but the address ain’t changed. Funny, huh?”
“Well, the sheriff has to eat too. What was that crack about being glad I called in?”
“Nothing much, Joe. Just a couple kind of funny items I thought you might get a laugh out of. You remember I told you about the city turning up a Tampa boy over on Alamitos?”
I thought hard. I didn’t remember him mentioning Alamitos.
“Oh, on Alamitos, was it?” I said.

“Oh, didn’t I say before? I must of forgot. Anyway, I hear they fell over another one. A body, I mean. And whattya know―they check out the prints with DC and turns out it’s another guy from Tampa.” He paused to let that sink in. “And then a couple nights ago they get a tip somebody ditched a Thompson up at the top of Mulholland Drive. It ain’t filed. Guess what? It was stole from Strike Command Headquarters at MacDill, about a year ago.”
“So?”
“You’re not sharp this afternoon, Joe. MacDill is at Tampa. In my book that’s a lot of Tampa.”
“So it seems.”
“Heard from Anglich?” he said sharply.
“Maybe he went back to Tampa. The population must have been depleted.”
“Uh-huh. Could be. Well, keep in touch.”

I told him I would. As I came out of the booth the little monster on the rocket got down briskly and aimed a businesslike kick at my ankle. He did it as if he’d kicked a lot of ankles in his time and had enjoyed the sensation. I shifted my foot just enough to let his shin connect with the edge of my shoe. He opened his mouth to let out a blat and a pregnant woman with limp black hair grabbed his arm and gave me a look like a curare dart. He kicked her in the leg and she slapped him hard enough to rattle the marbles in his pants pocket.
I had the feeling they deserved each other.
I got in my heap and headed out of there. The neighborhood was too rough for me.

Santa Monica Boulevard was full of the usual fast field of pecking-order rejects, gunning hard on the straightaways and chewing their steering wheels at the lights, hurrying home to take out the day’s accumulation of bad temper on their wives. They thinned out after the freeway and I made time on the empty stretch past the airport and the cemetery. The sun was dead ahead, the color of a brush fire but without heat. I turned left on Lincoln, crossed Ballona Creek, and zigzagged over to the beach.

The surf wasn’t running; in any case it was too late in the day for the beautiful people who spend their time between welfare checks waiting around the beach to be discovered by the movie scouts. The rumpled brown sand was as empty as an unmade bed; it looked tired and dirty, like an arena after the bullfights are over. The ocean was the color of old dishwater, sloshed up on shore by a careless scrubwoman. An airplane banked in tiredly against the purple evening clouds, lining up for final approach to L.A. International, like a weary sea bird at the end of a long crossing.

The houses and motels thinned out. I passed a public beach and a stretch of vacant land with real estate agents’ signs planted every hundred feet. On a rising bluff ahead a sign peeped into view among trees; scrawled neon letters spelled out The Blue Dahlia through a light mist.

I swung in between massive white pillars with peeling stucco and drove back under the big Monterey cypresses and parked next to a high, white-painted frame building that had probably been a nice place to spend a weekend as a house guest sixty years ago.
There were lights on on the high porch that ran all the way around three sides. Tables were set up on the porch with metal-legged chairs leaning in against them.
A single carriage lantern beside the walk gleamed on a strip of dull red carpet that ran up the center of the wide steps. Dull gay deck paint shone wetly with the mist as I crossed the porch.

The door was standing open, propped with a gilded brick. Inside were dim lights, more stacked chairs, a curve of bar, an illuminated clock with a beer ad. A big man detached himself from the shadows and drifted into my path.
“Not open yet, bud,” he said indifferently. “Come back around eight.”
I stopped. It was that or walk over him.
“London around?”
He looked me over. With the light behind him all I could see was a wide face on a short neck above shoulders like the foothills of the Rockies.
“Who should I say is asking?”
“The name wouldn’t mean anything to him.”

Another long pause. He was a man who thought before speaking. He said, “Wait here,” and moved off into darkness. A door at the back opened and closed. Some time passed. Cars went by on the road. The clock back of the bar said seven-thirty. Then it said seven-forty. I walked back to the door the big man had gone through and pushed it open on a passage with yellow wallpaper going up to a high cornice. Wall brackets that had once been gas fixtures held candle-shaped bulbs that gave a weak yellow light. More light leaked under a closed door down the hall. Faint gurgling sounds came from behind it. I opened the door and walked in.

Rex London sat behind an old oak desk that had been painted over with a reddish varnish that was somebody’s idea of the mahogany look. It had been quite a few years since last we’d met. He was a little leaner, a little hollower under the cheekbones than when I’d seen him last. Some of the sleek, sharp-tailored gloss was gone, along with some of the hair. He was in the act of pouring himself a shot from a large bottle of Cutty Sark. He jerked when he saw me and spilled a little.
“You ever heard of knocking?” he barked, and put the bottle away quickly, as if he was afraid I’d ask for a drink.

I swung a leather-backed chair away from the wall so that it half faced the door and sat in it. He fingered the shot glass, staring at me; he lifted it suddenly and tilted it down his throat, took a tissue from a box and wiped his mouth. I looked around the room, at chintzy wallpaper with water spots, at the cheap, stiff curtains on the big double-hung window, at the brown filing cabinet and the rug that showed unfaded patches where other furniture had stood once.

“Not like the old days, Rex,” I said. “No chromium doorframes, no milk glass in the foyer, no little Spanish orchestra behind a carved screen, no fine crimson steps down to the oval dance floor. Not even the carnation in the lapel. You’ve slipped, pal.”
“You’ve aged,” he said sourly. “What do you want, Shaw?”
“Seen Miss Prendergast lately?” I said politely.
London’s face clamped shut like a slammed book. His eyes got sharp and angry. He reached under the desk and thumbed something, sat back glaring at me.
“I thought so,” I said. “When was she here last?”
A side door opened and a tall, rangy man in a white shirt and high-waisted pleated slacks came through it. He halted with his eyes on me.
“Yeah, boss?” he said in a rather high, husky voice.
“Throw this grifter out, Elmer.”
The rangy man’s mouth twitched; he jerked a thumb over his shoulder. “Up and out, Jack. Let’s go.”

I didn’t move. He made a sound in his throat and stepped in and threw a swift right hook at my head. I was balanced for it; I leaned right and took the wrist he’d offered me and came up out of the chair and dropped my left arm over his biceps. I locked the wrist behind his elbow and ran him forward, continuing the momentum of his swing. His head hit the wall hard enough to dislodge a framed liquor license, which shattered on the floor. Elmer fell on top of it. As I turned London’s hand was just coming out of the drawer. He showed me a .32 Walther with almost an apologetic air. I walked around the end of the desk and took it out of his hand and threw it in the wastebasket.
“Let’s not waste time, Rex,” I said. “You didn’t want to shoot anybody. I just came out for a little talk-talk.”
“I’ve got nothing to say to you, Shaw.”
“Sure you have. You’d lots rather chin with me than have your loan called down at the sheriff’s office. We were talking about Miss Prendergast.”
“What’s the sheriff got to do with anything? My hands are clean, you’ve got nothing on me. I welcome investigation by the Sheriff’s Office or anybody else.”
“The sheriff will do. OK if I use your phone?” I reached for it. His hand got there first.
“Wait a minute, Shaw. What’s this about? Why are you making waves?”
I went back and sat down in my chair. Elmer snored peacefully on the rug. London’s eyes stuck to me like banderillas, watching me light a cigarette and drop the match on the floor.
“Miss Prendergast,” I reminded him gently.
He grimaced and made a chopping gesture. “That dame’s nuts,” he said suddenly. “Completely out of her mind.”
“That so?”
“Listen―the last time I saw that fool female she came in here waving a gun. At me! She could have blown my head off!”
“Why didn’t she?”
He picked up his shot glass and squeezed another drop from it. “I managed to convince her she was off base. God knows how. She ought to be locked up.”
“What was it about?”
“She had some screwy idea I was mixed up in some kind of shady deal with her uncle. A lot of damned nonsense. I tell you she was raving.”
“Where did she get that idea?”
He waved a hand. “How would I know? Where do screwballs get their screwball ideas?”
“You know the uncle?”
“I’ve seen him a few times.”
“Here?”
“Maybe. What’s all this to you, Shaw? Did that damned girl hire you to come out here?”
I shook my head. “Tell me a little more about this deal you weren’t in on,” I said.
He chewed his teeth and wrinkled his face at me. “All I know is what she was saying. Why don’t you ask her?”
“I’m asking you.”
“Well . . . she had some nutty idea I was in touch with some hoodlums, hired muscles.” His voice had dropped to a mutter. “I was supposed to be lining them up for Frank. For Mr. Prendergast, I mean―”
“First name terms, eh? Go ahead.”

“According to her, her uncle was pulling some kind of monkeyshines. She talked about . . . killings.” He looked at the end of his shoe, at the filing cabinet, at Elmer’s open mouth, anywhere but at me.
“Past or future?”
“Future. Past. Both. I don’t know. Look here, Shaw―all this has got nothing to do with me, understand? I want no part of it!”
“How long ago was this routine with the gun?”
“A week ago tomorrow.” He turned to look at the wall calendar as he spoke; that kept him from seeing my jaw drop. I drew a breath and let it out and said, “Seen the papers?”
He got a good grip on his knuckles and cracked them with a sound like dry twigs snapping in a fire.
“Yeah.” His voice was a near whisper. “Accidental death. You can’t make anything of that.”
“Mrs. Prendergast hadn’t walked in years, Rex. She was found at the foot of a staircase. She had help getting there.”
His face had taken on a look like unbaked pastry. He shook his head. “Naw,” he said. “Naw, you’re on a bum lay, Shaw, you’re sniffing at the wrong tree, I don’t care what that dame said―”
“How long since you were in Tampa, Rex?”
“What? I was never in Tampa. Florida, you mean? Never.” He looked at me anxiously as if he was eager to field the next question.
“You know a couple of workers named Sid and Rosie?”
He shook his head emphatically.
“Done any business with Jaster lately?”
“Who?”
I reached across to snuff out my cigarette. “I take it you hadn’t seen her in a while.”
“Who? The Prendergast girl? Hell, I never saw her before in my life.”
“That so?” I hoped it sounded casual. “You used to be seen around a little with one of the Prendergast girls.”
“That was Mianne. I took her out a few times. It never came to anything. Let’s face it: she’s out of my class.”
“Such modesty. I hear she was a little wild.”
“Who, Mi Prendergast? Nonsense. She wasn’t a bad kid at all.”
“I heard her old man disapproved of her carryings-on.”
“I wouldn’t know. I never saw the old buzzard.”
“And now Miss Ellen comes in waving guns at you. That makes you acquainted with the entire Prendergast family―the survivors, that is.”

“Go on―build something on it,” he said tiredly. “Get the sheriff’s boys down here to bounce me around and pry the backs off the cigarette machines and clean out the bar stock and grind cigar butts into the carpet I just paid seven bills to have put in wall to wall. I can’t tell them any more than I’ve told you, Shaw. That’s all there is.”

I played with his nervous system a few more minutes and then left, with Elmer still earning his pay on the rug. I felt a little mean for some reason. The big boy was leaning against the carriage light at the foot of the front steps. He moved partly into my path as I came down.
“Find Rex OK?” he said.
“We decided to make a night of it,” I said. “I’m just going out for chow mein.”
“A comic, huh? You want to get me fired?”

“Don’t worry, Tiny,” I said. “They’ll be shooting The Bride of King Kong one of these days. All you have to do is let your pelt grow.” I put a hand on his chest and eased him aside. He let me get away with it. I don’t know why.
I found a parking space fifty feet from the entrance to the Dockweiler. As soon as I stepped through into the lobby I knew something was wrong.

The elevator was grounded with the door open. The operator, a slim kid with pinched eyes, in pale green and tarnished gold, caressed an acned jaw with a white-gloved forefinger, watching a heavy man in a brown suit who leaned on the desk talking to a man I had never seen before. A couple of permanent residents―old men in vaguely shabby suits and high-top shoes―muttered together under the dusty rubber plants. As I crossed the lobby, the man talking to the clerk turned to stare after me.
“Where’s Stan?” I asked the kid. “I thought he went off at eight.”
He gave me a scornful look and didn’t move from his pose.
“In Holy Cross Hospital―not expected to live.”
I felt a cold sensation in the stomach that was not a result of the draft from the elevator shaft.
“Shot?” I said.
He gave me a slow ankles-to-neck check-out. “You said what?”
“He was OK this morning. I didn’t figure it was a wasting disease.”

He sneered at me and turned to look across at the brown man, who had levered himself off the desk and was coming across toward me, giving me one of those penetrating glances that’s supposed to take in everything but the monogram on your undershorts. He stopped in front of me and looked at where the carnation in my lapel would be if I had a carnation in my lapel.
“Visiting somebody?” he said in a voice like Buster Keaton’s expression.
“Maybe. Why?”
He flipped back his coat with an indifferent gesture, giving me a quick flash of a badge pinned to the inside pocket.
“Want to show me some identification?” he said in the same monotone.
“Why? I don’t want to cash a check.”
He sighed, made a move as if to clamp his fingers on my arm. I blocked that with my hip and said, “I’d like a longer look at the buzzer; I missed that sixth digit.”
He blew some bad breath on my face and said, “Parkington, out of the sheriff’s office. Don’t get funny, guy. Who are you?”
I got out my wallet and showed him my license.
“Shaw, huh? I heard about you. Nothing good.” He jerked his eyes upward. “Who you going to see?”
“Why does the sheriff want to know?” He pushed a little against me and I pushed back. His face turned pink around a pair of ears the color and texture of pickled pig’s feet.
“On account of there was a guy come down pretty sick here this afternoon, smart guy, that’s why.”
“He was asking for him, chief,” the elevator boy said quickly.

“Aha.” Parkington’s hand shifted toward his belt. He must have forgotten he wasn’t pounding a beat anymore, with a pair of bracelets handy. He shifted the motion to a pat on the bulge of paunch under his coat and hitched up his pants. He smelled of denture cleaner and un-cleaned dentures.
“Let’s you and me go in the office and talk,” he said, and started to turn away.
“This an arrest?” I said to his back. He whirled. His eyes had a red-edged look, like a boar at bay.
“By God, you’re asking for it, fella!”

“And you’re just the boy that can give it to me, hey, Partington? The padded sap, the night stick in the kidneys, the kick back of the knee, the bright lights and the no sleep and the unheated cell with no furniture and yesterday’s puke on the floor. Only you forgot one thing. The sheriff is a pal of mine. Tie that one, chum.” I gave him my second-best smile, the one with the edge like a rusty razor.
Various parts of his face twitched in various directions, trying out expressions. He settled for a look like a crocodile with an undigested missionary inside him.
“Aw, g’wan, beat it before I get mad.”

“Gosh, I bet that would be a sight to see,” I said. I stepped in the car and jerked a thumb at the ceiling, said “five.” The boy clashed doors, not looking at me. He leveled off roughly, flung the doors open.

“Wait,” I said. I went along to 507 and rapped lightly. No answer. I rapped harder, then tried the knob. Locked. There was a soft rustle behind me. I came around fast and the elevator boy was there, bouncing a pass key on the soiled palm of his glove. He gave me a sly grin.
“Key rental’s a sawbuck,” he said, and tossed the key up. I snatched it out of the air and jammed it in the lock and went in. The bed was made, the dresser bare, the closet empty.
“Looking for anything special?” the boy said behind me.
“How long’s she been gone?”
He let his mouth sag open and looked up into the corner of the room. He made a Stepin Fetchit routine of scratching his narrow head.

“Well, lessee. I come on at five, and I don’t rightly recollect seeing anybody check out of 507. Not as far as I can remember.” He looked at me and grinned a droop-lidded grin. “For five maybe I could remember better.”

I moved toward him casually and shot out a hand and got a wad of green wool and lifted and rammed him back against the wall. “Thanks for fingering me,” I said. “Now tell it. Leave off the trimmings. Just the bare facts. What time and who with.”
He spat and tried to kick me. I leaned on him and rattled his head against the wallpaper. “Talk it up, Slim.”
“G-g-go to hell,” he croaked.
I leaned harder. “Better spill, junior. I have that fine, careless feeling tonight. I want to hear the sound of voices. So many of the boys aren’t with us any more.”
He flopped and beat his hands against the wall. His eyes goggled at me. He made gurgling noises. I slacked off.
“Half past six,” he squeaked. “My God, I can’t breathe.”
“Breathe later,” I said. “Keep talking.”
“A guy checks her out. A old bird, snappy dresser.”
“Who else?”
“Nobody. Just him.”
“When did Stan get sick?”
“After lunch.”
I pushed him away; he scuttled a few feet and jerked his uniform into line, smoothed his hair.
“The lady a friend of yours?” he said, and squinted one eye at me, cocky again.
“How much did he pay you?”
“Who, me? Go soak your mush, chump.” He dodged back as I went past him toward the door. I took a dollar out of my wallet and tossed it his way; he snatched it and lifted his lip at me.
He trailed me to the elevator, rode me down in silence. At the bottom he leaned against the door and gave me a heavy-lidded look.
“Wife?” he said.
“Why?”
“You got problems, mister.” His voice gloated. “The guy’s got something on her. When he talks, she jumps.”
“All that for the same buck?” I said, and pushed the button that whooshed the doors open.
“Hey,” he said after me. “You forgot to pay for the key.”
“Sue my estate,” I said, and breezed on out. Partington glared at me from his hiding place back of a plastic palm tree, but no whistles blew.
I saw two gray Volkswagens on Sunset, but I was too tired to care.

It was after nine when I got home. I telephoned Holy Cross Hospital and asked after Stan Fellows. After two or three ricochets off the switchboard I was connected with a thin, impatient voice that identified itself as Dr. Aylesworth.
“Fellows, yes. A very sick man, but he’s off the critical list.”
“No possibility of talking to him tonight?”
“None whatever. Who is this?”
“A friend, Doc, just a friend. Not a bill collector. He was taken sick pretty suddenly, I understand.”
“It’s a variant strain. Very swift in its effects. Not quite so toxic, however, as the eighteen-hour variety of botulism.”
“You said botulism?”
“Certainly. It still occurs, usually as a result of misguided efforts at home canning.”
“What was it he ate, Doctor?”
“Tuna salad. Dangerous stuff at the best of times. I suggest you call back in the morning and speak to the ward nurse.”
I said I would and hung up. “Botulism, huh?” I said to the shadows in the corners of the room. “But tuna this time.”

I dialed the Prendergast residence. Nobody home. At least nobody answering the telephone. I sat for a few minutes communing with myself, but it was pretty dull company. Maybe a drink would help. I had one, and another one to keep it from being lonely. There were some odds and ends in the refrigerator. I ate them and had a third drink. Life began to loosen up a little. I hummed a little ditty as I showered and shaved and came back out and made another drink. Good idea. Why didn’t it occur to me sooner.
The phone rang. I grabbed it as if I was expecting good news.
“Glad to have caught you at home, Mr. Shaw.” It was Frank Prendergast, sounding glad to have caught me at home.
“How are things?” I said.

“Fine, fine. I was just calling to tell you that Ellen’s home. I hope you didn’t go to any great trouble on account of my rather overdramatic comments this morning. However, I’m sending along my check for one thousand dollars in any event.”
“That’s big of you, Mr. Prendergast. You say she’s home?”
“With me, I should say, in Las Vegas. I thought it best to take her away for a while, under the circumstances.”
“Where are you staying?”
“I hardly think that information is pertinent, Mr. Shaw. As I was saying, Ellen had taken a room in a rather unsavory hotel. She thought better of it, and telephoned me. I picked her up quietly.”
“Uh huh. May I speak to her?”
“Certainly not. I don’t want her further disturbed.”
“I see. Plan to tell the cops?”
“They’ve already been informed,” he said, with an inch of ice on top. “They were quite satisfied for Ellen to remain in my care.”
“That’s kind of unusual, Mr. Prendergast. A murder―”
“Inasmuch as the police have the matter in hand I hardly think you need concern yourself further, Mr. Shaw.”
“I’d like to see you, Mr. Prendergast. There are a couple of points we ought to go over―”
“Out of the question. I intend to be out of town for some weeks. Possibly we’ll take a cruise.”
“Mianne with you?”
“Yes―not that it concerns you. You may consider the matter closed, Mr. Shaw.”

I said, “Yes, but,” and the phone clicked and the dial tone was wavering in my ear. I hung up and sat looking at the phone. That, it seemed, was that. Miss Ellen was a girl who could invade The Blue Dahlia and threaten to blow a hole in a man on Monday, and on Tuesday be a shy little maid cutting roses in the garden. In the morning she could be scared to death of her big, bad uncle, but by teatime she was calling him to bail her out. A changeable girl, Miss Ellen.

I washed a few dishes, rearranged the four cans of beer and the three eggs and the bacon in the refrigerator, set out a chess problem on the coffee table, and then went and stood at the window and watched the street lights shining up through the pepper trees along the curb. The phone rang. I picked it up and somebody cleared a throat at me.
“On the Prendergast kill,” Pincus’ clotted voice said. “Anything new?”
“Which one?”
“Hah?” There was a moment of near silence in which I could hear the Pincus brains straining at the harness.
“Oh, I get it. Another nifty. Save it, Shaw. You can close your books on this one. Me and Dreyfus got it doped.”
“That’s nice. Who did it?”
“Huh? Look, wisey, how do we know who done it? But we got the motive. Prendergast’s wall safe was open.”
“Go on.”
“What more do you want? Some boxman with more guts than brains watched the house until it’s clear, then goes in to work.”
“What about the burglar alarms?”

“What burglar alarms? The front gate’s wired, that’s all. And he don’t use that. So OK, he’s inside working and old Mrs. P. lets out a squawk, so he’s a little nervous on account of it being daylight and he croaks her. Maybe it’s an accident. Then he tosses her downstairs to make it look like she done it without help. He’s a stranger, so he don’t know she’s a cripple. You show up about then, and he outfoxes you down the back stairs, saps you down, and drives off in his car, which he parked next door on account of there’s nobody home.”
“Why was the gate open over there?”
“ ‘Cause some guys was working on the furnace and they left it that way. Some guys are like that. Careless.”
“How does Mr. Prendergast like the theory?”
“Him? He’s nuts about it. By the way, the daughter turned up, so you can scratch that angle.”
“Back home, huh?”
“Take a tip. Shaw―lay off the Prendergasts. They ain’t home anyway. The whole family flew over to Vegas. I guess Mr. Prendergast feels like we done all we could. So be a sweet guy and leave it lay.”
“I see. Well, thanks for clearing that up. Now I can get back to my cocoa and macaroons.”
He said, “Hah!” and hung up. I sat holding the phone for a few empty seconds.

“Well, that’s it, Shaw,” I said aloud. “Everything’s worked out to everyone’s satisfaction―except maybe Mrs. P. and Lou Anglich and a certain out-of-work gumshoe.” I wandered back into the kitchen, still talking to myself. This morning Miss Ellen had seemed like a girl with a problem, and for a while there it had looked like something might be getting ready to give; but a few lonely hours in a grubby hotel room had corrected her thinking. There’d been a small tragedy in the family, but everyone was doing nicely now, thank you, Mr. Shaw. A few weeks on the high seas would soothe away the wrinkles in everyone’s dispositions with no need of any hired snoopers probing around and making things unpleasant. So get back to your dreary routine, Mr. Shaw. And don’t forget to open the mail before throwing it away, because Uncle Frank’s grand will be in there somewhere, a well-earned reward for keeping your nose clean.

Of course that left a few loose ends like a missing client named Anglich; but I had his locker key in my safe. If he didn’t turn up in a reasonable time I could always devote the suitcase full of cash to a worthy charity―such as the Joe Shaw Retirement Fund.

The doorbell dinged. Nice timing, whoever you are. Mr. Shaw is at liberty. He’s no longer working on the Prendergast case, because there isn’t any Prendergast case. And he’s not working on the Anglich case because there isn’t any Anglich.
I went over and yanked the door open, ready to buy a denture brush or enter a five-year subscription to The American Girl if that was what it took to reestablish contact with the human race.
There was nobody there. I stuck my head out in the hall. Nobody there either. Maybe the door to the fire stairs was still swinging and maybe not. I wasn’t in the mood for chasing anybody.
A fat envelope lay on the scuffed carpet at my feet. I picked it up and went back inside and held it up to the light and then tore the flap open and took out two pieces of paper.

They were birth certificates, a bit yellowed at the edges, both dated May 27, 1942. One attested to the advent of Maria Guadalupe Prendergast, in Tampa, Florida. The other recorded the birth of her twin sister, Elena Guadalupe. Both included sole prints of the right foot. Twin girls, named Prendergast. Mianne and Ellen didn’t look alike, but then there are such things as non-identical twins. So that settled that.

I probed in the envelope and fished out a piece of paper. It was a sheet of cheap linen-finish stationery, the kind you buy in pads from the five and ten. On it an unlettered hand had scrawled, with several erasures:

AJ left enclosed with me for safekeeping. Since I bow out of the case I bow all the way out. Believe me, I hold out nothing. All the way out is where I want to be. PS I was ribbing you about the fifty. AJ leave nothing for you, only some dirty shirts at my place. Some way to say so long to a pal.

I read the note over twice but it still seemed to say the same things. So much for the adoption theory. I looked at the birth certificates some more. The father was Harvey Prendergast, the mother Consuelo Guiterrez Prendergast. I folded the papers twice and took them in the bedroom and locked them in the allegedly fireproof lock box I keep on the closet shelf and went back to the telephone.
Morry Blumenthal was still on his desk at the Independent. He yawned in my ear and said, “Yeah, what about Harvey Prendergast?”
“His wife’s full name.”
“Check the obit, Joe. Never mind. I’ll do it myself.” I listened to scuffling sounds, like a mouse in a wastebasket.
“Yeah. Marion Prendergast, nee Hartley.”
“Anything on a previous marriage? Him, I mean.”
“That old kipper? I’m surprised he ever had enough vital juices flowing to manage one proposal―and I’ll bet that one was a masterpiece of poetry.”
“See if the name Consuelo pops up.”
“Aha. South of the border. Oke, I’ll see what I can dig. But don’t let your burial insurance lapse while you wait.”
“I’ll be right here.”

While I waited, I looked at the photostats some more. The names and dates were as I remembered them. Mother’s age, twenty-seven. Father’s age, twenty-five. Well, some men need a mother. As Miss Mianne had said, it was hard to picture Daddy ever being that young. I held the paper under the lamp and the figure still read twenty-five.
It took me that long to get it. Shaw, one double-take.
In 1942 Harvey Prendergast had been fifty if he’d been a day. A man with a certain kind of vanity might shade his age a little, but not by a factor of two.
So Harvey Prendergast wasn’t the father. Not my Harvey Prendergast. I reached for the phone and it rang.

“Surprise, I turned up something,” Blumenthal said, sounding a little pleased with himself, as if the old backhand was still in shape after all. “Passport application, dated 1938. Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Prendergast. He didn’t marry Marion until ‘forty-three.”
“Children?”
“How’d you guess?”
“Two girls,” I said. “Twins.”
“You should have quit while you were still playing the house’s money. One offspring, male.”
“You still there?” he said after a long pause. I got my jaw shut and said, “Uh-huh. No chance of an error, Morry? I’d like two daughters a lot better.”
“Hell, why call me if you got no confidence? One son. No daughter. Definitely not two daughters. Not in 1938, anyway. Funny at that, I never knew he had a son.”
“Maybe he died young.”
“Not too young. He was nineteen in 1938.”
“OK―try this for size: the kid’s name was Harvey, just like his pa.”
“Aw, you peeked.”
“See if you can dig up anything else on the boy or the first wife. By the way, her name would be anything but Consuelo.”
“It was Alma June. You couldn’t get much farther from Consuelo than that.”

I hung up and had a quick drink to ward off head colds. It was also good for snake bites. I had one more, in case of snakes. I capped the bottle and got up and did two brisk laps of the room and sat down and went back into conference.

So Harvey had a son, and the son married a Latin-type lovely older than himself, who produced twin girls. The girls wound up in an orphanage, reason unknown, and parents drop from picture. Enter Frank Prendergast. There were reasons now why he’d be on the scene. Not clear reasons, but at least a framework for reasons to be hung on. He was the uncle. He’d have a natural interest in his nieces. Maybe old Harvey had sent him East to bring his grandchildren home. Maybe . . .
I got a firm grip on the thought, not squeezing too hard.

Maybe one of the girls had already been handed over to foster parents. Foster parents named Conroy. Which would explain why somebody calling himself an uncle would pay ten quiet grand for the child. Naturally, Grandfather Harvey would prefer a matched set of grand-children.
But Pate had told Anglich it was little Anya the Conroys had taken; and he’d given him Harvey’s picture.

Anglich had mentioned that he’d had to squeeze Pate a little. Could be with a man like Anglich squeezing, a man like Pate might blurt out anything, might mention the first name that came to mind, might even hand over an old photo that might be lying around for possible future use, anything to get those big thumbs out of his neck.

And then afterward, thinking it over, a man like Jaster might get to thinking, might start weighing consequences, might start getting ideas. He might even change his name and up-stakes and move West―just in case Anglich came around wanting his money back. He might check out the Prendergast angle, smell money, make a few moves, and see money coming in.
But ail that would be threatened when a familiar face from the past popped up again.

It would have given Jaster lots to think about when he saw Anglich, lots of new angles to figure. He had trailed him to my office and then called me, checking to see what he could milk from the situation.
And then someone had come along and called all his bets. All but the ace in the hole.

Pate/Jaster had had enough cunning to stash the photostats with a friend. And I had pushed the right button, and the friend had passed them on to me, not wanting to come down suddenly with the same malady that had swept Jaster away with such unseemly haste.
It sounded good―or at least possible. But there was still something I wasn’t seeing.

The girls were Harvey’s granddaughters, whom he had adopted, and passed off as his own. What was there in that that would bring Uncle Frank out in a case of hives? That would get Jaster and Mrs. Prendergast killed―and maybe Harvey too, if there was anything in the planted botulism angle?
Nothing―except that we seemed to be one child short.
There had been two Prendergast infants, plus Lou Anglich’s Anya. Now there were just the two Prendergast girls.
But what if it wasn’t Anya that was missing? Maybe she was here, and had been here all along―under the name of Prendergast.

Maybe Frank hadn’t been able to turn up a matched set after all. So he had done the next best thing and found a substitute. Pate had tipped him to a child of the right age, with no records behind her, no embarrassing birth certificate―and he had rung her in on brother Harvey. For which no doubt Harvey had paid handsomely. Enough to give the Conroys ten Gs and still have enough to make ends meet.
Until the years passed and times got tough and it seemed appropriate to tap Harvey again.
Only Harvey died.
The last thing Frank would have wanted was to cut off his income. So the dirt that Ellen had on him was something else entirely.
Shaw, one dead end.
The phone rang.

“Oke, here it is,” Morry said. “Christ, I don’t know why I do these things. It must be I’ve got a lovely character. Harvey, Jr., was a hell-raiser. He and the old man fell out. He cut him out of his will, just like you read in those old novels. Junior had a couple of minor scrapes and went East. Something was said about the Merchant Marine. That’s the last that was heard from him. Alma died in ‘forty-two, same year Junior split. Prendergast was away for a year, came back here in ‘forty-three with a new wife and started over. Acquired daughters the next year, or so it seems. That part’s pretty vague. No birth certificates on record around here.”
“You forgot the mole on his left hip. Disinherited, huh? Officially?”
“Hell, he put it in the paper. No longer responsible for debts, the whole schmear―and I do mean schmear. If the kid had had any reputation what the old man left of it wouldn’t stuff a pipe.”
“Thanks, Morry. Let me know when you want a body found. I’ll give you my professional rate.”
“OK if I specify the body? Oh―by the way . . . “
I waited.
“I found a little item on the brother, Frank. Interested?”
“Go ahead.”
“A little trouble out here, in ‘thirty-nine. Arrest for assault with a deadly weapon. Got off on a nolle prosequi.”
“Go ahead. Spill the rest of it.”
“Oh, yeah. The victim was his brother, Harvey.”
“Nice fellows, the Prendergast boys.”
“Yeah. Will it be OK if I knock off now, boss? My wife thinks I should come home in time to go to the office in the morning.”
I held the button down and then dialed the hospital. Stan Fellows was still incommunicado. I had a drink and tried to think of somebody else to call, but no names leaped to mind.
It was after twelve and the bottle was empty when the phone jangled again. I groped it off the hook. A crisp voice that didn’t want any back talk asked me if I was Mr. Shaw.
“I think so,” I said. “Just a minute while I check.”
“I am Mrs. MacDougall, at Holy Cross Hospital. A patient―a Mr. Fellows―wishes to speak to you urgently.” Her tone implied she couldn’t imagine why.
“How is he?”
“Mr. Fellows is not yet out of danger. Kindly don’t excite him.”
“That’s jake at this end, lady,” I said. “I’m under sedation myself.”
She gave a ladylike snort and went away and a thin splinter of Stan’s voice said, “Joe, I let you down. But it hit me like a dropped piano. I’ve been worried―”
“Stan―where did you get that tuna sandwich?”
“From the drugstore in the lobby.”
“You bought it yourself, personally?”
“No; Chick, the hop, fetched it around.”
“Stan, did Miss Smith make any calls while you were on?”
“Nope, not a one, Joe. I would have called―”
“Who took over for you at the desk?”
“That would be Wally Frink.”
“Friend of yours?”
“I’d trust him with a buck―as long as I was holding one end of it. Don’t tell him anything you don’t want the corner newsboy peddling an hour later.”
I wished him well and gave him back to Mrs. MacDougall and rang up the Dockweiler, asked for the desk. A sharp little voice that would never miss an implied slur answered. I asked for Frink.
“Speaking.”
“My name is Shaw, Mr. Frink. I’m a friend of Stan Fellows. I understand you took over for him yesterday.”
“That’s right. I’ve been on duty almost twelve hours already, and the rest of the night to go. What about it?”
“Can you tell me if a Miss Smith, registered in 507, made any calls before she checked out?”
“You with the police?”
“Private,” I said. “I checked Miss Smith in―”
“Look, fellow, this isn’t that kind of hotel. And if it was it’s not our policy to divulge information on our guests.”
“You’ve gotten the wrong impression, Mr. Frink. As I said, I’m a private investigator. Miss Smith is my client. She checked out unexpectedly and I need―”
“That’s none of my affair.”
“All right, Frink,” I said the way they say it around a cold cigar. “I know where you live. Don’t make me get tough.”
“Wha-a-at did you say?” It was a yap like an indignant Peke.
“And I know all about Chick,” I added.
That netted me some silence.
“Give, Frink. Any calls, yes or no?”
“I’ll check,” he said, and I could almost hear his teeth grit. He came back on the line.
“No.”
“That’s definite?”
“What did you mean . . . about Chick?” Cautious now.
“You know, Frink,” I said heavily. “You know.” and hung up. So Ellen hadn’t called Uncle Frank. But he’d known where to find her.

I picked up the phone and called a friend at the Desert Wind in Las Vegas. For once the direct dialing worked. He came on the line to an accompaniment of clattering slots and shrill laughter in the background.
“Nick, I want you to check something out for me. A Frank Prendergast is supposed to be spending a few days in the hell town with his nieces.” I gave him their descriptions.
“Hell, Joe, if I had a buck for every old coot in this town shacked up with a snazzy young brunette I could retire into some honest job like splitting twenties.”
“Check around anyway. He may be registered under his own name.”
He said he’d try and hung up.

I went back in the bedroom and dressed. I didn’t have any definite plans; I was just getting dressed. It seemed like the thing to do. I mixed another drink and sat for a while and stared at the chessboard. The pieces seemed to be waiting for something to happen. I knew how they felt. Outside, the wind was getting up. It made a busy, impatient sound in the trees under the window.
After a while the phone rang again. It was Nick Rassias.
“I find your party’s known here in a small way, Joe,” he said. “He’s a pigeon who drops respectable dough on occasion. But he hasn’t been around for some months.”
I thanked him and poured a small drink while I digested the data. Then I tucked the lock box under my arm and rode downstairs.
The Olds was waiting under the pepper trees where I’d left it. I drove to the office, went up just long enough to lock the papers in the safe, then headed west for Mayfair Heights.

No lights showed in the Prendergast house. I did my usual cagey trick of parking down the block and walked back. The wind tossed the trees, shook the hedges. Dry leaves scuttled along the sidewalk with a furtive sound. A big iron lock held the big iron gates. Half-concealed wires suggested that bells would ring at Headquarters if anyone tinkered with it. The wall to either side didn’t look promising. Uncle Frank would be just the boy to set broken glass in the top. I went back to the wooden gates, still latched open, and stood in the shadows long enough to let any policeman staked out nearby to get nervous and start creaking shoe leather.

Nothing happened, except that some clouds blew across the moon, making the shadows sharpen and then fade. I eased through, went up on the turf beside the hedge that bordered the Prendergast drive. The tunnel through it was all the way at the back, almost against the house; not obvious, but not too hard to find when you knew it was there. It had probably been a convenient route for a couple of generations of Delias and Jessie Mays with a yen for gossip or a companionable snort or a cup of sugar. I used it and was in the Prendergast car yard.

Miss Mianne’s El Dorado was there, looking sharklike and eager in the moonlight. All four garage doors were closed. No dim lights burned at obscure windows at the side of the house. I thought about the dog―Robbie―and his commando training. It gave the seat of my pants, not to mention my jugular, a vulnerable feeling. But if the family was away, the dog wouldn’t be roaming around loose. From the look of it, they hadn’t left any servants behind. Nobody here but us private detectives, out getting a little fresh night air.
I went once around the house, walking like Hiawatha sneaking up on a dozing moose, then jimmied the back door and went in.

There was enough moonlight to show me the kitchen, neat and orderly and big enough to serve up a banquet for an orgy of congressmen. It was kind of homey to be back. It was a room I had bled in―one of the many. I went across it and into the hall and sampled the night sounds there: some wind in the eaves, a creak or two, the thump of unpruned vines against the window―nobody-home sounds. I sniffed; there was a faint medicinal odor―not strange in a house where an invalid had just died. I went on along the hall, past the spot where I had last seen Mrs. Prendergast. Nobody there this time. I looked in the library, and the dining room. Everything neat, and very, very still. I checked the sunroom, where I had been parked the first time I’d come to call. The drapes were drawn; a thin line of silver moonlight lay across the hard rug. I parted the hangings and looked out at an empty terrace, black lawn, moonlight on the closed garage, the distant line of trees, proud and aloof as captive kings.

I went back to the hall and along to the kitchen and opened doors and found a pantry and a laundry and an equipment room and a neat little back stair almost as steep as a ship’s companionway. I went up it and emerged in a small room under the slant of the eaves, furnished with a narrow bed, a cheap dresser, an oval hooked rug, a bookcase with a few paperbacks and an ash tray, and empty wastebasket, and a small closet full of bent coat hangers. A door opened into a miniature bath with a sink, water closet, and a steel shower stall. Another door opened into the upstairs hall.
Obviously a servant’s room, but no servant in residence.

I tried doors along the hall. The first one was spacious, done in pale blue, with a big four-poster and gauzy curtains and a sitting room adjoining. It was the room where I’d seen Mianne brushing her hair just after the dog didn’t bite me. The adjacent room was locked. None of the gadgets I had with me opened it. I put an ear to the door and listened to some silence.

Mrs. P.’s room had been made up. I stared in at the big bed and sniffed the faint perfume that lingered there. Not really so faint at that, and not the same scent I remembered from my last visit. That bothered me a little, but not enough to phone anybody about.

The next room was Ellen’s. It looked a little untidy, as if it had been made up in a hurry. Well, it’s not every day a girl gets to go to Las Vegas or wherever Uncle Frank had taken her instead. She could be excused a little sloppy housekeeping. A small, lacy handkerchief lay on the floor beside the vanity. I picked it up, sniffed it, didn’t smell anything. I put it in my pocket. A Souvenir of Your Visit to the Prendergast Mansion. Why was I here? I didn’t really know. I seemed to be looking for something. Maybe I’d recognize it if I saw it. Or maybe not. I went on to the last room.
There was a desk, a dark rug, a single bed with a tailored spread in a chocolate brown, a rocker, a comfortable-looking brown leather chair, a small bar. Uncle Frank’s lair, no doubt.

A dozen or so suits hung in the closet, all with custom tailors’ labels. A row of highly polished shoes were on a rack below, plus a couple of shoe boxes he hadn’t gotten around to opening yet. I looked inside. They were full of the smell of new leather, plus the new leather itself.

I pushed aside a hatbox on the shelf and was looking at a featureless ovoid the size of a human skull. It was mounted on a chromium-plated shaft set in a walnut base. It was an item that might have saved some grief if I had seen it the first time I came snooping, but now it was just anticlimax.

I poked through Uncle Frank’s effects without finding any handwritten confessions tucked away in the drawers, no telltale jottings on the back of an envelope, no receipts from experimental labs for an order of contaminated lobster. Nothing you wouldn’t expect to find in the quarters of a luxury-loving old sponger taking it easy in the silk.

I stuck my head in a couple of bathrooms and a linen closet big enough to supply a couple of regiments, then went back down to the front hall and stood in the dark, listening for something, testing the air with the delicate Shaw antennae. There was a faint odor of furniture polish, a hint of cigarette smoke, a touch of perfume, the errant whiff of medicine.
Or possibly more than an errant whiff. I sniffed harder. I was right. It was more than a whiff. And it wasn’t medicine. It was chloroform.
