My gun got into my hand without me having much to do with it. I faded back against the wall as if to cut down the number of directions they could come at me from. Nothing else happened. The wind blew, the vines thumped at the windows, my heart beat.
Come on, Shaw, what’s a little chloroform? Maybe it’s not even chloroform. Maybe it’s cleaning fluid, or floor wax, or disinfectant. Maybe it’s your imagination. Maybe it’s those five drinks you had.
No, six―but who’s counting?

The still air stirred; the taint of chloroform was as distinct as a footprint in wet sand. It was coming from the direction of the kitchen. I went back, silent as a shadow, silent as a foreclosed mortgage, silent as an obituary column, silent as two deaf mutes at a seance. At least I didn’t fall over an umbrella stand. I edged the kitchen door open. A faint but distinct current of fresh air hit me in the face.

I closed the door to let the odor concentrate again. It was there, then it wasn’t there. I sniffed cautiously, like a man testing for poison gas. I didn’t smell a thing. And suddenly I was smelling it in a wave. I went toward it, toward a blank wall of dark paneling. I felt over it, tried a soft rap. It rang hollow. It took me another minute to find the latch. A wide door, with the top cut at an angle to fit under the stairs. The dark space behind it reeked of chloroform. There were cardboard boxes here, a mop rack, buckets, a vacuum cleaner and attachments, a shelf of soap powder and waxes. A patch of white on the floor at the back caught my eye: a piece of cloth, protruding from under the wall. That made it a second door. I found the knob and turned it. Chloroform came out in sickening waves. In the dark behind the opening, something moved. A dark shape half rose, launched itself at my knees. Teeth clicked, a heavy body sprawled past me. Claws scrabbled against the floor. A low growl rumbled and subsided in heavy panting.

I knelt beside the dog. His yellow wolf’s eyes moved, following me. There was no fear in them. He had saved what he had and used it all on one last try and missed. There was no more where that came from. He lay quietly on his side and waited for what came next.
“All right, Robbie,” I said softly. “Good boy, Robbie. You’re all right now, boy. Now you can breathe. Just work on it, boy. Everything’s OK now.”

Whoever had tried to kill the dog had been in just a little too much of a hurry. They’d gotten him inside, then tossed the rag in after him. It stuck in the door. That let in just enough of a draft at floor level.

The big dog’s tongue moved as if he wanted to swallow, but couldn’t quite make it. His front legs twitched hard once, and subsided. The eyes went vague and out of focus. The panting faltered. I reached out and put a hand on his side. Under the coarse hair and the curve of ribs I could feel a light, rapid pulse, like a trapped hummingbird.

“Come on, Robbie. Let’s go, boy.” I hooked fingers under the big horsehide collar and hauled him halfway to his feet. His forepaws made aimless paddling motions. His hindquarters were inert, a dead weight. I dragged him out into the hall and ten feet along it, then back. His panting was stronger. Or maybe I was just choking him to death. I got an arm under his barrel and one under his chest and lifted him. When I let go he collapsed, like a bag of wet laundry. He was a big dog. He must have weighed close to ninety pounds. He lay on his side and panted, not even looking at me now.

I went back in the kitchen and found the cooking sherry, poured some in a dish, brought it back and put it under his nose. That brought his head up an inch or two. His big rough tongue came out and spilled a little of the sherry around.

I tried the collar grip again, and we did a few more laps. His front legs seemed to be taking a little of his weight now, like a colt taking its first steps. I was feeling a little light-headed myself. The reek of chloroform was cloying as syrup.
“Fresh air, Robbie,” I said. “A nice walk in the fresh air. Let’s go, boy.”

I maneuvered him through the swinging door, across the kitchen, down the back steps. Going down, his rear quarters came to life enough to throw his weight against my legs and almost trip me. We had another rest and tried it again.

It was twenty-five paces to the garage. At the end of three round trips he was walking like a weekend drunk on his way to the men’s room to pass out. After another ten minutes I let him try it alone. He stood for a moment with his legs spraddled, tried a step, and went over sideways. But he was up again in the same motion, and went over the other way and lay there, panting. It was all a lot of damned foolishness. To hell with it. He lay and watched me, breathing better now, but still a lot of very sick dog. I got him on his feet again.

We walked and rested. The moon came out and took a look and went in again. Robbie walked, stumbled, caught himself, walked, fell, got up and tried it again. I sweated and changed hands on the collar and reached the garage doors and started back. How many laps? Say twenty. Call it seventy feet. That’s under a quarter of a mile. Keep going, Shaw. It’s tougher on Robbie than it is on you. One more lap. One more. And one more.

At the end of an hour he was walking unassisted. He weaved a bit, and his hindquarters still had a tendency to drop out from under him, but he was walking. I went back in and got our bottle, took a healthy swig, and poured another slug for Robbie. He drank it in a businesslike way and his tail tried a small wag or two. He looked around for more. He’d live.

“Who did it to you, boy?” I said. “Who wanted you dead? And why stuffed in a closet? That’s careless―very careless. Unless they were planning on coming back very soon to tidy up . . . .” Robbie lay down, and put his chin on his paws and his tail thumped the ground once or twice.
“Come on, Robbie, let’s go,” I said. He got to his feet and came over wobbling a little, and nosed the bottle hopefully.
“All right, just one,” I said. “Then we’ve got work to do.”
I drove over to Fountain, cruised along looking for a sign I remembered seeing stuck in a small front lawn, a veterinarian’s shingle.
I found it in the fourth block: a tan frame house with green-shingled gables. The sign read: Dr. I. L. Very. Veterinary Medicine. Office Hours 9―4.

There was a bright light on in the back room. I pulled in the drive and went around to a side door and worked a brass knocker. A dog yapped somewhere out back and a crabbed voice shushed him. Feet crossed a floor. The door opened inward and a dim little man with frameless glasses and a narrow head of wispy hair peeked out at me. He was wearing a dirty pale green surgeon’s smock with rusty stains on it.
“I’ve got a sick dog in the car,” I said. “OK if I bring him in?”
“Do you have any idea what time it is?” he said sharply. His voice matched his face; small, pinched, and expecting the worst.

“Swell; I’ll bring him in,” I said, and went back to the car. I had a little trouble getting Robbie on his feet. He lurched and leaned against me like a mild-mannered drunk. The vet watched us come, stood aside to let us in.
“It’s after ten o’clock,” he said. I could hear his fee going up from where I stood. I patted Robbie and he flopped down on the linoleum and looked dazed.
“What seems to be the trouble?” the little man said. He sounded reluctant to get involved.
“Somebody tried to chloroform him,” I said.
The dim little eyes got tight and sharp behind the pinkish lenses. They flicked toward the telephone on the wall over the kitchen table, back to me.
“That sounds like a matter for the police, Mr. . . . ..”
“Shaw. The police have a lot on their minds, Dr. Very. I walked him some and gave him a little sherry.”
“Sherry? Sherry? The dog?”
“Yeah. This dog right here, Doc. He still doesn’t feel good, in spite of the sherry.”
“How do you know?”
“He told me. Look, Doc―”
“I very much dislike being called ‘Doc,’ Mr. . . . .
“Shaw. Sorry, Doctor. Say, would it be OK if you took a look at the dog―while he’s still breathing, I mean? We can talk afterwards.”
“You’ll have to help me get him up on the table. I can’t handle an animal of that size alone.”
We lifted Robbie onto the table. Dr. Very looked at his eyes, handled his head some, stared into his mouth. He put a stethoscope to his ribs and frowned and moved it around. He examined his paws.
“He’s weak,” he said, as if someone might dispute the point.
I didn’t say anything.
“How did this happen?” He looked at me like a smalltown high school principal waiting for an explanation of the frog in the inkwell.
“I dunno, Doctor. I just happened along. He was locked in a closet. At first he couldn’t stand.”
“How long ago was this?”
“About an hour and a half. When I found him, that is. I don’t know how long he’d been in there.”
“Hummph. You came along just in time, I’d say. Fine animal. Worth good money, assuming he has papers.
Broken tooth.” He looked at me quickly to see if that netted any response.
“He broke it a long time ago. He used to be in the Army.”
Dr. Very got all set to be offended and I added, “In the K-9 Corps; you know.”
“Well, he’s a valuable dog. Where did you say this happened?” He sneaked a look at the brass tag on the collar. If his expression changed, I couldn’t tell it.
“Near here. How about giving him some oxygen?”
He shook his head. “Not necessary. He’ll be all right. I’ll give him a shot of atropine. He’ll sleep it off in a few hours.”

He twiddled with needles in an autoclave, filled one, picked a spot on the dog’s flank, and jabbed. Robbie paid no attention. Very put the needle away and wiped his hands and said, “That will be twenty-five dollars.”
I gave him the stony look. “For a shot of atropine?”
“That―plus my time . . . plus knowing to give him a shot of atropine.”
“Would that include kennel fees for a day or two?”
“I wouldn’t want any trouble,” Very said in a low voice. I looked at him casually and waited.
“There’s blood at the edges of the mouth,” he said, looking at my tie. “Not his blood.”
“Oh?”
“And there are fibers between his teeth, and adhering to his claws. Wool fibers, I suspect. Clothing, in other words.”
“Seems as though he may have bitten somebody, you mean.”
“An animal of this size and breed is quite capable of killing a man, Mr. Shaw.” Dr. Very wiped his forehead with the cuff of his smock.
“I see what you mean. But I didn’t find any bodies. Just the dog.”
“My fee doesn’t cover trouble with the police,” he said quickly.
“Sure not, Doc. Doctor. How much would trouble with the police run me?”
“One hundred dollars?” He said it in a tight-lipped murmur as if he didn’t want anybody to overhear it, even me.
“Thanks, Doc,” I said. “I’ll keep that in mind.” I paid and took the dog and left.

The streets were almost empty at that hour. I drove over to Santa Monica, cruised aimlessly west past closed stores as bleak as a pauper’s funeral, past all night cut-rate liquor stores as garish as a Chinese wedding, past used-car lots like elephant graveyards, as gay as a rainy day at the orphanage.

An orphanage in Florida, a long time ago. Three baby girls and a man named Pate. And out West, an aging Harvey Prendergast with a new wife, maybe regretting his break with his son, maybe learning of his grandchildren for the first time, maybe commissioning his brother Frank to find them and bring them back.

But one of the girls is missing, adopted or dead. So, with Pate’s help, a small substitution is made. Harvey acquires his family. Time passes. And one day Pate hits town. He knows things. He makes threats. He dies.
You’re doing swell, Shaw. Familiar ground, but let’s go over it just one more time.
Here’s Frank, sitting pretty. Here are the Prendergast heiresses, one of whom might not have been an heiress―might still not be―if the truth were known. Here’s Mrs. Prendergast.
Correction. Not any more. She died. And Ellen knows something that worries her uncle. She ran away, but she came back―maybe.
She hadn’t called Uncle Frank while Stan Fellows was on duty; maybe not at all.

I pulled over beside a lighted phone booth at the corner of a vacant lot and got out and shuffled through the book. I was lucky; the page I wanted was still there. Lieutenant Dreyfus was off duty, but Pincus came on, sounding peeved at being caught at the office at this hour―or at something.
“Frank Prendergast’s not in Las Vegas,” I told him. “I don’t suppose he gave you any alternate destination?”
“You mean so we can reach him in case we find out he’s lying? He must of forgot. Who says he ain’t in Vegas?”
“A friend of mine who’d know. I’d kind of like to get in touch with him in a hurry. Any ideas?”
“Yeah―keep the snoot out of the Prendergast case. There ain’t any―”

“I know. There ain’t any Prendergast case. Say, you might look into a case of botulism over at Holy Cross. Stan Fellows, day clerk at the Dockweiler. Seems he took sick suddenly―about an hour before Ellen Prendergast checked out.”
“The Prendergast dame, huh? Holding out again. You think she slips the guy something?”
“It’s an angle,” I said. “Well, you’ll have to excuse me now, Sergeant. I’ve got a big wash to hang out.”
I hung up with the feeling I’d blown my chance for some cooperation from the police. The problem seemed to be in just how to phrase my appeal:
“Say, fellows, I happened to be out burgling the Prendergast house and I found a chloroformed dog. And Uncle Frank wears a wig. So how about putting out an all-points on him and his niece.”
Of course I could just call up and tell them I had a funny feeling. Pincus could have some fun with that one.

I wasted another twenty minutes calling airlines and railroad reservations offices trying to find out if Frank and his nieces had bought any tickets under their own names. If they had, no one was letting on.

I started to step out of the booth and checked automatically as a car rounded the corner down the block. The headlights swept across a gray VW parked in the side street, facing the intersection. A head inside it ducked down just as the lights hit. The car went past, making noise from a rusted-out muffler. The racket faded; the street was dark and quiet again.
It was a temptation to leave the door open; with the light on I made such a tempting target. But I toed it shut and dropped a dime and dialed.

A voice that was tired of being tough told me Lacey wasn’t on the duty roster that night. Add a dime to the expense account. I dialed his home number. After ten rings somebody picked it up and fumbled the receiver and growled what might have been a greeting.
“Lacey, how long since I asked you a favor?”
“Geeze, don’t you guys ever sleep? Not since yesterday, anyway. Why?”
“I’m in a booth on Santa Monica, just west of Robertson. How soon can you get a carload of law over here?”
“Run into something you can’t handle alone? Good for you, boy, I thought the day would never come.”
“The years bring all things. In case the bird flies, it’s a gray VW, not too new, with a crease in the left front fender. I’m in my Olds.”
“Uh-huh. Any chance of you saying what it’s about?”
“It’s a swell pinch, Lacey. Don’t haggle.”
“I’ll see what I can do.”
I saw movement at the corner. “Hold it.” The VW was easing back out of sight, still showing no lights.

“Oh-oh. They smell something. Check with you later.” I racked the phone and sprinted for the car. Robbie was stretched out on the floor in back. He didn’t move as I got in. The car stank of chloroform. I cranked up and tooled away from the curb and up to the corner. No VW.

That put it up to them. I held it at thirty-five and drove west, watching the rearview mirror. At the second light I slowed with a lot of braking and turned left into Doheny. I made three blocks before they came into view in the mirror. I went on to Wilshire, turned right. Through Beverly Hills I speeded up. The VW closed to a block and a half. I gunned it again as the road split the golf course, followed the curves through Westwood, past the high hedges and the big comfortable dark houses. A few lights shone in the college buildings, far away behind trees.
On the straightaway through Santa Monica I boosted it up to fifty and held it. The VW dropped back. If there was anybody working me from ahead they were doing it with plenty of velvet.

At the beach I turned north, eased it up to sixty; they stayed with me, well back, but edging closer. Not yet, boys. Not here. Be patient. I’ll think of something. I pictured the road ahead, tried to remember the lie of the land. It had to be soon, before I got into the stretch north of San Vicente. I came on the spot before I knew it.

It was a small patch of county beach, pocketed between low bluffs, with too many rocks for surfing and too much cold wind for lovers, which was why it was county beach. I swung in, followed an access drive back a hundred feet to a blacktop parking lot drifted over with blown sand. I nosed the Olds up against the log barrier and cut the engine. I locked both doors and used the button to lower the window on my side six inches, then raised it an inch. That looked about right. I checked the magazine of the Luger, jacked a round into the chamber and clicked the safety off, tucked it under my thigh, out of sight.
Robbie lay quietly in the back; I spoke to him and he pricked up his ears. “Easy, boy,” I said. He closed his eyes. He’d had a long day.

I lit a weed and tried to look like a man who had sought out some solitude to think things over. A mosquito came and checked me out and went away again. The dash clock clicked, an impatient sound. Back up on the highway a car droned past. Down below the surf thudded monotonously. After a while there was another sound: the soft creak a shoe makes on dry sand.

A face slid into view at the window beside me. It was Rosie, the Cuban, and he was smiling. I smiled back and blew smoke at him and shook my head. He tried the door; it didn’t give. He lifted a small black gun of the kind you see in a police display of confiscated hardware and poked it at the glass, talking over it:
“You got company, palsy. Come on out and play.”
I slapped casually at an imaginary mosquito on my neck to cover a quick glance at the other window. Sid was standing back about six feet looking across the top of the car.
“Careful,” I said to the Cuban. “That’s bullet-proof glass.”

“You got a bullet-proof head, hijo?” He snarled and jammed the gun through the opening. I hit the button and the glass closed on his hand and the gun banged and a slug whined into the headliner. He yowled, and the gun bounced off the back of my seat. Robbie came up fast, growling. Sid made a noise and started around the front of the car; I scooped up the Luger and hit the horn button. Sid jumped six feet and landed facing me. His gun was halfway up; mine was aimed through the windshield at the spot where his eyebrows grew together.

His hands went up, still holding the flat automatic that looked like an Austrian Steyr. I soothed the dog over my shoulder, then pushed the door open, riding the Cuban back, and got out. Rosie cursed rapidly in Havana gutterese and yanked at his hand. I shoved the door shut. Robbie was down out of sight again.
“The wrist will give before the glass, amigo,” I told him. “Just relax.” I jerked the gun at the tall one. “Your arm gets tired holding it, Sid. Let it fall.”
He opened his hand and the automatic thudded in the sand.
“You made a bad mistake, bo,” he said in a voice from a haunted cellar. “We ain’t working solo.”
“Two bits you’re not working at all when word gets back how you handled this one,” I said. “Kick the gun behind you and put your hands in your pockets.”
“I’ll be there when they cut your neck,” the Cuban snarled, with a lot of saliva. “You squeal like a pig when the knife goes in.”
“You’d know, wouldn’t you, amigo? By the way, you ever find your chopper?”

He kicked at me and missed and lost his balance. His wrist made an ugly sound when his weight came on it. He screamed until he got his feet under him. The noise was thin and unimportant against the background of the surf. He leaned against the side of the car, breathing noisily through his nostrils.
“Your color’s not so good, amigo,” I said. “Maybe you don’t get out enough. Where’s your boss tonight?”
“Deal,” the man by the front of the car said in a hollow whisper. “We give you a clean bill. You go your way, we go ours.”
“Easy, huh?” I said. “When you hold cards, you win. When you don’t it’s a misdeal. Nice system―if you can make it work.”
“We don’t talk,” the Cuban gasped between his teeth.
“Let’s you give it a try, Dracula,” I said to the other one. “Who sent you punks out?”

Instead of answering, he put his head down and charged with his hands halfway out of his pockets. I clipped him above the ear and he hit the door jaw first and went down under the car. The impact hadn’t helped the Cuban’s wrist any. He was sprawled back across the hood, slack-jawed, half out on his feet, moaning.
“Shiner must be hard up for good boys,” I said. The Cuban stopped moaning and unpeeled himself from the car. He even managed a ghastly sort of grin.
“I’m sorry for you, peeper,” he whispered.

I got a grip on an ankle in a maroon sock and dragged Sid out where I could see him. He was out cold, but breathing well. I checked his pockets, then the Cuban’s. Their names were Sid Sidoris and Carlos Vaquez. They were both licensed drivers, and both had matches from a place called the Spezzia Club, a chisel-town dive. Rosie had a well-used leather sap on his hip. I tossed it in the car, lit another cigarette, and nudged the gaunt man with my foot.
“Sid needs his rest. Let’s you and me talk, Rosie. Where’s the girl?”
He drew a breath to spit at me and I doubled my fist and hit him hard under the ribs. He went to his knees and gagged. When he was through I said, “Where’s the girl, Rosie?”
“See c-can you m-make me talk, peeper.”
I grabbed his hair and dragged him to his feet and slammed him back against the car.
“You’re not getting the picture, Rosie. This is my turn at bat. That makes you do the talking. Now, you’re a pretty hard boy. Maybe Sid will give first. So why make it tough?”

He tried to knee me and I hit him again in the same spot. This time I didn’t let him go down. I held him up and grinned at him. “I can’t afford to let you stay clammed, Rosie; you can see that. It’s just one of those situations. Where is she?”
He was sagging, his legs splayed. Blood ran down from his hp where he’d bitten it. One tough Cuban. The gaunt man groaned and an outflung hand scratched at the pavement. I pushed Rosie away.

“Well, here’s Sid. Maybe Sid will want to tell me things. How about it, Sid?” 1 got a couple of handfuls of coat front and hauled him up and threw him back against the car. He hung on and breathed hoarsely. His eyes glittered at me.
Up on the highway, brakes squealed. The sound seemed to go on for a long time. Then a long, splintering crash, and sudden silence.

The gaunt man lurched away from the car and started to run. I hooked his ankle and laid the Luger against the side of his head. He dived forward and lay still. I went around to the other side of the car and rummaged in the glove compartment and brought out a set of GI bracelets. They made a bad fit on Sid’s ankle. I dragged him back and hoisted his leg up high enough to get the other cuff on Rosie’s good wrist.

A flashlight winked and bobbed on the drive. I faded back into the deep shadow of the sandbank. A man came across toward my car. The beam touched Rosie and Sid, held on them. I moved back, around the curve of the dune.

The VW was parked thirty feet away in the sand. The driver’s door was open. I flashed my pen-cell on the front seat and floor, then slid in back of the wheel to check the glove compartment. I found a much folded city map, another match folder from the Spezzia Club, a stack of gas receipts. Maybe the boys were on an expense account.

There was a leather jacket in the back seat. The pockets gave up a flattened packet of Cuban cigarettes, a dirty handkerchief, a brass key with a tag. On the tag, in faded ink in neat handwriting, were the words, beach house.
I tucked the key away and went back around the sandbank. A gun jabbed me in the side.
“Don’t shoot, officer, it’s just us chicken thieves,” I said.
“I thought I heard something,” Lacey said. “You’re lucky at that, boy; I could of been two other guys.”
“Sure―that’s why I took to the tall brush. How’d you find me?”

“Like I said―luck. I figured you to hold west. I came on out and gambled you was ahead of me. You cost the county some money tonight. Them other two guys I could have been are up on the highway picking their windshield out of their teeth. The poor boobs tried to curb me. Gunderson’s watching ‘em bleed.”
“The other half of the team. They worked me from in front. I never spotted them.”

We went over to the car and Lacey shone his light on the Cuban’s face. His eyes glistened almost sleepily under half-closed lids. Sid was lying on his face; the pants leg had slid down on his cuffed ankle, showing the white of his shin above the sock. He didn’t move.

Lacey gave me a sideways look. “Seems like these boys had an accident too.” He knelt beside the gaunt man and put his fingers into the side of his neck. He moved the head on the long neck. He grunted and stood, dusted off his knee. He didn’t look at me. I had a sudden chilly feeling that didn’t come from the sea air.
“Neck’s busted,” he said. “You must have been pretty riled at something, Joe.”
It was my turn to feel Sid’s neck. It was cool―too cool. There was no pulse. I dug my fingers in hard; there was still no pulse. I straightened and looked at the Cuban.
“Afraid he’d talk, eh, Rosie?” I said softly.
“I guess maybe you better come on in with me and Gunderson, Joe,” Lacey said.
“Sorry, Lacey. I’ve got a place to go first.”
“Want to tell me about it?”
“Would it change anything if I did?”
Lacey sighed. He yanked the big service revolver out of his belt and stood with it pointed at the ground.
“He was breathing fine five minutes ago,” I said. “He hadn’t sung yet, but he would have. Rosie had other ideas.”
Lacey swung around to look at the Cuban. The Cuban sneered with one side of his face. Lacey waited long enough for me to club him if I was going to, then turned wearily to face me.
“You know I got to take you in, Joe―long as I’m able.”
“You forget―I carry a Luger, Lacey.”
He looked at me sadly. “That’s no way to talk, boy.”
“Even the best of cops gets gun-walked once in a while.”
“What about Gunderson?”
“I’ll take the back way.”
He sighed again, a perplexed man in a complicated world.
“You’ll come in in the morning,” he said dully.
“Sure thing.”
“I sure hope to God you know what you’re doing, boy.”
I shoved Rosie away and slid into the seat and let the window down to free his hand. He sat down on the sand. Lacey looked at me sadly.

“It’s still a swell pinch,” I said. He didn’t answer. I backed, drove around the end of the barrier, swung back up past the VW to the highway. Two cars rested at the side of the road, locked together. Broken glass glittered on the pavement. A big deputy with no hat ran forward as if to cut me off. I gunned around him and off down the road to the north.

North of Cape Royal, a string of motels of diminishing grandeur petered out into off-brand gas stations, a lone eatery, closed up and dark, a defunct red-hot stand. Then the hills moved back in, crowding the highway. Up high a light showed here and there from a house hung on the cliff like a brooch on a dowager’s bosom. The road curved and the rock pulled back far enough for a small gas station blazing with lights to crowd in under it. I swung in beside the pumps. A husky kid with a wide jaw and hair the color of bleached khaki came out whistling and wiping his hands on a wad of cotton waste.
He nicked paint jamming the nozzle in, went around front and hoisted the hood, kept his head under it for all of five seconds and slammed it down, whistling all the while.
“A rock ever drop on you from up there?” I said.

He stopped whistling long enough to say “Nope,” and got right back on “Darn that Dream.” He smeared the windshield, gave the outside mirror a dab, strolled around back and polished the license plate, and leaned on the pump, watching the numbers go by. He was on “Ebb Tide” now, and having a little trouble with the phrasing.
I got out a cigarette and waved it in the general direction of the cliff top.
“Which one is the Prendergast place?”
He shook his head, unpuckered, and said, “Don’t light up, mister,” and picked up the beat without missing a note.
“Neat,” I said. “How’s about “Hora Staccato” for a big finish?”
He grinned through the music and topped off the tank and racked the hose, said “Four-eighty.”
I got out a ten and folded it lengthwise and held it so that he had to reach a little. I didn’t let go. He was so surprised he dropped “Stardust” in mid-chorus.
“I don’t plan to blow it up,” I said. “The Prendergast place, I mean.”
“Would I know, Jack?”
“Don’t kid me―a connoisseur like you. Two sharp brunettes and an El Dorado―or maybe a Jaguar. And no husbands; just the old uncle.” I leered at him. “Or so they say.”
“You mean maybe he’s not?”
“You get the idea.” I let go the bill and he tucked it away.
“Next right, about half a mile along.” He pointed with his ear. “First left off that. One of those redwood layouts with all glass on the ocean side and a carport on the roof. Say a mile altogether.”
“Don’t tell me,” I said. “I can’t miss it.” T got in under the wheel. He puckered up to whistle and grinned at me out of the corner of his eye and said, “You figure maybe he ain’t the uncle?”
“That’s not our problem,” I said. “All we want is our money.” I caught the beginning of a blank look as I pulled back out on the road.

I almost missed the turn, which was tucked back in under a mass of wind-twisted eucalyptus crowding a dilapidated pergola with a salt-pitted metal plate that read Bonito Rise. A narrow road, well paved but overgrown, followed a cut that curved back up through dense growth. Low-growing branches of yellow pine and black oak almost scraped the top of the car. It was a road that was carefully maintained to give the impression of not being maintained at all.

The odometer had clocked two-tenths of a mile when I saw the gravel drive branching left. A new-looking sign beside it said dead end―no exit. I switched to parking lights and turned in. The track climbed, twisting and turning around outcroppings of rock. When it seemed like I’d gone far enough I stopped and cut the switch and lights. I rolled down the window. The air smelled fresh and green and dark. Wind made moaning noises in the trees. Far below surf boomed with a dull, defeated sound.
I checked the Luger, set the safety, and tucked it back under my arm. The braided-leather sap I had taken off Rosie was in the glove compartment. I stuck it down in my right shoe, inside the sock.
Robbie stirred when I opened the door. I said, “Lie down, boy,” and he flopped back. The car still stunk of chloroform.
I got over on the shoulder and prowled up past three more curves and saw the house.

It was a complex of black shadows spread against black trees. Steep, one-sided gables thrust up here and there between stretches of flat roof. There was a sundeck with a railing around it, steps that went down among boulders as big as office safes.

The drive widened out into a car yard under the big pines. I circled it, keeping to the grass along the edge. A double garage was cantilevered out over empty air. The doors were closed, locked. I used the pocket flash on the crack at the hinge side, made out the flank of a black car inside. Could be Uncle Frank’s. Or maybe not. There are lots of black cars.

There was a door off the terrace and another at the foot of the steps, both solid planks, both locked. My key didn’t work in either of them. All the windows in reach were covered by metal gratings that would have been a cinch to remove with a D-8 and a length of one-inch braided steel cable. Outside what might have been the kitchen I thought I caught a faint odor of cookery. I sniffed again and wasn’t sure.

If there was anyone inside, he was keeping very, very still. Off in the woods an owl hooted. A pine cone dropped on the roof and clattered down the slope and off the edge past the garage. It made a metallic sound, striking something below. I went over that way and leaned far out past the corner of the building and saw a small flagged terrace ten feet below, on the other side of a redwood guardrail. There were two galvanized garbage cans in the corner; it was one of these the pine cone had hit. The rock leading down looked steep but climbable.

I got down there without turning more than two ankles. A neglected perforated steel table and two spring-mounted chairs covered with bird droppings and dried leaves were near the wall. The terrace extended around the corner and along the west side of a cut-back in the west front of the house; it ended in a blank wall with a flush door that matched the ones on the other side. I used my flash on a small window. It was double hung, with one large pane below and four smaller lights in the upper half, and almost dusty enough to obscure my view of a sheet of unpainted plywood nailed over it from the inside. I took off my coat and wrapped it around my fist and punched in the pane beside the latch. The glass dropped back against the plywood with what seemed like a lot of noise under the circumstances. The latch gave with some persuasion. I got the lower sash up and tested the spring of the plywood. It felt hopeful. I put a fist against an upper corner and leaned my weight on it. No luck. I folded my coat against it and jarred it with a couple of short right jabs. On the second one the nails came free with a sound like a shoat having his tail docked. Still no reaction from inside. I folded the plywood down out of the way and ducked inside.

The car was Frank’s Mercury. The tail pipe was cold. I went around it and tried a door in the far wall. It opened on three steps going down into a service hall. At the far end an open door gave into a kitchen probably smaller than the one at the Beverly Hilton, and with less counter space. There was a big range, stainless steel sinks, two wall ovens.

I went past a long table with a row of ladles and saucepans hanging from a rack above it and eased the refrigerator door open. Eggs, bacon, packaged cold cuts. What weekend guests might lay in for short stay. Beside the sink glasses and plates were racked on a drainboard. The hinge-top garbage can held potato peelings and grapefruit rinds that looked fresh. At least nothing had started to smell. I slipped the Luger out from under my arm and started across toward the swing door that looked as if it would lead to the main part of the house. I was halfway there when it banged open and light hit my eyes and a voice hammered out of cold rolled steel said, “Shed it and freeze, Jack.”

I couldn’t see the face behind the light but I recognized the voice of the Prendergast butler―if that was what he was. I stooped and put the Luger on the floor and straightened up with my hands well away from my sides. The light bobbed as he came toward me. I heard the swish and a sandbag like they use on the levee at Natchez hit me on the side of the head and knocked me a few hundred yards into a brick wall.

. . . somebody was hauling on my arm. I found a couple of feet and got them under me, with some difficulty due to the tilt of the floor. My head swelled and shrank in time to the revolution of the walls. I should stay out of kitchens. I didn’t do so well in them. Somebody was saying, “What is it, Thompson?” in Uncle Frank’s voice. The ceiling light went on. A couple of men that looked like Uncle Frank were standing in the doorway holding dressing gowns close under their chins. Two Thompsons were closer, off to one side, standing flat-footed, covering me with automatics. It was all happening on a well-lighted stage somewhere on the far side of a thick glass wall.
“Why―it’s Shaw,” the men that looked like Uncle Frank said. They stared at me. I got hold of my head and squeezed it back into shape.

“What on earth are you doing here?” Frank said. There was just one of him now. The walls weren’t traveling quite as fast and the floor had leveled out some. “What’s the matter with you? Have you been drinking?”

“Thompson got his sap out to show it to me and I ran into it with my head,” I said. “Careless.” I held on and felt seasick. Considering what I had for dinner it would be no great loss. Still, I hated to lose it in such nice company. I concentrated on breathing through my nose and the feeling subsided a little.
“I asked you what you were doing here,” Frank said again, with a nice snap of authority. “How did you get inside?”
“I guess Thompson forgot to lock up.”
The butler growled and said, “He’s lying, Frank!”
“Go check!”
Thompson didn’t move. “I better stick around,” he said flatly.
Frank let it go at that. “Who told you about this place?” he asked me.
“You could call it common knowledge.”
“Nonsense. I value privacy. I happen to have gone to some trouble to keep the location confidential.”
“In this town? You know better, Mr. Prendergast.”
“Very well, now that you’ve ferreted it out, what is it you want here?”
“I want to talk to my client.”
“What? He’s not―” He checked himself. “I never employed you, Mr. Shaw.”
“Miss Ellen. She paid me a retainer. I wanted to give it back. I don’t think I earned it.”
Frank’s lips tightened up. “She’s told me of your misguided efforts on her behalf. You may keep the fee.”
“I’d like to be fired in person, if you don’t mind,” I said.

“Don’t be absurd. As I told you over the telephone, this family has no further need of your services. I can’t imagine what you expected to accomplish by intruding here; I have every right to telephone the police and have you thrown in jail. However . . . “ He let the threat trail off.
“Good idea,” I said. “I’d feel better if I paid my debt to society. I was just kidding about the door. I busted in through the garage.”
Frank snorted. “You’re a fool. This nonsense has gone far enough. You may leave now, Mr. Shaw. Kindly don’t come back―ever.”
“Well, frankly, Mr. Prendergast, I’m not too happy about my client. I know you said she was with you, but I’d kind of like to see for myself. You understand.”
“Your arrogance is beyond belief. Thompson, show him out. And see that he leaves.”
Thompson jerked his chin toward the door, holding the gun nicely centered on my rib cage. “Lift ‘em, Jack. Let’s go. Out―like Mr. Prendergast said.”

Uncle Frank held the door. I went through it, staggering a little more than was strictly necessary. Thompson followed me along a wide carpeted hall, up two steps into a dining area, across that, down three steps into a big wide room with glass all along one side. There were low chairs arranged around a fieldstone fireplace; more chairs in conversational groupings. Soft light from an archway on the far side fell on a table with a silver ice bucket and a decanter, threw highlights off brass tools beside the fireplace. A curved stairway cantilevered from the wall led up to a railed gallery. I made it across the room without breaking anything, went up three wide carpeted steps past an acanthus in a teak tub, into another passage with a slab door at the end.
“Hold it there, Jack,” Thompson said. “Face the wall.”
I followed orders. He sidled past me, unsnapped a latch, threw the door open. The smell of pines flowed in.
“Out. I’m right behind with the heater.”

Outside, he switched on a flashlight, played it across teak decking, wooden steps. Halfway up, I stumbled more or less intentionally. Thompson waited well out of reach, holding the light on me until I got up.
At the top I stopped. The stars looked bright as Christmas tree ornaments.
“Nice night,” Thompson said. “Where’d you leave your heap?”
“Down the road.”
He shone the flash along that way.
“Show me.”

He stayed ten feet behind. My shadow bobbed against the trees; my back felt as wide as a ranch gate. A hundred yards from the house I stumbled again and went down harder than I meant to. This time I got the sap out of my sock and into my hand.
“Come on, on the feet, gumshoe,” Thompson said. “We got a little farther to go.”
“I’m pretty dizzy,” I said. “I have to rest.”
“You’ll get plenty rest, pal.”

“I’m going to be sick,” I said, and stayed where I was. Thompson swore and took a quick step toward me and swung his foot. I leaned away from it and swung the sap at his ankle―the only part of him I could reach. It wasn’t a bad swing, considering. It connected just above the arch and I heard and felt bone go. Thompson made a gargling noise and the gun banged and stabbed flame into the gravel. I hit him in the ribs with my shoulder and carried him back and down, rolled clear and came to my knees. I had the gun now. He tried to get up and the broken ankle folded and he went down hard on his face. While he was down I laid the sap behind his ear, not gently. He spread himself on the drive and snored. I picked up the light and went through him. Aside from a switchblade in his side pocket, a set of Japanese folding brass knuckles on his hip, and a .25 Walther in a shoulder rig. he was unarmed.

It took me a few minutes to hog-tie him with his belt and tie, and drag him over to the side of the road. The mosquitoes were pretty thick over there, but he wouldn’t mind that. I left him there and started back up toward the house.

There was a glow behind a skylight; a little light leaked out from behind closed drapes along the living room side. I went down the wooden steps and across the teak deck and put an ear against the door. No sound came through it. I teased the door open and was back inside. Voices came from somewhere, a low murmur without meaning. They got louder as I went along the hall. Somewhere a door banged open; feet scuffled. I went flat against the wall next to the potted plant and got the Luger into my hand and heard Frank say, “Damn you, girl, listen to me!”

More scuffling, with heavy breathing. They were in the living room now. There was the meaty sound of a blow, then feet coming toward me. I felt for a light switch and found it and a soft glow sprang up behind a cove just under the ceiling. Ellen Prendergast was at the foot of the steps below me. She stopped dead and stared up at me with eyes that looked as big and blank as black pansies. The sleeve of the little blue jacket was torn, a button missing. Her face was pale to the lips and she was breathing between her teeth in harsh gasps, like a winded runner.
“Private fight?” I said. “Or can anybody get a knuckle in?”

Uncle Frank was across the room, near the fireplace. His face was haggard and old, twisted into an expression like one of those stone faces that spout water. A small nickle-plated automatic lay on the rug in the center of the room. Frank’s eyes jumped to it.
“Uh-uh,” I said. “It’s not that kind of party.”
Ellen made a faint whimpering sound and started to sway. I went down the two steps and got an arm under her. Frank edged sideways, looking past me.
“Thompson won’t be along for a while,” I said. “He got tied up.”

“Y-you have no r-right,” Frank started to babble. “We―you’re intruding in a family affair!” But his voice crumbled like stale bread. I walked Ellen over to the nearest chair and she slid down into it.
“I’m sorry,” she whispered, and sat up straight. “That was foolish of me.”

I picked up the .22 and dropped it in my pocket. Uncle Frank reached for the decanter on the table, poured himself a couple of fingers of brandy. His hand shook so that the glass tinkled like little bells. The bouquet drifted across to me as smooth as an angel’s wing, but he put it back in a lump like bar whisky. He touched his tongue to his lips and braced his shoulders a little. I holstered the Luger and got out a cigarette and tapped it on my thumb.
“Expecting Miss Mianne soon?” I said.
“That is none of your affair,” Frank said. His lips looked gray. His face was the color and texture of the kind of paper they wrap apples in.

I nodded. “By the way,” I said, “the cops have Rosie and Sid.” I fit the weed and let some smoke drift along the room. “Maybe that’s a break for you after all, Frank. Or maybe not. It’s a fine point.”
“I haven’t the faintest idea what you’re talking about,” Frank said, barely moving his lips.
“Oh―I almost forgot,” I said. “Rosie talked some. Sid didn’t talk. He’s dead. The cops have an idea I did it. You can see the spot that puts me in.”
“I’m not in the least interested,” Frank started to whisper, but I waved that away.
“That line was all right yesterday, but things have happened since then. I don’t have time for the coy play. I have most of the picture but there are a few gaps you could fill in.”
Frank said, “Get out,” but not as if he expected anybody to move.

“It was the snapshot of Harvey that tipped me first, Frank,” I said. “It showed a man who was nearly bald, way back in the early forties. You and Harvey looked alike in those days―but he still had hair when he died; the news clips showed it combed the way vain old men comb their last few locks―straight across, like J. Paul Getty. Nobody would invest in a hair piece with that much scalp showing through. So it was real, and it was your silvery mane that was the rug. And the pic was you, not Harvey―which tied you to the orphanage.”
Ellen made a little sound and turned to look at me with a strange expression.
“How much did Harvey pay you for his grandchildren, Frank?” I said.
“You’re raving,” Frank said in a voice as faint as the promptings of conscience.

“Sure. Just let me rave a little. Harvey had heard about his son’s marriage―of which he no doubt disapproved―and the birth of the twins. When the parents died he had a change of heart. He wanted the children. But he didn’t know where they were. You did. One of them was in an orphanage at Tampa. You paid off a man named Pate and he handed her over. So far so good.”

Ellen was staring at Frank across the room with a look like the one just before the scream. He was holding one of his bony hands with the other, as if it might get away and bite him. He took a couple of tottery steps and sank down in a chair.
“You’re distorting the facts,” he said. “You make it sound like something . . . underhanded. Of course I helped him find the children. After all, I was his brother―”

“Sure. You tried to kill him once, and almost made it. He let you off the hook. I wouldn’t know why. Maybe he took the brotherly end of it more seriously than you did. I don’t know how the trouble started between you. Maybe it was just the fact that you started together and he finished way ahead. That would be hard to take, I guess.”

“It was nothing like that. Harvey was a cold man. He threw his son out of the house, cut him out of his will. The boy came to me. When he and Connie were killed I was left with the infants. I had no way to care for them. I placed them with a home. What else could I have done?”
I didn’t answer that one. He didn’t wait for me to.

“I admit at first I was not inclined to have anything to say to Harvey. I felt he didn’t deserve to have the children, a man like that. Then later―well, I saw I had no right to keep them from their patrimony.”
“I guess there’s nothing in my idea that you hid them out until he was in a mood to deal generously.”
“That’s fantastic. It was just as I told you―”
“There’s another question that nags at me, Frank. You knew there was money to be made from the twins. How come you let one of them get away?”
A ripple ran along his upper lip like a sneer looking for a place to park.
“I was not responsible for that. The man Pate . . . “ He tried to clamp his jaw shut, but it kept on quivering.
“What happened, Frank,” I said gently. “Did he hit her too hard?”
Frank’s face seemed to fall in on itself a little more. It wasn’t much more than a skull now, with the clownish wig askew on it.

“Well, there you were, Frank,” I said. “You had a deal―but Harvey was paying for an unbroken set, and you were one baby short. But luckily Pate could help you out. Maybe that’s how he saved his neck. He tipped you to where you could pick up a replacement. It wouldn’t be a matched set―but there are such things as non-identical twins―like you and Harvey. So you traced the Conroys West and bid her in. Harvey paid off. Everybody was happy.”
“Lies,” Frank muttered. “Distortions. I was concerned only with the welfare of my nieces.”
Ellen laughed suddenly, not the nicest of laughs. It had that dizzily balanced sound, like squirrels on a tightwire.
“Oh, yes. Uncle Frank was always concerned for the welfare of his nieces.”
“Well, the years passed,” I said. “Times got tough.
You and Harvey didn’t get along, but still, there was all that money. You got to thinking and you came up with an idea.”
There was a slight draft on the back of my neck. I moved a step sideways and gave Miss Ellen a reassuring smile that ricocheted off her face and died.

“Here was Harvey Prendergast, rich, stiff-necked, pompous, publicity shy. With two daughters who were really his granddaughters. And one of them not even that. There had to be money in it. Hitting Harvey with it might have worked, but only in a small way. Harvey was a man who liked a buck as well as the next fellow, even when the next fellow was you. You could embarrass him, but not more than a few grand worth. There had to be a better angle.”
“I don’t know why I’m listening,” Frank said.
“It wasn’t a thing to be gone into hastily,” I said. “The operation called for planning, and patience. Plenty of patience.

“Of course, there were the Conroys. They knew things. They’d been paid off, but they might get restless when they got wind of the new dividend. But they didn’t really count for much. They were the kind of people who never really had a chance. They’d struggled a little against what heredity and environment had for them, had even made a little progress. But the easy money and the thing they’d had to do for it had knocked that out. The ten grand was gone fast; maybe for the down on the house. Then all they had was the little voice that came in the night. That, and maybe wondering now and then how the baby was making out, if the man who said he was her uncle was treating her right. But they were no real threat. A visit, a few hints, a little cash, took care of that. The coast was clear.”
Frank undamped his hands and let them creep across his chest. His eyes looked past me; his mouth hung open. He made a strangled noise.

“So you contacted the false Miss Prendergast, told her who you were, told her the story―or parts of it. She was a girl with great expectations―but not if Harvey Prendergast found out who she was: a nobody―a waif who’d been rung in on him. Personal relationships didn’t mean much to Harvey, but Family was everything.”
Frank shook his head, slowly, as if he was testing his neck. His mouth opened and closed; a thin sound leaked from the corner of it.

“You figured you were solid, Frank. You couldn’t miss. But she fooled you. She told you to go to hell. And that created a problem. You hadn’t figured on that. The threat was good―as long as the victim played ball. But if Harvey threw her out on her ear it didn’t mean a dime to you.”

“I told him . . . I was glad,” Ellen said, in a high, rapid voice, like an old maid reporting a rape attempt. “I hated my life, hated my father, hated being who I was, where I was. I didn’t care. I laughed at him. I told him―at least now I didn’t have him as an uncle.”
I didn’t look at her.
“But you had one more round in the chamber, didn’t you, Frank? The other girl. A bluff might work. You gave her the pitch―not mentioning how you’d struck out the first time. And she believed you.”
Ellen leaned forward toward her uncle. “You―you vicious old liar,” she said. “You promised me―”

“She believed you,” I said, “maybe because she was old enough to remember a little. Fred and Mae, the long trip, the strangeness. She’d always had the feeling she didn’t quite belong in the big house.” I went across and stubbed out the cigarette in an ash tray like a ten-pound ice block that had been melting in the sun. Frank’s eyes followed me. I’d seen customers at the morgue who looked healthier.
“She swallowed your story, didn’t she, Frank? Hook, line, and fisherman.”
“Ellen,” Frank croaked. “Get my doctor.”
“Things looked good―for a while,” I said. “Then they started to go a little wrong.”
I poured some of Frank’s brandy into a glass and slid it across my tongue. It felt good. I swallowed the rest.
“Funny thing about a man like you, Frank,” I said.
“You feed your own hungers―but you never stop to think there might be other appetites around. Appetites that are used to the big table, that won’t share, that aren’t content with scraps.”
“Maybe I’d better call the doctor,” Ellen said.

“Maybe later,” I said. “For a careful man, you didn’t cover your trail very well, Frank. First, Rosie and Sid: I thought for a while they were just some of Lou Anglich’s old Tampa chickens coming home to molt; but Lou dropped out of sight, and they were still with me. I dropped a few hints here and there as to where I might be going next. The ones they picked up were the ones I fed to you.
“Then there was the matter of the timing the day Mrs. Prendergast died. You came home at a bad time―bad for you. If I hadn’t been there first, things might have been awkward.”
“Are you trying to imply . . . ?” Frank let it hang there. I could almost hear him thinking it over.
“You lied to the police about going to Las Vegas, Frank―when there was no need to. That’s dangerous business, even without an unsolved murder or two lying around on the books.”
“I told you―”
“Yeah, you told me. And who told you, Frank?”
He looked at me with his mouth open.

“All along you’ve behaved like a man taking orders, Frank. Someone’s been doing your thinking for you. And you’ve been going along―building the platform, getting the rope all ready, adjusting it around your own neck. You even picked the hangman, and all along you’ve been telling yourself you were in charge.”
“That’s―that’s impossible―insane―”
“Uh-uh, Frank. You’ve been kidding yourself long enough. It’s time to wake up and take a good look at a few things. She didn’t look like that kind of girl―but do they ever?”
Frank Prendergast stiffened in his chair; his feet, in shiny wing-toed shoes, slid forward on the rug. He raked at his chest.
“It’s his heart,” Ellen said, in a crisp voice, like a dedicated fan explaining a tricky play around left end. “I really think I must get help for him.”

“After a while,” I said. “It was a little ironic that after the ringer gave you the horse laugh, the real Prendergast girl believed you. Those are the little surprises that make life interesting. But you had another surprise in store―maybe bigger than the first. You had pointed out to the young lady that if Harvey got the idea she was no relation of his, she’d be out of his will faster than an option dropping. But instead of folding like a show hanky all ready to be slipped into your pocket, she took a more direct approach. She killed him.”
Ellen gave a little scream and twisted her fingers together until the knuckles went white.

“It wasn’t hard,” I said. “A good squirt of red hot botulism culture on his sandwich, and she was out of range of any nasty rumors. And after all―it wasn’t as if she was really committing patricide. Harvey wasn’t really her father―or so you’d convinced her.”
Ellen came up out of her chair. Her eyes were a little wild. She said: “You killed my father!” and jammed her knuckles into her teeth.

“Afterwards she spelled it out for you: play ball or she’d pin it on you. You were in a spot. You’d tried to kill him once. You had motive and opportunity. And when they started digging, they’d find you had a record back in Florida. You could spill the whole story, but who’d believe an old ex-con when she batted those big innocent eyes and cried a little? She was covered. There was nothing to tie her to the spiked sandwich. And she was smart enough even then not to overplay her hand. She had you on a rope, but she wasn’t ready to hang you. Not quite yet. She was a girl who could look ahead. She was living under false pretenses, eating high on somebody else’s hog. That could all disappear in a minute―if there was someone else out there who knew the story. That meant she had to get hers quick, before the bubble popped. And for that, you’d be useful. She told you all this. She had you cold. So you played along.”
Ellen turned and lunged for my pocket. I caught her wrists; she was a strong girl.
“Give me the gun,” she whispered. “He’s evil, evil!”
I pushed her back into her chair and held her there until she went slack and started to cry quietly.

“The trick was to loot the estate without attracting too much attention. That was where you came in, Frank. You knew the ins and outs of business―especially dirty business. You knew who to pay off, how to work it. You saw to it that funds were shifted from the conservative investments Harvey had socked away to chancier propositions―the kind that fold suddenly in the night, leaving a bunch of trimmed shareholders wondering where the capital went. Rex London helped out there. You channeled a lot of your take through his tables on a percentage deal―a good enough cover for some of the outflow of cash, if they didn’t dig too hard. And why should they?”
Ellen sobbed. Frank shook his head and made noises that didn’t even try to be words.

“Everything seemed to be working swell; and then Lou Anglich hit town, showing a picture of a child and asking questions. And he had a picture of you, Frank. That brought your old pal Pate out of the woodwork. He got to you, implied things, feeling for an opening. That worried you. You looked up a little man named Carlotti, an old acquaintance from Florida. He and a couple of other boys went out to have a talk with Lou. That didn’t work out. Lou dropped out of sight. He’d been seen at my office. Your boys tailed me back to Jaster. That was too much connection. The boys chilled him and shook down his office, but didn’t hit pay dirt. That left me for you to worry about. You didn’t really like all this killing, so the boys had instructions just to bend me a little. Something went wrong there, too. Maybe you needed some new boys, Frank.”
“I don’t know what you’re talking about,” Frank said in a monotone.

“Mr. Shaw,” Ellen said. “I’ve heard enough. I can’t stand any more. All this deceit, treachery, violence, in my own family. It’s more than I can bear. Please―take me away from here!” She said all this in a rush, with heavy breathing.

“There’s not much more to tell,” I said. “Jaster had something that had to be found. Maybe you had it, Frank. Your partner wouldn’t have put it past you to hold out. She got you out of the house and searched your room. No luck. Then she had a better idea. Maybe the old lady knew something. She asked her. Maybe she wasn’t satisfied with the answers. The conversation got out of hand. Mrs. Prendergast was pretty frail. Her neck broke. So she dumped her down the stairs and I showed up and she cracked me over the head and beat it out the back way.”
Ellen stood suddenly; she hugged herself and shivered.
“I can’t listen to any more of this,” she said, and started to turn away.
“You don’t want to miss the punch line, Miss Ellen,” I said. She looked at me and shivered again; but she waited.

“You might think a woman would lose her head after a close call like that,” I said. “But not this girl. She had found Lou Anglich. She knew all about Anya. She drove out there and told him who she was. When she asked him to go with her he went like a lamb.”
“Why?” Ellen said. “Why . . . would she . . . ?”

“She thought he might know things she needed to know. But you don’t crowbar information out of a man like Anglich. She had to play it with roses. That would take time. She had to get him off by himself and con him gracefully. But that didn’t pan out either. Lou didn’t tell her the things she wanted to know because he didn’t know them. He was no part of the shakedown. He was just a poor old roughneck, looking for a lost dream.”
“Guesses,” Frank croaked. “Wild imaginings. How could you possibly know―” He stopped and looked surprised and sank back in the deep chair.

“By this time it was pretty clear that things were coming apart. There were too many angles, too many people who knew too many things. It was time to get out. Most of the haul was already safely stashed somewhere, probably south of the border.”
Frank uttered an exclamation.

“Didn’t you know, Frank? But then you wouldn’t, would you? She was still stringing you along with the idea that you were partners, that in the end the two of you could sit back and enjoy the Prendergast name and the Prendergast fortune. The catch was, there isn’t any Prendergast fortune. Not any more. She cleaned it, Frank―she and Rex London. There’s not enough left in the kitty to finance a weenie roast for the help.”
Frank made stuttering noises.
“That’s why everything was set up for the big finale, Frank. That’s why she had you tell lies to the police, and why you’re here tonight.”
“What . . . do you mean?”
My cigarette had burned down. I lit another one while he stared up at me like a cancer patient waiting for the report on the X-rays.
“You still don’t see, do you, Frank? You can’t get it through your head that a little girl you once bought and sold like a pet kitten could and would truss you up and throw you to the dogs.”
Frank started to get up out of his chair; Ellen took a step back. They stopped, poised that way.
“You’re the fall guy, Frank,” I said softly. “That’s what she kept you for all along. She didn’t really need you for the rest. Not even for what was planned for tonight.”
“Tonight?”

“It would have looked like murder and suicide. The heiress, murdered by her uncle, who then shot himself. The other heiress missing and presumed sunk in a lake somewhere. When they discovered the estate was stripped―and your hand would show up in that, not hers―the motive would be clear. You’d robbed the family till, lost the money gambling―she saw to it you planted a reputation for plunging on the tables. When your niece caught you out, you killed her, then blew your brains out in a fit of remorse. Neat, tidy, and not a bit too flashy for Mayfair Heights. How does it sound?”
“Murder? What are you talking about?” Frank’s whisper was like a ghost asking himself where he’d taken a wrong turning, back when he was alive.
“Get Mianne in here,” I said. “And we’ll see.”
“Mianne . . . is in Mexico,” Frank whispered.
“There’s a light on in an upstairs room,” I said. “Maybe you forgot about the skylight.”
“There’s no one there, Mr. Shaw.” Ellen said in a tone of gentle reproof, like a nun reprimanding a novice for telling her beads too fast.
“I’d kind of like to see for myself, Miss Ellen.”
“Mr. Shaw,” Ellen said in a voice that was all alone on a tightwire, high above the crowd, “I’m going now.”
“Uh-uh,” I said. “Not just yet, Miss Ellen.”
“Would you . . . try to stop me?”
I looked at her; she stared back at me.
“Let’s go up,” I said. “You lead the way, Uncle Frank.”

He levered himself out of his chair and gave me a look as empty as Pharaoh’s tomb; his hand fluttered at his throat. He turned and went past me toward the stairs. Ellen shivered again and followed him. I brought up the rear.
Frank stopped in front of a door.
“The next one,” I said. He moved on to it. It was a nice slab of bleached teak with a fancy brass lock built into the outside. Frank tried the knob.
“Locked,” he said, and looked vaguely puzzled.
I got out the key I had taken off Rosie. They watched me try it, and I watched them watching me. It fit. The latch clacked and the door swung in.

Mianne Prendergast was standing by an unmade bed. She was dressed in the same gray suit I’d seen her in three days before. Her black hair was swept severely back, tied behind. There was no make-up on her face. Her cheekbones stood out like ridges in the desert. The window behind her was boarded over, under the drapes. There was a rug, a chest of drawers, chairs, a door in the wall opposite the bath, a skylight in the slanted ceiling. It was a nice room but it smelled as frowsty as a cell at the Railroadmen’s Y.

Mianne drew a deep breath and looked at me, past me at Ellen. Ellen came into the room, moving stiffly, like a cat in a strange kitchen. Frank sidled in and slid sideways along the wall and leaned there.
“All present or accounted for,” I said. “Who wants to tell the rest?”
Mianne shook her head slowly, like a TV nurse reporting no hope. Ellen’s face twitched. Frank looked at a spot on the floor between the two women.

“Murder is like sex,” I said. “It can’t stand too much talking about. Let’s talk about it anyway. It’s here, in this room. I can feel it leering out of the wallpaper like a dirty old voyeur. Can you feel it, Frank?”
He made a rather curious sound, something like an elderly owl might make, laying her first egg.
“What about you, Miss Mianne?”
“Go away,” she whispered in a voice with no more strength than a nonagenarian’s last wish.
“Miss Ellen?”
She looked at me. She was hugging herself again. She smiled a frail little smile, like a forget-me-not in the snow.
“You’re playing with me, aren’t you, Mr. Shaw?”

I shook my head. “Not me, Miss Ellen. The one who planted the plague in Harvey’s lobster salad had a cute taste for games. The routine with Jaster was a nice frolic―while it lasted. Mrs. Prendergast played one hand and lost. And it was a fun routine with Rosie and Sid. But tonight’s the big night. This is the climax, the pay-off. This is the night the killer gets well―and the play is with the house’s money.”
“I don’t like allegories, Mr. Shaw.”
I waved a hand. “There are four of us in this room.
One murderer, two slated as victims, one patsy to take the rap and die.”
“Really? Would you care to identify us?”
“I’m victim number one. Too bad, I snooped too hard. I’ll have to go. And of course Uncle Frank will be the suicide.”
“And the others, Mr. Shaw?” Ellen’s voice was as gray and fragile as a rope of ash.
“Easy,” I said, and raised my voice. “Little Anya has to die too, for the killer to collect the prize.”

I moved fast then, but not fast enough. The door six feet to my left exploded. Lou Anglich came through it like a switch engine hitting a roadblock, in a hail of splinters. I had my Luger halfway out; he slammed through me, bounced me against the wall hard enough to loosen my back teeth. The gun went flying somewhere. Anglich skidded to a stop, spun to face the room. His eyes were like the muzzles of a pair of smoking forty-fives.
“Who’s gonna hurt little Anya?” he said, and took a step forward.
“Wrong girl, Lou,” I said. “That’s not Anya.”
Lou halted. He swung to look at me, like Goliath noticing David. His hands opened and closed. He said, “Hah?”
“The other one is Anya,” I growled. “This one wants to kill her.”
Anglich turned to stare at Ellen. Her arms that were folded, hugging her, unfolded. There was a shiny little automatic in her hand.
“Stand back,” she said.
Lou took a step toward her. He whispered “Anya?”

The gun jumped, once, twice, three times. The shots were hard slaps of sound, and over the slaps the other slaps, of lead striking flesh. Lou stopped dead. Three red flowers bloomed suddenly on his rumpled white shirt, down low, just above the belt. He folded his arms carefully over his stomach, as if he were cradling a baby. He made a sound halfway between a grunt and a sigh. His mouth opened and closed. He turned his torso without moving his feet and went over sideways like London Bridge falling down.
Ellen stepped sideways around him. The gun in her fist was as steady as the cornerstone of the Bureau of Standards. She reached the door and kicked it wide.

“Mianne is coming with me,” she said. Skim ice was never more brittle than her voice. “For your good behavior, Mr. Shaw, I’ll free her at the border. Unless there’s trouble. You understand.” She motioned with the gun.

Lou Anglich made a sound and drew his knees up. He got his hands under him and pushed his torso up a few inches from the floor. The expression on his face was of a man intent on an important task that wasn’t going well but which had to be done. The end of his tongue came out and touched the sweat on his upper lip. He frowned and fell on his face and blood came out of the corner of his mouth.

Mianne made a small whimpering sound and went to him, knelt beside him. She lifted the big rough head into her lap. His eyes were half shut; the stubble on his broad cheek was like a smear of soot. His lips moved. Mianne leaned over him. Then he went still all over, with no more fuss than a cloud shadow passing over a hill.
“Come along,” Ellen said. Mianne got to her feet. There was blood on her skirt. She went past Ellen into the hall.
“Wait a minute,” I said.
Ellen looked back at me. “Don’t talk, Mr. Shaw. You’re a clever man. I should kill you, of course; all of you. But I really hate killing. Wait two hours before you leave the house.”
She pushed the door shut and the latch clicked. I listened to their footsteps until I couldn’t hear them anymore.

Frank hadn’t moved, he stood against the wall in a half crouch, paying no attention to me. I went to the window. The plywood sheet covering it was three-quarters of an inch thick, screwed in place, solid. The skylight was too high and the angle of the roof too steep to do me any good. I leaned against the door. Long experience of butting stone walls with my head told me not to waste my time there.

I went through the broken connecting door into the room where Anglich had hidden out. The hall door was locked, but it was just a door. I backed up and hit it with the old linebacker’s plunge and was out in the hall.

There was light enough from the living room to get me down the stairs. A cold draft was blowing along the hall. The door to the deck was open. I went across and up the wooden steps and had one foot on the gravel when I heard the scream. Before it was finished another scream mingled with it. A dog barked once, a deep, hoarse baying. Then the shots, two of them, close together, like Chinese crackers. Then nothing.

I had covered about a hundred yards when headlights went on down below. Mianne was standing in the road, silhouetted in the fight. The dog was on his side between her and the car, looking as big as a yearling calf in the pool of black that spread under him.
Ellen lay huddled between the dog and the car. From fifty feet away I could see the tear in her neck, as clean as a razor cut.

“He came out of the car like a thunderbolt, without a sound,” Mianne said in a voice as drained as a vampire’s victim. “She went down. Then the shots. Even then―so horribly hurt―she fought back.” She shuddered violently. “Poor Robbie. And poor Ellen. She wanted so badly to live.”
“Don’t we all,” I said. “Come on. Let’s go back up to the house and call some law.”

It was a couple of days later. I was sitting in a hard chair in a room full of old cigar smoke and the smell of policemen. Lieutenant Dreyfus smiled at me across the desk. It wasn’t the kind of smile that warms an unfriendly world.

“You played it just right, Shaw,” he said sadly. “Another death―two if you want to count Anglich―and an old man in the hospital on pure oxygen not expected to last another night. Nice work. Maybe if you’d confided in the Police Department some of that could have been saved.”
“Sure―if I’d known anything. All I had was guesses. Hell, I wasn’t sure until I saw Mianne on her feet which one was the real killer.”
His head cocked sideways like an alert robin tuning in on a worm.
“You’d already seen Ellen shoot Anglich down―or so you stated.”
“Sure; but that could have been panic. If she’d been a prisoner in the house this might have looked like her last chance. And she had no proof I wasn’t in on the plan.”

He looked at me without a whole lot of approval. “It’s a lucky thing for you that you have a friend in the sheriff’s office. Lacey gives you a good character. He says you wouldn’t break anybody’s neck unless maybe you didn’t like them. So I guess we can chalk Sid up to Rosie. It won’t make much difference to him, where he’s going.”
“That’s thoughtful of you, Lieutenant,” I said.
“I guess we can chalk this Jaster up to the same account,” he said. “No point in smearing the girl’s name any further.” He looked at me sideways. “No matter what her name is,” he added.
I did the business of getting out a cigarette and tapping it on my thumbnail. Dreyfus watched me, smiling a little sadly.

“Kind of tough on a girl, one day an heiress with a family, next day an orphan and broke―or almost. Maybe I should have told her to stay around, but what the hell. She’s been through a lot. Mexico will be good for her, eh?”
I nodded.

He looked at the corner of the ceiling. “I guess she must have had a little something socked away in the sugar bowl for a rainy day, at that. Seems like she opened an account just before she drove south. Nothing important, you understand. Just a hundred and forty some grand, cash deposit.”
I rolled the cigarette in my fingers, another of my suave mannerisms. “That so?”

“Uh-huh. I don’t suppose the Treasury boys would be interested. If you’ve lost a million, a few thousand is just salvage, you might say. But you wouldn’t care about that. Nothing to do with you, eh, Shaw? You’re just a workingman, putting in his time for fifty a day and expenses.”
“I’m thinking of bumping it to seventy-five,” I said. “Just to stay competitive.”
Dreyfus yawned and stretched. “Yeah. We’ll call you if we get puzzled by anything.”
I started to get up, but he went on talking:
“I still don’t quite see what this Anglich person was doing, stashed at the Prendergast place. That connection’s not too clear.” He hooked an eyebrow up and looked at my chin.

“Jaster got wind of him when he began nosing around the orphanages, flashing Anya’s picture,” I said. “He tipped Frank; Frank told the girl. They sent Rosie and Sid around to ask why, but that didn’t work out too well. So Ellen found out where he was hiding and went to see him. I’d guess she had the little gun in her bag―but she didn’t use it. She told Lou she was Anya, and he bought it. He told her things that made her decide he’d be nice to have alive, for the time being. She sweet-talked him out of his hole and into a room at the beach house. She kept him there the same way.”
“He couldn’t have been too well hidden―if she found him.”

“I did some wondering about that, too. Rosie and Sid were a possibility, but I’d already had my run-in with them. I was careful. Nobody tailed me. That means Lou must have phoned out. Maybe he got lonely and risked a call to my office and got the answering service. They could have strung him long enough to trace the call―if the price was right.” I mashed out the cigarette. “I changed answering services, this morning.”

“Maybe. Or maybe you’re not as hot as you think you are. Anybody can be followed if somebody’s willing to take the trouble. Maybe Ellen Prendergast followed you herself. It didn’t have to be two men in derby hats.”
“Maybe a lot of things, Lieutenant. Life is full of maybes. Maybe it doesn’t matter much―now.”
“Academic,” Dreyfus agreed. “Like the question of why your man Pate gave Anglich the lead in the first place. He could have put him off with any old story.”
“Maybe he did,” I said.
Dreyfus looked at me alertly.

“Pate was having his neck squeezed. He might have improvised a little. Throwing in Frank’s picture might have been his idea of a cute little trick, to muddy the waters. Maybe afterwards it got to seeming not so cute. So he came out to check up. He smelled money in it, and made the last in a lifetime full of mistakes.”
Dreyfus nodded, looking thoughtful, in a sleepy-eyed way that had probably fooled a lot of crooks into underestimating him.
“Anyway Anglich died happy, eh, Shaw? He thought he’d found her.” He grinned a cynical grin.
“Who knows?” I said. “Maybe he had.”
The grin got a little crookeder. “Yeah. As you say, who knows?”

I got up. “Good night, Lieutenant,” I said. He shook his head and didn’t answer. I went out, along an empty hall, out into an empty street under an empty night sky. The car was waiting where I had left it under the pepper trees. I got in it and drove over to the office.

There were no lights on there. My feet echoed in the corridor hke a caretaker making the rounds the day after the end of the world. Nobody was waiting for me in the anteroom. There was a musty, embalmed smell in my private thinking parlor. Maybe it was the odor of the private detection game.

I got out the fresh bottle and checked to see if it was what the label said. It seemed to be. I administered another dose and opened the safe and got out the envelope with the birth certificates in it. I took another envelope out of my inside pocket and spread everything out on the desk. Two pieces of paper, yellow around the edges, and two glossy photographs of footprints, white swirls on black. I had lifted one from the bathroom of the apartment where Mianne had been locked up, with the help of a ten-buck tip to the cop on the door. The other had been supplied gratis by an old acquaintance at the morgue.

I got a magnifying glass out of the drawer and looked at the prints of the naked female feet, and at the smaller prints on the certificates. I looked at them for a long time. I put the glass away and poured another sample of my tonic and drank that and listened to my watch tick for a while.

I tore the papers into small pieces, starting with the birth certificates. I heaped the pieces in the big glass ash tray and lit a match and sat back and watched it burn. When it was all gone, I poked at the ashes with a pencil until they were black dust and dumped the whole mess into the wastebasket.

The room was a little smoky; I opened a window and watched the gray tendrils drift out and add themselves to the smog layer that reflected pink light above the city. The night air smelled fresh and cool, with a hint of rain. Maybe tomorrow would be a nice day.

“Another maybe,” I said. “Maybe everything’s coming up roses. Maybe life will unfold and you’ll get rich and happy and die in bed at ninety surrounded by loving faces crying a little, but not too much to spoil things. And maybe not.”
Nobody answered. I rode the elevator downstairs and walked along the dark street and the rain was cool and sweet on my face.
The End
